commit_message:
Remove eventlet cap

This is preventing any testing of projects with the new eventlet
because it causes a requirements conflict.  We need to first remove
the cap in oslo.service in order to move forward with this process.

Change-Id: I1cbd25041981b68a3b2573162cba2f5ea4cb6f85

commit_message:
Fix Cinder's default db purge cron settings

Change the CinderCronDbPurgeAge default value to 30 so that it matches
the default value in puppet-cinder.

Closes-Bug: #1761749
Change-Id: I00e1b257067bb4bff955f65ca8256092470a5cdc

subject: Prevent pending file flushing to retiring db
messages: [{'account_id': 7847, 'date': '2018-04-03 20:53:46.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 1.'}, {'account_id': 7847, 'date': '2018-04-04 14:24:50.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 2.'}, {'account_id': 7847, 'date': '2018-04-06 16:21:01.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2: Workflow-1'}, {'account_id': 7847, 'date': '2018-04-06 17:05:08.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 3.'}, {'account_id': 7847, 'date': '2018-04-07 09:59:21.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 4.'}, {'account_id': 7847, 'date': '2018-04-09 21:12:30.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 5: Patch Set 4 was rebased.'}, {'account_id': 15343, 'date': '2018-04-10 19:42:23.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 5: Workflow+1 Code-Review+2\n\nYeah, I think this all makes sense. I still worry a little that we don't seem to verify that self corresponds to self.db_files[-1] in get_brokers(), but that's been there for a bit..."}]
revisions:
[{'created': '2018-04-03 20:53:46.000000000', 'message': "Always commit pending file updates to fresher db

Before, while a container was in sharding state, a container GET
called ContainerBroker.list_objects_iter() on the retiring broker,
with the goal of listing any objects in the retiring
db. list_objects_iter() flushes any pending object updates into the
broker's object table, which in this scenario was the retiring db,
causing the retiring db to be polluted.

The opportunity for pending updates to pollute was limited; before
calling list_objects_iter() the container GET method calls the broker
get_info_is_deleted() method which also flushes the pending file, so
the vulnerability is only to updates arriving in the pending file
after that point in time.

Now, when list_objects_iter() is called from the server GET method, it
uses the fresh db broker to flush the pending file and uses the
retiring db broker to list objects.

Change-Id: I268d01a373491c693b793748065d212f9703ffab
"}, {'created': '2018-04-04 14:24:50.000000000', 'message': "Always commit pending file updates to fresher db

Before, while a container was in sharding state, a container GET
called ContainerBroker.list_objects_iter() on the retiring broker,
with the goal of listing any objects in the retiring
db. list_objects_iter() flushes any pending object updates into the
broker's object table, which in this scenario was the retiring db,
causing the retiring db to be polluted.

The opportunity for pending updates to pollute was limited; before
calling list_objects_iter() the container GET method calls the broker
get_info_is_deleted() method which also flushes the pending file, so
the vulnerability is only to updates arriving in the pending file
after that point in time.

Now, when list_objects_iter() is called from the server GET method, it
uses the fresh db broker to flush the pending file and uses the
retiring db broker to list objects.

Change-Id: I268d01a373491c693b793748065d212f9703ffab
"}, {'created': '2018-04-06 17:05:08.000000000', 'message': "Prevent pending file flushing to retiring db

Before, while a container was in sharding state, a container GET
called ContainerBroker.list_objects_iter() on the retiring broker,
with the goal of listing any objects in the retiring
db. list_objects_iter() flushes any pending object updates into the
broker's object table, which in this scenario was the retiring db,
causing the retiring db to be polluted.

The opportunity for pending updates to pollute the retiring db during
a container GET was limited; before calling list_objects_iter() the
container GET method calls the broker get_info_is_deleted() method
which also flushes the pending file, so the vulnerability is only to
updates arriving in the pending file after that point in time.

However, there are other place where the pending file might be flushed
into the *retiring* db, for example as a side effect of calling
get_info() or get_items_since(). Although we generally expect object
updates to be redirected away from a sharding container, this may not
always be the case, for example while a shard range is found but not
yet created.

This patch adds an attribute 'skip_commits' to DatabaseBroker which
when True will prevent the broker ever committing records to its db
via _commit_puts() method.  'skip_commits' is False by default (legacy
behaviour) but is set to True whenever a broker is created for a
retiring db using ContainerBroker.get_brokers().

Note that 'skip_commits' does not prevent objects being directly
merged to the db via a direct call to merge_items().

Change-Id: I268d01a373491c693b793748065d212f9703ffab
"}, {'created': '2018-04-07 09:59:21.000000000', 'message': "Prevent pending file flushing to retiring db

via _commit_puts() method.  'skip_commits' is False by default (legacy
behaviour) but is set to True whenever a broker is created for a
retiring db using ContainerBroker.get_brokers().

Note that 'skip_commits' does not prevent objects being directly
merged to the db via a direct call to merge_items().

Change-Id: I268d01a373491c693b793748065d212f9703ffab
"}, {'created': '2018-04-09 21:12:30.000000000', 'message': "Prevent pending file flushing to retiring db

always be the case, for example while a shard range is found but not
yet created.

when True will prevent the broker ever committing records to its db
via _commit_puts() method.  'skip_commits' is False by default (legacy
behaviour) but is set to True whenever a broker is created for a
retiring db using ContainerBroker.get_brokers().

Note that 'skip_commits' does not prevent objects being directly
merged to the db via a direct call to merge_items().

commit_message:
Prevent pending file flushing to retiring db

Before, while a container was in sharding state, a container GET
called ContainerBroker.list_objects_iter() on the retiring broker,
with the goal of listing any objects in the retiring
db. list_objects_iter() flushes any pending object updates into the
broker's object table, which in this scenario was the retiring db,
causing the retiring db to be polluted.

The opportunity for pending updates to pollute the retiring db during
a container GET was limited; before calling list_objects_iter() the
container GET method calls the broker get_info_is_deleted() method
which also flushes the pending file, so the vulnerability is only to
updates arriving in the pending file after that point in time.

However, there are other place where the pending file might be flushed
into the *retiring* db, for example as a side effect of calling
get_info() or get_items_since(). Although we generally expect object
updates to be redirected away from a sharding container, this may not
always be the case, for example while a shard range is found but not
yet created.

This patch adds an attribute 'skip_commits' to DatabaseBroker which
when True will prevent the broker ever committing records to its db
via _commit_puts() method.  'skip_commits' is False by default (legacy
behaviour) but is set to True whenever a broker is created for a
retiring db using ContainerBroker.get_brokers().

Note that 'skip_commits' does not prevent objects being directly
merged to the db via a direct call to merge_items().

Change-Id: I268d01a373491c693b793748065d212f9703ffab

commit_message:
First step towards python 3 support

* Removed dependacy on supervisor.
* Added template configuration for systemd target that includes all
  services.
* Added templates configuration for systemd service for every single
  service.
* Changed monasca_setup to use the new templates.

Change-Id: I0d0c4ea41a830581d6b9f247fad6a2dda1f96cbe
Task: 4126
Story: 2000975

Change-Id: If10cf30521445b6611ab7af23212f02b4377f623

Yeah, I didn't get this ready in time for an FFE, so it should wait until the queens branches have been cut.

commit_message:
Skip Floating IP QoS scenario test in DVR environment

It looks that QoS for FloatingIP is not applied properly
in DVR router and related scenario test is failing 100% times.

Until this issue will not be fixed we should skip this test to
make dvr scenario job works better.

Change-Id: Ia4f8fc259bae36e40d45a1a7dc9faf4b878f0b9b
Related-Bug: #1758033

commit_message:
Clean old output before new doc builds

Remove the doc/build directory to make sure there are no stale
artifacts from past runs.

Change-Id: I87b302733402cc096eecacebbbc5631aebc42948

commit_message:
Enable proxy header parsing

Ensure that oslo.middleware parses any proxy information
forwarded from haproxy/apache with regards to protocol;
this ensures that https connections are correctly detected.

Change-Id: I64e8c14123e5d12850902ce99490697ca4bb853d
Closes-Bug: 1758675

commit_message:
Update installation guide: no uwsgi for glance

The Pike and Queens release notes recommend against running
Glance under uwsgi.  Add a note to the install guide as another
location where this information is available.

Change-Id: I3aa61ea45a3d3edaa5b8062813fc3e1388556f9f

revisions:
[{'created': '2018-04-07 00:40:54.000000000', 'message': "Don't persist RequestSpec.retry

During a resize, the RequestSpec.flavor is updated
to the new flavor. If the resize failed on one host
and was rescheduled, the RequestSpec.retry is updated
for that failed host and mistakenly persisted, which
can affect later move operations, like if an admin
targets one of those previously failed hosts for a
live migration or evacuate operation.

This change fixes the problem by not ever persisting
the RequestSpec.retry field to the database, since
retries are per-request/operation and not something
that needs to be persisted.

Alternative to this, we could reset the retry field
in the RequestSpec.reset_forced_destinations method
but that would be slightly overloading the meaning
of that method, and the approach taken in this patch
is arguably cleaner since retries shouldn't ever be
persisted. It should be noted, however, that one
advantage to resetting the 'retry' field in the
RequestSpec.reset_forced_destinations method would
be to avoid this issue for any existing DB entries
that have this problem.

The related functional regression test is updated
to show the bug is now fixed.

Change-Id: Iadbf8ec935565a6d4ccf6f36ef630ab6bf1bea5d
Closes-Bug: #1718512
"}, {'created': '2018-04-07 13:38:07.000000000', 'message': "Don't persist RequestSpec.retry

During a resize, the RequestSpec.flavor is updated
to the new flavor. If the resize failed on one host
and was rescheduled, the RequestSpec.retry is updated
for that failed host and mistakenly persisted, which
can affect later move operations, like if an admin

live migration or evacuate operation.

This change fixes the problem by not ever persisting
the RequestSpec.retry field to the database, since
retries are per-request/operation and not something
that needs to be persisted.

Alternative to this, we could reset the retry field
in the RequestSpec.reset_forced_destinations method
but that would be slightly overloading the meaning
of that method, and the approach taken in this patch
is arguably cleaner since retries shouldn't ever be
persisted. It should be noted, however, that one
advantage to resetting the 'retry' field in the
RequestSpec.reset_forced_destinations method would
be to avoid this issue for any existing DB entries
that have this problem.

The related functional regression test is updated
to show the bug is now fixed.

Change-Id: Iadbf8ec935565a6d4ccf6f36ef630ab6bf1bea5d
Closes-Bug: #1718512
"}]
commit_message:
Don't persist RequestSpec.retry

During a resize, the RequestSpec.flavor is updated
to the new flavor. If the resize failed on one host
and was rescheduled, the RequestSpec.retry is updated
for that failed host and mistakenly persisted, which
can affect later move operations, like if an admin
targets one of those previously failed hosts for a
live migration or evacuate operation.

This change fixes the problem by not ever persisting
the RequestSpec.retry field to the database, since
retries are per-request/operation and not something
that needs to be persisted.

Alternative to this, we could reset the retry field
in the RequestSpec.reset_forced_destinations method
but that would be slightly overloading the meaning
of that method, and the approach taken in this patch
is arguably cleaner since retries shouldn't ever be
persisted. It should be noted, however, that one
advantage to resetting the 'retry' field in the
RequestSpec.reset_forced_destinations method would
be to avoid this issue for any existing DB entries
that have this problem.

The related functional regression test is updated
to show the bug is now fixed.

Change-Id: Iadbf8ec935565a6d4ccf6f36ef630ab6bf1bea5d
Closes-Bug: #1718512

Run tempest on fs027 using containerized tempest

* Added tempest tests for compute, glance, keystone

Depends-On: https://review.openstack.org/#/c/551441

Change-Id: Ie97aa98e206c0408df8c03ad0c3fdf72ad093c3f

commit_message:
Refactored validate-tempest role for undercloud and containers

* Introduced new workflow for validate-tempest role
- Remove previously created tempest artifacts
- Install tempest
- Create tempest workspace
- Create tempest resources
- Generate tempest configurations
- Run tempest
- Removed unused ironic undercloud fake services
- Removing public network from undercloud as there is no public network
- Added tempest_dir var to give path to tempest workspace
- use {{ working_dir }}/tempest_git for clonning stuff
- Added test_black_regex to skip a series of tests
- Fixed permission issue for tempest_dir to generate subunit files
- Install stestr subunit-filters and subunit for generating subunit files
- Added tempest_skip_master containing skip list for undercloud
- Introduced tempest_conf_version for installing particular version of
  tempestconf from git
- Enable set -e to find the exit status of command running inside
  container

Change-Id: I021432e222fae0e57a13ca4859ba77e990ac6c67

revisions:
[{'created': '2017-09-20 18:30:08.000000000', 'message': "Ignore original retried hosts when live migrating

When we originally create an instance, if we rescheduled
the request spec will track how many retry attempts we
had and which hosts we tried to build on. This gets persisted
with the request spec.

During a live migration, we pull the persisted request spec
for the instance and send that to the scheduler to select a
destination host. Before we do that, we reset the original
forced host/node (if there was one) so that the scheduler doesn't
pick that host again, and we exclude the source host.

However, any previously attempted hosts during the initial create
may be chosen by the scheduler and would fail the RetryFilter
because those hosts are in the request spec 'retry' field.

This is especially confusing if the admin is specifying a destination
host for the live migration and other similar instances are live
migrating to that host successfully.

This change resets the retry field on the request spec during live
migration when picking a destination host so that hosts which failed
the original instance build, for whatever reason (maybe the claim failed
or there was a configuration issue on that host), can be a candidate
again for live migration as long as they pass the filters.

Change-Id: Ib8a23db838b0bbf2cfb8123cf6aaa39d00ff0640
Closes-Bug: #1718512
"}, {'created': '2017-10-16 21:21:23.000000000', 'message': "Don't ignore original retried hosts when moving an instance

When we originally create an instance, if we rescheduled
the request spec will track how many retry attempts we
had and which hosts we tried to build on. This gets persisted
with the request spec.

During a live migration, cold migration, evacuation and when
unshelving an instance, we pull the persisted request spec
for the instance and send that to the scheduler to select a
destination host. Before we do that, we reset the original
forced host/node (if there was one) so that the scheduler doesn't
pick that host again, and we exclude the source host.

However, any previously attempted hosts during the initial create
may be chosen by the scheduler and would fail the RetryFilter
because those hosts are in the request spec 'retry' field.

This is especially confusing if the admin is specifying a destination
host for the live migration or evacuation and other similar instances
are live migrating / evacuating to that host successfully.

This change resets the retry field on the request spec when picking a
destination host so that hosts which failed the original instance build,
for whatever reason (maybe the claim failed or there was a configuration
issue on that host), can be a candidate again for scheduling as long
as they pass the filters.

Change-Id: Ib8a23db838b0bbf2cfb8123cf6aaa39d00ff0640
Closes-Bug: #1718512

doesn't actually fail without any fix, so I don't really know how
the bug exists in the first place, unless we used to persist the
request spec during reschedules prior to Newton?

the request spec will track how many retry attempts we
had and which hosts we tried to build on. This gets persisted
with the request spec.

Commit 74ab427d4796d8a386f84a15cc49188c2a60f8f1 in Newton added
code to persist changes to the RequestSpec during a resize since
the flavor changes.

That change inadvertantly also persisted any failed hosts during
the resize that are stored in the RequestSpec.retry field during
a reschedule.

The problem is that later those persisted failed hosts are rejected
by the RetryFilter, which can be confusing if an admin is trying
to live migrate or evacate the instance to one of those specific
hosts.

This adds a functional regression test to show the failure, which
will be fixed in a separate change that then modifies the assertions.

Closes-Bug: #1718512

commit_message:
Add regression test for persisted RequestSpec.retry from failed resize

Commit 74ab427d4796d8a386f84a15cc49188c2a60f8f1 in Newton added
code to persist changes to the RequestSpec during a resize since
the flavor changes.

That change inadvertantly also persisted any failed hosts during
the resize that are stored in the RequestSpec.retry field during
a reschedule.

The problem is that later those persisted failed hosts are rejected
by the RetryFilter, which can be confusing if an admin is trying
to live migrate or evacate the instance to one of those specific
hosts.

This adds a functional regression test to show the failure, which
will be fixed in a separate change that then modifies the assertions.

Change-Id: Ib8a23db838b0bbf2cfb8123cf6aaa39d00ff0640
Related-Bug: #1718512

fix the logic for handling default for --reqs

When --reqs is specified on the command line, take the
value. Otherwise select an appropriate default.

Change-Id: I97bf967c49f6765139b89e434297c9985daca28c
Signed-off-by: Doug Hellmann <doug@doughellmann.com>

commit_message:
lower-requirements: Adds WMI and PyMI

Because PyMI and WMI are not in the lower-requirements, the
requirements-check job fails in os-win [1]. This patch adds the
two requirements.

[1] Ia95aa8f003151cbce870acc54f2053cbcfc6effb

Change-Id: I9875ab24b1fda4e1492b173517ac4795c3f3276c

commit_message:
script to fix lower constraints entries that do not match local requirements

We have a few projects that have lower constraints lists that do not
match their own local requirements settings. This script tries to fix
that by changing the constraints to match.

Change-Id: I5f9bfc30e5dab855c9cef77cd9c4063658aab4c1
Signed-off-by: Doug Hellmann <doug@doughellmann.com>

commit_message:
Support filter by attribute with None

This will enable users to filter list result with attributes
with value 'null' that will be interpreted as None.
For example, the request below will list all legacy subnets
(assume the legacy subnets are the ones without subnetpools).

  GET "/subnets?subnetpool_id=null"

Change-Id: I4afc2aec124050c104998df6715a8450203f7b5c
Closes-Bug: #1749304

revisions:
[{'created': '2018-04-09 10:52:59.000000000', 'message': 'libvirt: Allow to specify granular CPU feature flags

The recent "Meltdown" CVE fixes have resulted in a critical performance
penalty[*] that will impact every Nova guest with certain CPU models.

I.e. assume you have applied all the "Meltdown" CVE fixes, and performed
a cold reboot (explicit stop & start) of all Nova guests, for the
updates to take effect.  Now, if any guests that are booted with certain
named virtual CPU models (e.g. "IvyBridge", "Westmere", etc), then those
guests, will incur noticeable performance degradation[*], while being
protected from the CVE itself.

To alleviate this guest performance impact, it is now important to
specify an obscure Intel CPU feature flag, 'PCID' (Process-Context ID)
-- for the virtual CPU models that don't already include it (more on
this below).  To that end, this change will allow Nova to explicitly
specify CPU feature flags via a new configuration attribute,
`cpu_model_extra_flags`, e.g. in `nova.conf`:

    ...
    [libvirt]
    cpu_mode = custom
    cpu_model = IvyBridge
    cpu_model_extra_flags = pcid
    ...

NB: In the first iteration, the choices for `cpu_model_extra_flags` is
restricted to only 'pcid' (the option is case-insensitive) -- to address
the earlier mentioned guest performance degradation.  A future patch
will remove this restriction, allowing to add / remove multiple CPU
feature flags, thus making way for other useful features.

Some have asked: "Why not simply hardcode the 'PCID' CPU feature flag
into Nova?"  That's not graceful, and more importantly, impractical:

  (1) Not every Intel CPU model has 'PCID':

       - The only Intel CPU models that include the 'PCID' capability
         are: "Haswell", "Broadwell", and "Skylake" variants.

       - The libvirt / QEMU Intel CPU models: "Nehalem", "Westmere",
         "SandyBridge", and "IvyBridge" will *not* expose the 'PCID'
         capability, even if the host CPUs by the same name include it.
         I.e. 'PCID' needs to be explicitly when using the said virtual
         CPU models.

  (2) Magically adding new CPU feature flags under the user's feet
      impacts live migration.

[*] https://groups.google.com/forum/m/#!topic/mechanical-sympathy/L9mHTbeQLNU

Closes-Bug: #1750829
Change-Id: I6bb956808aa3df58747c865c92e5b276e61aff44
BluePrint: libvirt-cpu-model-extra-flags
(cherry picked from commit 6b601b7cf6e7f23077f428353a3a4e81084eb3a1)
'}, {'created': '2018-04-10 14:01:50.000000000', 'message': 'libvirt: Allow to specify granular CPU feature flags

The recent "Meltdown" CVE fixes have resulted in a critical performance
penalty[*] that will impact every Nova guest with certain CPU models.

I.e. assume you have applied all the "Meltdown" CVE fixes, and performed
a cold reboot (explicit stop & start) of all Nova guests, for the
updates to take effect.  Now, if any guests that are booted with certain
named virtual CPU models (e.g. "IvyBridge", "Westmere", etc), then those
guests, will incur noticeable performance degradation[*], while being
protected from the CVE itself.

To alleviate this guest performance impact, it is now important to
specify an obscure Intel CPU feature flag, 'PCID' (Process-Context ID)
-- for the virtual CPU models that don't already include it (more on
this below).  To that end, this change will allow Nova to explicitly
specify CPU feature flags via a new configuration attribute,
`cpu_model_extra_flags`, e.g. in `nova.conf`:

    ...
    [libvirt]
    cpu_mode = custom
    cpu_model = IvyBridge
    cpu_model_extra_flags = pcid
    ...

NB: In the first iteration, the choices for `cpu_model_extra_flags` is
restricted to only 'pcid' (the option is case-insensitive) -- to address
the earlier mentioned guest performance degradation.  A future patch
will remove this restriction, allowing to add / remove multiple CPU
feature flags, thus making way for other useful features.

Some have asked: "Why not simply hardcode the 'PCID' CPU feature flag
into Nova?"  That's not graceful, and more importantly, impractical:

  (1) Not every Intel CPU model has 'PCID':

       - The only Intel CPU models that include the 'PCID' capability
         are: "Haswell", "Broadwell", and "Skylake" variants.

       - The libvirt / QEMU Intel CPU models: "Nehalem", "Westmere",
         "SandyBridge", and "IvyBridge" will *not* expose the 'PCID'
         capability, even if the host CPUs by the same name include it.
         I.e. 'PCID' needs to be explicitly when using the said virtual
         CPU models.

  (2) Magically adding new CPU feature flags under the user's feet
      impacts live migration.

[*] https://groups.google.com/forum/m/#!topic/mechanical-sympathy/L9mHTbeQLNU

Closes-Bug: #1750829
Change-Id: I6bb956808aa3df58747c865c92e5b276e61aff44

commit_message:
libvirt: Allow to specify granular CPU feature flags

The recent "Meltdown" CVE fixes have resulted in a critical performance
penalty[*] that will impact every Nova guest with certain CPU models.

I.e. assume you have applied all the "Meltdown" CVE fixes, and performed
a cold reboot (explicit stop & start) of all Nova guests, for the
updates to take effect.  Now, if any guests that are booted with certain
named virtual CPU models (e.g. "IvyBridge", "Westmere", etc), then those
guests, will incur noticeable performance degradation[*], while being
protected from the CVE itself.

To alleviate this guest performance impact, it is now important to
specify an obscure Intel CPU feature flag, 'PCID' (Process-Context ID)
-- for the virtual CPU models that don't already include it (more on
this below).  To that end, this change will allow Nova to explicitly
specify CPU feature flags via a new configuration attribute,
`cpu_model_extra_flags`, e.g. in `nova.conf`:

    ...
    [libvirt]
    cpu_mode = custom
    cpu_model = IvyBridge
    cpu_model_extra_flags = pcid
    ...

NB: In the first iteration, the choices for `cpu_model_extra_flags` is
restricted to only 'pcid' (the option is case-insensitive) -- to address
the earlier mentioned guest performance degradation.  A future patch
will remove this restriction, allowing to add / remove multiple CPU
feature flags, thus making way for other useful features.

Some have asked: "Why not simply hardcode the 'PCID' CPU feature flag
into Nova?"  That's not graceful, and more importantly, impractical:

  (1) Not every Intel CPU model has 'PCID':

       - The only Intel CPU models that include the 'PCID' capability
         are: "Haswell", "Broadwell", and "Skylake" variants.

       - The libvirt / QEMU Intel CPU models: "Nehalem", "Westmere",
         "SandyBridge", and "IvyBridge" will *not* expose the 'PCID'
         capability, even if the host CPUs by the same name include it.
         I.e. 'PCID' needs to be explicitly when using the said virtual
         CPU models.

  (2) Magically adding new CPU feature flags under the user's feet
      impacts live migration.

[*] https://groups.google.com/forum/m/#!topic/mechanical-sympathy/L9mHTbeQLNU

Closes-Bug: #1750829
Change-Id: I6bb956808aa3df58747c865c92e5b276e61aff44
(cherry picked from commit 6b601b7cf6e7f23077f428353a3a4e81084eb3a1)

subject: Allow for single tempest image upload
messages: [{'account_id': 6816, 'date': '2018-04-10 12:38:57.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Cherry Picked from branch master.'}, {'account_id': 17068, 'date': '2018-04-10 12:40:00.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Code-Review+2'}, {'account_id': 14805, 'date': '2018-04-10 18:38:03.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Workflow+1 Code-Review+2'}]
revisions:
[{'created': '2018-04-10 12:38:57.000000000', 'message': "Allow for single tempest image upload

If 'tempest_images' has been overridden to only contain a single image,
setting a fact for a secondary image will fail since it always expects
'tempest_image_create' to contain two elements. Instead, set the
'tempest_glance_image_id_2' fact as the last element.

Change-Id: If4bbd73f70bfb59695bb7d5f167ed6555e6de16a
(cherry picked from commit 540a6be329d78df6a195bf1749364c6f514cefe9)
"}]
commit_message:
Allow for single tempest image upload

If 'tempest_images' has been overridden to only contain a single image,
setting a fact for a secondary image will fail since it always expects
'tempest_image_create' to contain two elements. Instead, set the
'tempest_glance_image_id_2' fact as the last element.

Change-Id: If4bbd73f70bfb59695bb7d5f167ed6555e6de16a
(cherry picked from commit 540a6be329d78df6a195bf1749364c6f514cefe9)

My current environment (oooq from master) has SELinux running in Permissive mode. IIUC this means the validation would fail on a default installation (which is something we want to avoid). Is there a related change that sets the mode to Enforcing as part of the undercloud installation?'}, {'account_id': 11491, 'date': '2017-10-23 09:26:50.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2:

> My current environment (oooq from master) has SELinux running in
 > Permissive mode. IIUC this means the validation would fail on a
 > default installation (which is something we want to avoid). Is
 > there a related change that sets the mode to Enforcing as part of
 > the undercloud installation?

By default RDO builds always set SELinux to Permissive mode, but an OSP Undercloud have to use SELinux in Enforcing mode. So I need to find out a clean way to identify that we are using RDO or OSP. And I admit that I have added this SELinux check with OSP in mind...

The only simple thing I have in mind now is to fail only if we using RHEL and just warn if using CentOS maybe. What do you think?'}, {'account_id': 11491, 'date': '2017-10-23 13:25:58.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 3.'}, {'account_id': 11491, 'date': '2017-10-23 13:27:30.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 4.'}, {'account_id': 9317, 'date': '2017-10-27 16:02:19.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 4: Code-Review-1

commit_message:
Add new SELinux validation check

As the default SELinux mode for CentOS is Permissive, we only warn (not fail)
if SELinux is not running in Enforcing mode on CentOS.

Change-Id: Id991b39a062b4962355b682c175fe92e8f92e0bb
Signed-off-by: Gael Chamoulaud <gchamoul@redhat.com>

New version of diskimage-builder
(https://pypi.python.org/pypi/diskimage-builder) requires to
explicitly specify the type of block-device such as
block-device-mbr or block-device-gpt when using vm element
: I4a566a97d073fc0dda0ab2494ac988fe015800a9.

Change-Id: I9fa78773e47e45c8f4638854314a741f3e4cf603

commit_message:
Reflects the changes on diskimage-builder

New version of diskimage-builder
(https://pypi.python.org/pypi/diskimage-builder) requires to
explicitly specify the type of block-device such as
block-device-mbr or block-device-gpt when using vm element
: I4a566a97d073fc0dda0ab2494ac988fe015800a9.

This patch fixes to specify as block-device-mbr,
since it was the default type for the previous versions
of diskimage-builder.

Change-Id: I9fa78773e47e45c8f4638854314a741f3e4cf603

commit_message:
conf: Remove 'db_driver' config opt

This option has been deprecated for a long time and any kinks, where
they existed, should have long since been worked out. Time to kill it.

Change-Id: Ifa686b5ce5e8063a8e5f2f22c89124c1d4083b80

commit_message:
Fix pep8 errors

Recent pep8 upgrade and corresponding pycodestyle update break
horizon pep8 job due to the new rules.

This commit fixes the following new errors:
- E226 missing whitespace around arithmetic operator
- E241 multiple spaces after ','
- E731 do not assign a lambda expression, use a def

The following errors are added to the ignore list
as there are many errors:
- E402 module level import not at top of file
- W503 line break before binary operator

Change-Id: I3478b0684175d2604bbcc1d89cbfca298b97f1e1

commit_message:
Enable storyboard for openstacksdk

Now that it's been renamed, turn on storyboard for openstacksdk
projects. Add an openstacksdk group for the related repos, and shift
shade into that group and out of openstack-ci.

commit_message:
Fix ansible-lint job

The 'linters' tox environment was not running on roles, it was only
running on playbooks. This change adds a command to the linters
environment to ensure all roles are linted. This also cleans up a
comment in the tox file that was referring to a nonexistent zuul job.

Change-Id: I04d9d79fca16a7f78f9c646f96e5fba78a5f5329

subject: Revert "Stop systemd-resolve from booting on our images"
messages: [{'account_id': 7118, 'date': '2018-04-03 05:39:56.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 1.'}, {'account_id': 6547, 'date': '2018-04-03 06:53:48.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Code-Review+2'}, {'account_id': 4162, 'date': '2018-04-10 18:34:28.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Workflow+1 Code-Review+2'}]
revisions:
[{'created': '2018-04-03 05:39:56.000000000', 'message': 'Revert "Stop systemd-resolve from booting on our images"

This reverts commit da1552359561a35b802dde534073f2ea5fec6372.

systemd-resolved was not really involed in this.  What seems to be
happening is that during the initial chroot creation there is no
/etc/resolv.conf file, and so the systemd postinst script creates one
pointing to the compatability files created by systemd-resolved.

This is not what we want, but dib doesn't really provide a way for us
to overwrite the file.  That is covered in
Ie0e97d8072e2b21a54b053fa6fb07b62960c686d

We actually want systemd-resolved running -- it provides the dbus
nameserver api stuff that some tools may use.  If /etc/resolv.conf is
a file, systemd-resolved leaves it alone and uses it for resolution as
you would expect.  (we do, however, want to wait for the depends-on to
ensure the image has a correct /etc/resolv.conf before merging this).

Depends-On: https://review.openstack.org/557842/

Change-Id: Ie3cdc323bf8fb4fcee725f9a52bf53a4a6a01bbf
'}]
commit_message:
Revert "Stop systemd-resolve from booting on our images"

This reverts commit da1552359561a35b802dde534073f2ea5fec6372.

systemd-resolved was not really involed in this.  What seems to be
happening is that during the initial chroot creation there is no
/etc/resolv.conf file, and so the systemd postinst script creates one
pointing to the compatability files created by systemd-resolved.

This is not what we want, but dib doesn't really provide a way for us
to overwrite the file.  That is covered in
Ie0e97d8072e2b21a54b053fa6fb07b62960c686d

We actually want systemd-resolved running -- it provides the dbus
nameserver api stuff that some tools may use.  If /etc/resolv.conf is
a file, systemd-resolved leaves it alone and uses it for resolution as
you would expect.  (we do, however, want to wait for the depends-on to
ensure the image has a correct /etc/resolv.conf before merging this).

Depends-On: https://review.openstack.org/557842/

Change-Id: Ie3cdc323bf8fb4fcee725f9a52bf53a4a6a01bbf

This seems related to https://review.openstack.org/505168 . The result seems to be that there is no way to bake a self-signed cert for a raw IPv6 address that will be accepted by all the different libraries we have in use, one of them is always bound to fail. The situation gets worse with python3.

[{'created': '2018-04-09 20:30:09.000000000', 'message': '[WIP] Fixup certificates

Using cfssl to regenerate fresh certificates:
rm *
echo '{"CN":"CA","key":{"algo":"rsa","size":2048}}' | cfssl gencert
-initca - | cfssljson -bare ca -
echo '{"signing":{"default":{"expiry":"43800h","usages":["signing","key
encipherment","server auth","client auth"]}}}' > ca-config.json
export ADDRESS=127.0.0.1,::1,localhost
export NAME=server
echo
'{"CN":"'$NAME'","hosts":["127.0.0.1"],"key":{"algo":"rsa","size":2048}}'
| cfssl gencert -config=ca-config.json -ca=ca.pem -ca-key=ca-key.pem
-hostname="$ADDRESS" - | cfssljson -bare $NAME
export ADDRESS=
export NAME=client
echo
'{"CN":"'$NAME'","hosts":["127.0.0.1"],"key":{"algo":"rsa","size":2048}}'
| cfssl gencert -config=ca-config.json -ca=ca.pem -ca-key=ca-key.pem
-hostname="$ADDRESS" - | cfssljson -bare $NAME
cp ca.pem ca.crt ;
cp ca-key.pem ca.key;
cp client.pem certificate.crt ;
cp client-key.pem privatekey.key ;

commit_message:
Fixup certificates and skip failing test

Using cfssl to regenerate fresh certificates:
rm *
echo '{"CN":"CA","key":{"algo":"rsa","size":2048}}' | cfssl gencert
-initca - | cfssljson -bare ca -
echo '{"signing":{"default":{"expiry":"43800h","usages":["signing","key
encipherment","server auth","client auth"]}}}' > ca-config.json
export ADDRESS=127.0.0.1,::1,localhost
export NAME=server
echo
'{"CN":"'$NAME'","hosts":["127.0.0.1"],"key":{"algo":"rsa","size":2048}}'
| cfssl gencert -config=ca-config.json -ca=ca.pem -ca-key=ca-key.pem
-hostname="$ADDRESS" - | cfssljson -bare $NAME
export ADDRESS=
export NAME=client
echo
'{"CN":"'$NAME'","hosts":["127.0.0.1"],"key":{"algo":"rsa","size":2048}}'
| cfssl gencert -config=ca-config.json -ca=ca.pem -ca-key=ca-key.pem
-hostname="$ADDRESS" - | cfssljson -bare $NAME
cp ca.pem ca.crt ;
cp ca-key.pem ca.key;
cp client.pem certificate.crt ;
cp client-key.pem privatekey.key ;

Also the results from the related bug show that there is currently no
solution to make self-signed certificates work in conjunction with
raw IPv6 addresses consistently, so we skip the failing test.

Related-Bug: 1656329
Change-Id: I160108059e17122035d8d914c5157b7ce3ada3a5

Recent revelations have prompted the need for further enhancement.'}, {'account_id': 14070, 'date': '2018-04-02 20:41:40.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 4:

(1 comment)'}, {'account_id': 14070, 'date': '2018-04-02 20:48:29.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 4:

(1 comment)'}, {'account_id': 1063, 'date': '2018-04-02 21:58:23.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 4:

(2 comments)

I think consumer generations are fundamentally different from RP generations, and there is no need to change the API to return them. Any agent will PUT their allocations at once, and will not need to re-PUT amended allocations again.'}, {'account_id': 14070, 'date': '2018-04-02 22:22:31.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 4:

> I think consumer generations are fundamentally different from RP generations, and there is no need to change the API to return them. Any agent will PUT their allocations at once, and will not need to re-PUT amended allocations again.

My take is that we shouldn't be predicting/restricting how consumers (beyond Nova, beyond right now) will want to use allocations.  High frequency is only one possible use case (though a reasonable one).  Clients may wish to cache allocations to make the next update (whenever it happens) a PUT instead of a GET/PUT - think resize, vif/disk/device attach, etc.  Clients may wish to hand off allocations from one method/process/agent to another.

And generally speaking, it just makes sense that an API that generates or modifies some part of the record being submitted should return that generated/modified data.  Before, 204 made sense because allocations were created exactly as they were submitted.  (Data such as internal db ID doesn't count - never gets seen by the API consumer.)  Returning the record really would have been pointless because it would be exactly the same as in the request.  Now that's no longer the case."}, {'account_id': 11564, 'date': '2018-04-03 12:18:51.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 4:

(2 comments)

> My take is that we shouldn't be predicting/restricting how
 > consumers (beyond Nova, beyond right now) will want to use
 > allocations.  High frequency is only one possible use case (though
 > a reasonable one).  Clients may wish to cache allocations to make
 > the next update (whenever it happens) a PUT instead of a GET/PUT -
 > think resize, vif/disk/device attach, etc.  Clients may wish to
 > hand off allocations from one method/process/agent to another.

At which point they are soon to be wrong, see within.

In general I do not think we should be expecting or desiring clients in general to keep and carry info about state for which only placement is authoritative."}, {'account_id': 7, 'date': '2018-04-03 13:45:42.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 4: Code-Review-1

(2 comments)

A small change in wording of REST API impact needed, but nothing like the changes that Eric is advocating for.

-jay'}, {'account_id': 14070, 'date': '2018-04-03 13:53:40.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 4:

(1 comment)'}, {'account_id': 1063, 'date': '2018-04-03 14:54:01.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 4:

(4 comments)

We had a Google Hangout on 2018-04-03 to resolve some of the outstanding issues where we were not in agreement. I've summarized the results of that hangout as comments in the spec that are prefixed with the phrase "Hangout resolution:".'}, {'account_id': 14070, 'date': '2018-04-03 15:37:52.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 4:

I concur with Ed's assessment of the hangout resolution.

So let's just get the doc updated to call out the None behavior.  That needs to be spelled out because it's non-obvious and a little weird."}, {'account_id': 14070, 'date': '2018-04-07 16:25:55.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 4:

Another edit pursuant to an IRC chat sometime this week that I haven't tried to find yet: making project and user ID nullable."}, {'account_id': 11564, 'date': '2018-04-09 08:23:26.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 4: -Code-Review

> Another edit pursuant to an IRC chat sometime this week that I
 > haven't tried to find yet: making project and user ID nullable.

Can you point me to this IRC chat please? This seems an odd change to me.

* At stage 1 we didn't have project and use ID
* At stage 2 we did and required them (v 1.8)
* At stage 3 we're now saying they should be nullable.

Why?

And further if we do that makes for a very complicated flow when mentally navigating the microversions."}, {'account_id': 11564, 'date': '2018-04-09 08:30:24.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 4:

> Another edit pursuant to an IRC chat sometime this week that I
 > haven't tried to find yet: making project and user ID nullable.

Oh, you mean just in the database tables because otherwise we don't write entries in the consumer table at all. Hmm, yeah, guess so."}, {'account_id': 14070, 'date': '2018-04-09 13:21:01.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 4:

@cdent, here's that IRC conversation: http://eavesdrop.openstack.org/irclogs/%23openstack-nova/%23openstack-nova.2018-04-04.log.html#t2018-04-04T13:35:30"}, {'account_id': 1063, 'date': '2018-04-09 15:28:10.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 5.'}, {'account_id': 14070, 'date': '2018-04-09 15:36:37.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 5: Code-Review+1

commit_message:
Add Generation to Consumers

Potential conflicts have been identified when more than one process
attempts to allocate resources for a given consumer, and there is
currently no way to detect these conflicts. We propose to add a
generation field to the consumers table in Placement, and implement the
same mechanism for tracking updates to consumers as is implemented for
ResourceProviders.

APIImpact

Blueprint: add-consumer-generation

Change-Id: I8128da7185e149ecde45c94bb00668ce3e949251

commit_message:
Deprecate cinder::api::nova_catalog_admin_info parameter

This is no longer present in the cinder code-base, so there's no use in
keeping configuring it. Thus, I moved it to the deprecated section and
now it's unused.

Change-Id: I80b27d06b802db3cffe24db6a8fb79a9ad30a460

yeah, that'll do"}, {'account_id': 11564, 'date': '2018-04-03 20:01:09.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 7: Code-Review+1'}, {'account_id': 25625, 'date': '2018-04-04 00:57:40.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 7: Code-Review+1'}, {'account_id': 7634, 'date': '2018-04-06 06:45:01.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 7: Code-Review+1'}, {'account_id': 15888, 'date': '2018-04-08 03:06:18.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 7: Code-Review+1'}, {'account_id': 7, 'date': '2018-04-09 18:38:57.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 7: Code-Review-1

(1 comment)

A few gripes about this patch, sorry :(

1) This patch couples length checks with transforming character strings. This makes the resulting slugify() function dual-use. I'd very much prefer to have length checks be in a single place, and that be the REST API json schema layer. Not only are we going to run into synchronization issues (what happens if/when we change those lengths?) but it violates the principle of single responsibility.

2) "Slugify" actually has a specific meaning already, and that is to make a string URL-friendly. This is not doing that. Rather, what this is doing is transforming strings to meet a particular naming convention of resource classes and trait names in the placement REST API.

3) Slugification typically replaces blank characters with the hyphen (note: not the underscore) character. So reader of this code might assume it does that. So, let's please call it something other than slugify() -- which, btw, there are already a ton of libraries out there called slugify and have a slugify() module namespace with a slugify() function...

How about calling the method "normalize_resource_or_trait_name()" or something like that?

Thanks!

-jay'}, {'account_id': 14070, 'date': '2018-04-10 18:05:22.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 7:

TIL.  I thought "slugification" was a generic thing.

In poking around some more, I found that ResourceClass already has a normalize_name, which (although it has a bug [1]) more or less does the same char-swapping and upcasing I'm doing here.  So all we need is something similar for traits.  Which, it seems to me, would be most appropriately put into os-traits.  So I did that [2].

[1] https://bugs.launchpad.net/nova/+bug/1762789
[2] https://review.openstack.org/#/c/560107/'}, {'account_id': 14070, 'date': '2018-04-10 18:05:31.000000000', 'content': 'Abandoned'}]
revisions:
[{'created': '2018-03-26 19:32:26.000000000', 'message': "Slugification utilities for placement names

Names of resource providers, resource classes, and traits in placement
are restricted to certain characters and lengths.  Consumers (e.g. virt
driver implementations of update_provider_tree) may wish to generate
such names dynamically based on inputs that don't necessarily know or
follow those rules.  Such consumers could use a convenient way to
sanitize such generated names such that they conform to what placement
expects.

This change set introduces three public methods into the
(eventually-to-be-split-into-a-common-library)
nova.api.openstack.placement.lib module.  slugify_provider_name,
slugify_resource_class, and slugify_trait respectively sanitize a
resource provider name, a resource class name, or a trait name.  The
caller gets to decide whether a too-long string is truncated or results
in an exception.

Related to blueprint update-provider-tree

Change-Id: Ie293b6157aab3e736c9f146cf232129a33c705ab
"}, {'created': '2018-03-26 21:33:29.000000000', 'message': "Slugification utilities for placement names

Names of resource providers, resource classes, and traits in placement
are restricted to certain characters and lengths.  Consumers (e.g. virt
driver implementations of update_provider_tree) may wish to generate
such names dynamically based on inputs that don't necessarily know or
follow those rules.  Such consumers could use a convenient way to
sanitize such generated names such that they conform to what placement
expects.

This change set introduces a `slugify` method into the
(eventually-to-be-split-into-a-common-library)
nova.api.openstack.placement.lib module.  It will sanitize a string to
make a suitable resource provider, resource class, or trait name.  The
caller gets to decide whether a too-long string is truncated or results
in an exception.

Related to blueprint update-provider-tree

Change-Id: Ie293b6157aab3e736c9f146cf232129a33c705ab
"}, {'created': '2018-03-27 22:56:12.000000000', 'message': "Slugification utilities for placement names

Names of resource providers, resource classes, and traits in placement
are restricted to certain characters and lengths.  Consumers (e.g. virt

commit_message:
Slugification utilities for placement names

Names of resource providers, resource classes, and traits in placement
are restricted to certain characters and lengths.  Consumers (e.g. virt
driver implementations of update_provider_tree) may wish to generate
such names dynamically based on inputs that don't necessarily know or
follow those rules.  Such consumers could use a convenient way to
sanitize such generated names such that they conform to what placement
expects.

This change set introduces a `slugify` method into the
(eventually-to-be-split-into-a-common-library)
nova.api.openstack.placement.lib module.  It will sanitize a string to
make a suitable resource provider, resource class, or trait name.  The
caller gets to decide whether a too-long string is truncated or results
in an exception.

Related to blueprint update-provider-tree

Change-Id: Ie293b6157aab3e736c9f146cf232129a33c705ab

[{'created': '2018-04-09 18:56:23.000000000', 'message': "Fix missing allowed network type 'flat' for ODL OVS

The 'flat' network type was missing from the default allowed network
types with OpenDaylight deployments.  This is OVS configuration which
detemrines which tenant network types are supported on a per node basis.
By default, flat should be allowed.

Closes-Bug: 1762495

Change-Id: Idf626948ee46a88f95f020fc12b7cd8b04db8be6
Signed-off-by: Tim Rozet <trozet@redhat.com>

commit_message:
Fix missing allowed network type 'flat' for ODL OVS

The 'flat' network type was missing from the default allowed network
types with OpenDaylight deployments.  This is OVS configuration which
detemrines which tenant network types are supported on a per node basis.
By default, flat should be allowed.

Closes-Bug: 1762495

Change-Id: Idf626948ee46a88f95f020fc12b7cd8b04db8be6
Signed-off-by: Tim Rozet <trozet@redhat.com>

subject: Corrects ODL-OVS vhostusermode default and docs
messages: [{'account_id': 17280, 'date': '2018-04-10 13:14:17.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Cherry Picked from branch master.'}, {'account_id': 14985, 'date': '2018-04-10 15:36:54.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Code-Review+2'}, {'account_id': 9414, 'date': '2018-04-10 16:25:22.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Workflow+1 Code-Review+2'}]
revisions:
[{'created': '2018-04-10 13:14:17.000000000', 'message': "Corrects ODL-OVS vhostusermode default and docs

The vhostuser_mode parameter was incorrectly defined as the
client/server mode of OVS, when actually it is the configuration of the
VIF port/QEMU mode.  Therefore a value of 'client' will actually
configure OVS to be in 'server' mode.  This type of port is deprecated
and the correct value should be 'server' (where QEMU creates the port).

Partial-Bug: 1762473

Change-Id: Idda82cae48b11eae1c79c6bbdd85827e3e43e56b
Signed-off-by: Tim Rozet <trozet@redhat.com>
(cherry picked from commit f85794de8572e9f89137da8a3cba9b33438afd34)
"}]
commit_message:
Corrects ODL-OVS vhostusermode default and docs

The vhostuser_mode parameter was incorrectly defined as the
client/server mode of OVS, when actually it is the configuration of the
VIF port/QEMU mode.  Therefore a value of 'client' will actually
configure OVS to be in 'server' mode.  This type of port is deprecated
and the correct value should be 'server' (where QEMU creates the port).

Partial-Bug: 1762473

Change-Id: Idda82cae48b11eae1c79c6bbdd85827e3e43e56b
Signed-off-by: Tim Rozet <trozet@redhat.com>
(cherry picked from commit f85794de8572e9f89137da8a3cba9b33438afd34)

commit_message:
Fix wrapping of neutron forbidden error

In neutronv2 api, the neutron forbidden error is not wrapped
correctly. The exception class expects the first parameter as
the error message but an exception object is passed.

Closes-Bug: #1720726
Change-Id: I6e88333427ec2befe2122274b02775f013404e30

commit_message:
add lower-constraints job

Create a tox environment for running the unit tests against the lower
bounds of the dependencies.

Create a lower-constraints.txt to be used to enforce the lower bounds
in those tests.

Add openstack-tox-lower-constraints job to the zuul configuration.

See http://lists.openstack.org/pipermail/openstack-dev/2018-March/128352.html
for more details.

Change-Id: I6a7a78800caf3c536603ae0bcfeb03830c8a5860
Depends-On: https://review.openstack.org/555034
Signed-off-by: Doug Hellmann <doug@doughellmann.com>

commit_message:
add lower-constraints job

Create a tox environment for running the unit tests against the lower
bounds of the dependencies.

Create a lower-constraints.txt to be used to enforce the lower bounds
in those tests.

Add openstack-tox-lower-constraints job to the zuul configuration.

See http://lists.openstack.org/pipermail/openstack-dev/2018-March/128352.html
for more details.

Change-Id: Iaf938db5d3d45a7187f2c2c619d0f86e90128fb2
Depends-On: https://review.openstack.org/555034
Signed-off-by: Doug Hellmann <doug@doughellmann.com>

subject: Fixes the OvsVhostuserMode heat parameter
messages: [{'account_id': 18575, 'date': '2018-04-10 11:03:49.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Cherry Picked from branch master.'}, {'account_id': 14985, 'date': '2018-04-10 13:48:10.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Workflow+1 Code-Review+2'}]
revisions:
[{'created': '2018-04-10 11:03:49.000000000', 'message': "Fixes the OvsVhostuserMode heat parameter

The mode was incorrectly defined as configuring the mode for OVS when it
is really configuring the client/server mode for QEMU.  A value of
'client' here will cause OVS to create the  vhostuser socket, and
actually make OVS the server.  This type of port is deprecated so the
default should be 'server' (QEMU creates the port).

Closes-Bug: 1762473

Change-Id: I7cd34b30f54766fe35e4a40a57b278166d0197cb
Signed-off-by: Tim Rozet <trozet@redhat.com>
(cherry picked from commit 2ecf3ac88bcdbab60b7f292ce635915c99acebc8)
"}]
commit_message:
Fixes the OvsVhostuserMode heat parameter

The mode was incorrectly defined as configuring the mode for OVS when it
is really configuring the client/server mode for QEMU.  A value of
'client' here will cause OVS to create the  vhostuser socket, and
actually make OVS the server.  This type of port is deprecated so the
default should be 'server' (QEMU creates the port).

Closes-Bug: 1762473

Change-Id: I7cd34b30f54766fe35e4a40a57b278166d0197cb
Signed-off-by: Tim Rozet <trozet@redhat.com>
(cherry picked from commit 2ecf3ac88bcdbab60b7f292ce635915c99acebc8)

commit_message:
Install the zuul-cloned dib and tripleo-common

For stable branches in addition to master. So that the code changed
gets deployed. Similar to the recent change to do this for master
(I72cab0131ccffb1989d6c1324d0c9b92166782da) but for all branches.

Also add the queens rdo repository paths. As stable branches now
include have queens.

Change-Id: Iac57d604fa49b6dab836001daba36da0685aed74

revisions:
[{'created': '2018-04-10 03:32:43.000000000', 'message': 'Apply the vhost group parameter for the vhost_sockets directory creation

Directory /var/lib/vhost_sockets will be used to create vhost sockets
which should have the the group name as hugetlbfs, which is common
between qemu and openvswitch to share the vhost_sockets. And the
correct selinux context to be applied on the vhost_sockets directory.
Closes-Bug: #1751711
Change-Id: Ib917cf86bd9a4ce57af243ab43337ea6c88bf76c
(cherry picked from commit 611830fd7621325fbbea5267492a631312aca767)
'}]
commit_message:
Apply the vhost group parameter for the vhost_sockets directory creation

Directory /var/lib/vhost_sockets will be used to create vhost sockets
which should have the the group name as hugetlbfs, which is common
between qemu and openvswitch to share the vhost_sockets. And the
correct selinux context to be applied on the vhost_sockets directory.
Closes-Bug: #1751711
Change-Id: Ib917cf86bd9a4ce57af243ab43337ea6c88bf76c
(cherry picked from commit 611830fd7621325fbbea5267492a631312aca767)

commit_message:
Fix run_test_list

tempest run list could return some logging line when stderr is
being redirected to stdout into CI server.

This fix just looks for expected test names instead of comparing
the exact command output.

Change-Id: Ia44d661d115db93ab37b2204be1825469d6acda8

commit_message:
Support quotas

Ensure that get_l2_gateway_connections_count is added to support
quotas. A change in horizon/neutron calls this method and
if its not an admin tenant then this fails. This results in a
tenant being unable to create a FIP when using horizon.

Closes-bug: #1762414

Change-Id: I8875334fa6700c33154bc690ebcad6cb5fe6c0c2

- gate-keystone-specs-docs-ubuntu-xenial http://docs-draft.openstack.org/31/396331/5/check/gate-keystone-specs-docs-ubuntu-xenial/3cdddaf//doc/build/html/ : SUCCESS in 2m 06s
- gate-keystone-specs-python27-ubuntu-xenial http://logs.openstack.org/31/396331/5/check/gate-keystone-specs-python27-ubuntu-xenial/040db83/ : SUCCESS in 2m 22s'}, {'account_id': 2218, 'date': '2016-11-15 18:58:55.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 5: Code-Review-1

I appreciate the effort here, but you are retreading paths we've already investigated.

THere is a better approach.  Using implied roles and something along the lines of this mechanism https://review.openstack.org/#/c/391624/  you can get most of what you want here.  Trusts will not have any power that any other form of delegation would have."}, {'account_id': 12542, 'date': '2016-11-16 10:14:32.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 5:

> I appreciate the effort here, but you are retreading paths we've already
> investigated.

Can you provide a pointer?

> THere is a better approach.  Using implied roles 

As far as I understand them, implied roles only allow you to build an
inheritance hierarchy of roles...

> and something along the lines of this mechanism
> https://review.openstack.org/#/c/391624/

...and with that you get centralized RBAC to apply to your hierarchy of roles.
The combination of the two doesn't even come close. Here's what's missing:

* There can be no resource UUID granularity (keystonemiddleware which enforces
  token-verify-role-check does not have that information - only oslo.policy
  does)

* Endpoint restrictions are not possible.

* Self-service delegation on the user's part in any cloud that has this feature
  enabled will pretty much be useless. For the implied-roles plus
  token-verify-role-check approach to be feasible, you will need a cloud
  with bullet-proof RBAC rules for every single API operation and dedicated
  roles to tie all these rules to. And every service that uses trusts needs to
  be aware of the correct role to use. Instead of saying "give me only this
  specific capability" it needs to

    (a) Travel down the rule DAG to find out if there is a role granting that
        specific capabiltity ("e.g.  volume:delete").

    (b) In 90% of cases: travel back up the DAG to arrive at the Member role
        because the cloud's operator didn't bother creating finely grained
        role/rule pairs and the service provided default rule set (sensibly)
        uses the Member role for most operations.

    (c) Create a trust with the role found in steps (a) and (b).

This approach would be fine in an ideal world where every OpenStack project
creates finely-grained default rules and/or every cloud operator creates finely
grained custom rules. This world is not ideal. See the sample rules for Glance
in token-verify-role-check for a case study in how granular the rules are going
to be. There is a reason it's so permissive (it assigns the Member role to
everything). Anything more granular than that would cause operators to pull out
their hair because they need to create tons of roles to even test the service.

The trust-scope-extensions works without these constraints.

> you can get most of what you want here.

No, I cannot. What I want is a reliable way to restrict trusts to the least
privilege in any OpenStack cloud out there, regardless of its concrete RBAC
rules. With the implied-roles plus token-verify-role-check approach a cloud
that achieves almost (but not quite) the same granularity can in theory be
built, but it will not be representative of the state of affairs in most
OpenStack clouds. So this gives me "way" but not "reliable". And arguably it's
missing "least privilege" as well because per-resource granularity is not
possible.

> Trusts will not have any power that any other form of delegation would have.

What do you mean by that?'}, {'account_id': 12542, 'date': '2016-11-16 10:54:22.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 5:

> That is OAUTH.  Do we need a separate mechanism for that?

For trusts this in their current state, this is like OAUTH yes. Much like OAUTH, they currently only allow role delegation. If https://review.openstack.org/#/c/396331/ is implemented this allows more restrictions than plain OAUTH (i.e. capabilities, endpoints), though.

On the authentication side OAUTH could be used to obtain tokens scoped to the trust. To this end, one could amend the OAUTH spec with an additional requested_trust_id parameter for the "Create Request Token" parameter which causes the requested service tokens to be scoped to the trust rather than a project.'}, {'account_id': 2218, 'date': '2016-11-16 16:28:35.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 5:

* There can be no resource UUID granularity (keystonemiddleware which enforces token-verify-role-check does not have that information - only oslo.policy does)

Correct.  But that check is static, and will stay in place.  It is not something that end users should be modifying or changing.

There are some people requesting policy enforced on direct ownership of objects but that approach does not scale (Pets vs Cattle, to use a horrible metaphore)  as you then need the exact person to perform a check, and that forces delegation to do impersonation.  The restrictions of operations should be limited to classes of resources in a project and roles for a user.

THere have been some attempts to go behond that, and I would recommend you join the weekly policy meetings we just started to see what other people want.

But regardless of that, it would not be Trusts that enforce it, but some wider policy extension.'}, {'account_id': 2218, 'date': '2016-11-16 16:31:11.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 5:

"Endpoint restrictions are not possible."

Actually, they are, I just did not take the spec that far.  If you have the full URL, you can acually do a finer grained URL pattern selection based on the endpoint.  The problem with this has been that Endpoints do not know their own identity, and thus it is really hard to match.  Even the Hostname used to call the endpoint is likely to have been modified by a proxy in many cases.

The better option would be to have some pre-agreed on name that scopes the endpoints policy that is not assigned by Keystone;  we can work on that once we have the RBAC mechanism fixed.'}, {'account_id': 2218, 'date': '2016-11-16 16:33:42.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 5:

For Actual operations:

The goal is to make the RBAC mechanism modifyable by the end deployer.  Ideally, a single operation could have its own role, and the implied roles mechanisms would let the admin change the enforcement without having to change the assignments for every user.

With implied roles. a user can create a trust that has a subset of their roles, including ones they only get through inference rules.  Thus, we *can* do operation level delegations.'}, {'account_id': 12542, 'date': '2016-11-17 10:03:24.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 5:

>> There can be no resource UUID granularity (keystonemiddleware 
>> which enforces token-verify-role-check does not have that 
>> information - only oslo.policy does)

> Correct.  But that check is static, and will stay in place.  It is not
> something that end users should be modifying or changing.

trust-scope-extension does not modify existing policy rules. Much like the RBAC
check it happens as an additional gate _before_ the policy check. I only
proposed oslo.policy as a location for that check since it's got access to
objects' UUIDs and can thus match them against UUIDs mentioned in the trust.

> There are some people requesting policy enforced on direct ownership of
> objects but that approach does not scale (Pets vs Cattle, to use a horrible
> metaphore)

I believe my approach is scalable. Let me explain:

> as you then need the exact person to perform a check, and that forces
> delegation to do impersonation.

No it doesn't require impersonation. The trust capability check matches the
UUID in the trust's capability rule against the UUID in the object. After that
the regular policy and/or role check is performed (and may still fail). For the request to succeed you consequently need two things:

1) Matching UUIDs for object and capability rule

2) The roles required to access the object in question at the level you are
   trying to access it at. Impersonation is _not_ required."}, {'account_id': 12542, 'date': '2016-11-17 10:22:21.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 5:

>> "Endpoint restrictions are not possible."

> Actually, they are, I just did not take the spec that far.  If you have the
> full URL, you can acually do a finer grained URL pattern selection based on
> the endpoint.  The problem with this has been that Endpoints do not know
> their own identity, and thus it is really hard to match.  Even the Hostname
> used to call the endpoint is likely to have been modified by a proxy in many
> cases.

True enough. That part is a bit messy anyway, since it also raises (valid)
objections about having region specific information (i.e. endpoint URLs) in
there and I may end up dropping/modifying it. One conceivable approach would be
having a restriction to endpoint type (e.g. adminURL, internalURL, publicURL).'}, {'account_id': 12542, 'date': '2016-11-17 10:49:44.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 5:

# For Actual operations:

> The goal is to make the RBAC mechanism modifyable by the end deployer.
> Ideally, a single operation could have its own role, and the implied roles
> mechanisms would let the admin change the enforcement without having to
> change the assignments for every user.

Ideally, yes. The logistics for that are pretty daunting, though. Case in
point:

  % for i in cinder nova heat
  > wc -l $i/etc/$i/policy.json
  138 cinder/etc/cinder/policy.json
  491 nova/etc/nova/policy.json
  85 heat/etc/heat/policy.json

This averages out to 238 api operations and thus 238 roles per service. Let's
make it generous 200 roles because there's some noise in these files, too.

This leaves you with thousands of roles that need to be created for this level
of security to be feasible.  Every service in the Big Tent needs to do create
these automatically (no operator is going to do that by themselves) and get it
right. And then you need to make sure (at a minimum) your Member role implies
all of these. I guess that falls to the services, too. I think that ideal takes
a while to reach.

trust-scope-extensions can be implemented right now, because it doesn't need
such an elaborate role infrastructure. And no matter how the policy overhaul
ends up looking, it is entirely orthogonal to it. These trust scope extensions
will always only be an additional check _before_ the policy check (and only for
trust scoped tokens), because the two things have different goals:

1) Policy is concerned with controlling which user gets to perform which
   set of operations.

2) Trusts are concerned with delegating tightly limited subsets of what policy
   allows a user. Ideally it is concerned with delegating subsets of
   cardinality 1. This can be grafted onto policy, but it entails the herculean
   effort outlined above. Beyond that they are concerned with imposing further
   restrictions on that single-element subset, namely per-UUID granularity.
   Again, this could be grafted onto policy but would complicate it even
   further.

Also, there's the practical concern of all the ingredients currently being
thrown into the policy discussion. Everybody's got their own (incompatible)
axes to grind. Even the discussion on all of that will take a long time to
conclude, not to mention implementation. Again, trust-scope-extensions can
be implemented right now, using existing infrastructure.

> With implied roles. a user can create a trust that has a subset of their
> roles, including ones they only get through inference rules.  Thus, we *can*
> do operation level delegations.

Yes, once the logistics of establishing these fine-grained roles and rules in
the first place are out of the way. That will take a long time."}, {'account_id': 6482, 'date': '2016-12-16 02:09:47.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 5: Code-Review-2'}, {'account_id': 6482, 'date': '2016-12-16 02:09:49.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 5:

I will remove the -2 once this is resolved.'}, {'account_id': 8482, 'date': '2018-03-07 09:43:39.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 7:

(5 comments)

Adam, please reconsider the -2, I do not think this is in conflict with building a general solution to RBAC. This won't touch the current RBAC system at all, and application credentials still must have traditional role assignments in order to work. We can keep building on that while also providing a basic solution that can satisfy end-users.

Johannes, one thing that Adam brought up yesterday in IRC that I think is valid is how we are going to deal with APIs that have implied actions behind the scenes, such as POST /v2.1/servers automatically calling glance, neutron, cinder, etc. We don't want the user to have to think about all those implied API calls. At the PTG we handwaved over "service tokens" (http://specs.openstack.org/openstack/keystone-specs/specs/keystonemiddleware/juno/service-tokens.html) to help with this but I'd like to see something solid reflected in this spec.'}, {'account_id': 12542, 'date': '2018-03-07 10:14:19.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 7:

(9 comments)

> Johannes, one thing that Adam brought up yesterday in IRC that I 
> think is valid is how we are going to deal with APIs that have 
> implied actions behind the scenes, such as POST /v2.1/servers 
> automatically calling glance, neutron, cinder, etc.

Hmm. Good point. That's either easy or _very_ tricky, for...

> We don't want the user to have to think about all those implied API
> calls.

...if one were to do nothing these kinds of requests would of course fail if they did not have dedicated white list entries, yes. For the use cases we discussed so far this would not be _much_ of a problem, though:

* Magnum would not have any implied calls for certificate signing
* Magnum may have implied calls for handling Neutron load balancers
* Magnum may have implied calls for attaching/detaching volumes
* Monasca would not have any implied calls
* Heat would not have any implied calls for wait condition signalling

So two out of three use cases do not even involve implied calls. And I'd argue that Magnum is a bit of a special case anyway - it's uncommon to require that much API access inside a VM. Which leads to my somewhat heretical idea: if somebody really needs to issue requests that cause implied requests down the line it should be ok for them to have to think about these implied requests and add additional white list entries that allow them.

I'd be happy to codify this in the Limitations section. Thoughts?

> At the PTG we handwaved over "service tokens (http://specs.openstack.org
> /openstack/keystone-specs/specs/keystonemiddleware/juno/service-
> tokens.html) to help with this but I'd like to see something solid 
> reflected in this spec.

Hmm. I'm not too fond of this kind of approach. It softens the white list because it may cause inadvertent information leaks or worse because a user thinks they nailed things down tight by allowing access only to a few Nova APIs but opened a backdoor into Neutron and Cinder in fact.'}, {'account_id': 12542, 'date': '2018-03-07 13:39:52.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 8.'}, {'account_id': 12542, 'date': '2018-03-07 13:44:06.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 8:

Ok, I added a scheme for using service tokens to handle recursive calls now. There are two things about it that I'm not quite sure of, though:

1) There's no way to know how much in the way of extra permissions individual services may give a request that has a service token bolted on.
2) Will the service token remain attached to follow-up requests if it's part of the request object passed to the service by keystonemiddleware?"}, {'account_id': 2218, 'date': '2018-03-07 15:18:06.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 8:

(4 comments)

I like where this is headed, but I thihnk you are focused on cases where the number of API calls redelegated is relatively few.  In cases where the majority of the API calls need to be redelgated, this is going to be very unwieldy. 

In order for me to remove the -2, this needs to be reconcilied with the RBAC in middleware approach.  I think they can peacefully co-exist, and even complement each other.  But if they compete, it is going to confuse people, and make debugging very painful.


RBAc in middleware does not need to happen first, just this approach and RBAC in middleware need to have a common mechanism to indicate the URLs, and to be able to link from a role to that URL.  I think you are close, but that is essential.'}, {'account_id': 2903, 'date': '2018-03-07 17:31:58.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 8:

(4 comments)'}, {'account_id': 2218, 'date': '2018-03-07 18:55:28.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 8:

Here are the notes from talking with Morgan on video.

1. Keystone operator has to opt in
 Wildcard is sufficient
otherwise full URL Pattern + optional dictionary
Any user must be able to query valid patterns

If there is an explicit wildcard, user can use free-form strings for URLs.


2.  Middleware needs to understand the extra URL fragments before it can be enabled in Keystone
  No dead/unusable API code in Keystone.

3.  Keystone cannot be relied on to talk to Nova.  All info must be queried from Nova during run time or pushed from Nova by operator explicitly.

4.  URL patterns can be seeded from upstream builds but must be assumed to lag microversion'}, {'account_id': 2218, 'date': '2018-03-07 19:03:18.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 8:

(1 comment)

Please simplify this spec based upon our conversations:

1) Remove the user-supplied templates (that work like the operator templates). The operator supplies templates that will be used to validate (think like json-schema) the white-list urls that users supply.

2) Do not add a config option to enable/disable APIs (see #1)

3) Store the user-supplied data for the white-list in the app-cred. The operator supplied lists are meant to validate the user-input, not be exclusively relational (don't force the user to reference the "rule" the operator uploaded). You may, behind the scenes make a relational link between what operator templates match(ed) the user-input to ease invalidation checks for when the operator list is updated, this is not required.

4) if you would like to re-process user app-creds if the operator template is updated, you may implement (and document in the spec) such functionality, but I worry that the invalidation of a user-app-cred in such a manner is inappropriate and poor UX.

5) You will need to change the {*} wild card to allow "/" as well; the need to allow '/' is to allow a user to be more restrictive in the app cred, than the API itself (e.g only specific actions on sub-urls beyond what the operator wishes to upload).

6) All operator templates should be implicitly anchored at the start (in REGEX parlance, "^" at the start).'}, {'account_id': 5046, 'date': '2018-03-21 15:05:39.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 17: Code-Review-1
