I'm also now aware that we haven't defined what the name of the property is in the API.'}, {'account_id': 12542, 'date': '2018-03-23 12:28:57.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 20: Code-Review-1

(5 comments)

Alright. I will probably get into trouble for stating my opinion on this, but
this ban on the term "white list" stinks to high heaven! But I won't be able to 
face myself in a mirror ever again if I just go along with this rather than 
speaking up now. So here we go:

1) "white list" is an established industry term. Everybody in IT, be they a
   programmer, a system administrator a manager or an ITIL auditor will know 
   the term and understand its purpose. The convoluted language we replace it
   by will not nearly be universally understood. Consider somebody with poor
   English skills, for instance. They'll have trouble understanding what this
   spec is about, they'll have trouble understanding the documentation on this
   feature and they'll have trouble contributing to the resulting code. All 
   because an already complex subject matter gets even harder to reason about
   due to political correctness forbidding the usage of a precise technical 
   term. This is the very opposite of "inclusive language"! This language
   _excludes_ everyone with less-than-stellar English skills!

2) "It has beeen brought to my attention". By "somebody", I presume. So 
   "somebody" who does not even want their name associated with this publicly 
   wants to bully us into changing our terminology. And apparently they are 
   succeeding. We've got an unknown person pulling strings in the background,
   censoring our (not very, apparently) free speech. And...
   
3) ...you, Adam, are going along with it. At a time when I am sound asleep
   (01:16AM in Europe) given the time zone differences and without even the
   curteousy of asking me first. Now I do realize this is a collaborative
   effort, but I would appreciate a little bit of discussion before simply
   going ahead with this pretty sweeping edit.

4) There is just a nebulous `"whitelist" and "blacklist" are not friendly 
   terms` justifying this change. Why are they not friendly? Who are they
   unfriendly against? Is there an actual person or group of people who feel 
   offended by this and have they spoken out against it? Or is there a third
   party who is offended on behalf of somebody whom they have not even asked 
   about their actual opinion?  

5) I conclude with a bit of constructive criticism: "restriction list" is
   definitely the wrong replacement term, since its meaning is "that which is 
   not allowed". "permission list" with its "that which is allowed" semantics 
   would be more appropriate.
   
Last but not least the disclaimer in case there are any lawyers hidden in the
woodwork: all opinions are my own, personal opinions, not my employer's.'}, {'account_id': 2218, 'date': '2018-03-23 13:52:40.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 20:

Johannes:  I understand your concern.  This is an English language issue embedded in American culture.  There are many terms in common usage that are racist in retrospect.  We use the terms blacklist and whitelist in the Federation mappings, so we have overlooked this in the past.  But as we move forward through time, we, hopefully also grow wiser.

Instead of getting too worked up over "this is what is used in the past" lets get a more accurate term in place.  Since we are not implementing a corresponding "do not allow" list, we should really look at this as a polace to say "what is this?"  and thus come up with a better term.

The term "fine grained" was what was used earlier.  Its also not perfect.'}, {'account_id': 12542, 'date': '2018-03-23 17:46:05.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 20: -Code-Review

Ok, so here's an expert opinion by a linguist:

  https://www.quora.com/Is-the-term-blacklist-racist

tl;dr: the term "blacklist" is not racist. Since - being the antonym of "blacklist" - it is the same side of the same medal I believe it's not too much of a stretch to extend that verdict to the term "whitelist" as well.

If you still insist on not using the term "whitelist", though, I'll live with that (I'm certainly not going to throw a spanner into the works over terminology). In that case I suggest using "capability" for the individual entry and "list of capabilities" for the URL. Just like "whitelist" it's a well established industry term probably just as universally understandable.'}, {'account_id': 12542, 'date': '2018-03-23 17:48:25.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 20:

s/for the URL/for the whole list/ - sorry, got mixed up editing.'}, {'account_id': 5046, 'date': '2018-03-23 17:53:42.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 20:

> (5 comments)
 > 
 > Alright. I will probably get into trouble for stating my opinion on
 > this, but
 > this ban on the term "white list" stinks to high heaven! But I
 > won't be able to
 > face myself in a mirror ever again if I just go along with this
 > rather than
 > speaking up now. So here we go:
 > 
 > 1) "white list" is an established industry term. Everybody in IT,
 > be they a
 > programmer, a system administrator a manager or an ITIL auditor
 > will know
 > the term and understand its purpose. The convoluted language we
 > replace it
 > by will not nearly be universally understood. Consider somebody
 > with poor
 > English skills, for instance. They'll have trouble understanding
 > what this
 > spec is about, they'll have trouble understanding the documentation
 > on this
 > feature and they'll have trouble contributing to the resulting
 > code. All
 > because an already complex subject matter gets even harder to
 > reason about
 > due to political correctness forbidding the usage of a precise
 > technical
 > term. This is the very opposite of "inclusive language"! This
 > language
 > _excludes_ everyone with less-than-stellar English skills!

I agree that deviating from an industry standard isn't ideal, but we've done it before. Outside of a couple minor differences, application credentials are *extremely* close to API keys.

 > 
 > 2) "It has beeen brought to my attention". By "somebody", I
 > presume. So
 > "somebody" who does not even want their name associated with this
 > publicly
 > wants to bully us into changing our terminology. And apparently
 > they are
 > succeeding. We've got an unknown person pulling strings in the
 > background,
 > censoring our (not very, apparently) free speech. And...

This was in reference to https://twitter.com/bketelsen/status/976811995981807616

I should have clarified my response to Adam [1], and implied starting with a discussion. I apologize if my response invoked an update in a way that made you unaware of the changes. That was not my intention.

[1] https://twitter.com/LanceBragstad/status/977049707838099456

 > 
 > 3) ...you, Adam, are going along with it. At a time when I am sound
 > asleep
 > (01:16AM in Europe) given the time zone differences and without
 > even the
 > curteousy of asking me first. Now I do realize this is a
 > collaborative
 > effort, but I would appreciate a little bit of discussion before
 > simply
 > going ahead with this pretty sweeping edit.

I understand it can be frustrating to wake up and realize things moved without being a part of a discussion. But Adam was only trying to be helpful.

We have ways to propose changes without modifying the original patch (sharing diffs, proposing following on patches, et cetera). We should have used one of those techniques, especially since they are much more social and are great for kick starting discussions.

 > 
 > 4) There is just a nebulous `"whitelist" and "blacklist" are not
 > friendly
 > terms` justifying this change. Why are they not friendly? Who are
 > they
 > unfriendly against? Is there an actual person or group of people
 > who feel
 > offended by this and have they spoken out against it? Or is there a
 > third
 > party who is offended on behalf of somebody whom they have not even
 > asked
 > about their actual opinion?

To my knowledge this is purely proactive. I'd hate to look back on this opportunity and say we had a chance to fix this but we failed to even discuss it.

 > 
 > 5) I conclude with a bit of constructive criticism: "restriction
 > list" is
 > definitely the wrong replacement term, since its meaning is "that
 > which is
 > not allowed". "permission list" with its "that which is allowed"
 > semantics
 > would be more appropriate.

I appreciate the constructive criticism.

I think we should all take a step back and work through this as a group. Let's have a discussion and look at some other terms. Semantically, everyone appears excited and happy about this work. I'd hate to see the problems you're solving linger because we had the opportunity to change a term and failed to come to consensus.

 > 
 > Last but not least the disclaimer in case there are any lawyers
 > hidden in the
 > woodwork: all opinions are my own, personal opinions, not my
 > employer's.'}, {'account_id': 12542, 'date': '2018-03-27 09:24:50.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 20:

So, this has been sitting here in awkward silence for quite a while now. I for one not happy with getting rid of the perfectly fine term "whitelist" for what I consider dubious reasons[0].

That being said, I also don't want to block a perfectly fine feature because I cannot use my terminology of choice. So if we decide not to use "whitelist" I'll be happy to rewrite this to use "capability list" (I like that term because it's almost as universally understandable as "whitelist"). I'd just like to have a decision on this, so I can finish he spec? So can we reach one?


[0] See https://twitter.com/jeffwilcox/status/976817000872796160 for a guess at why the whole thing happened: Brian Ketelsen is at Microsoft where they run PoliCheck. PoliCheck is basically a souped up grep that checks code for "bad" words. That tool lighting up like a Christmas tree at the drop of a hat is probably what sparked his quest to get rid of "unfriendly" words.'}, {'account_id': 2903, 'date': '2018-03-27 16:41:08.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 20:

> It has beeen brought to my attention that the term "whitelist" and
 > "blacklist" are not friendly terms, and are not in keeping with the
 > spirit of Keystone collaboration. I'm removing the term "whitelist"
 > in the next update.

Adam, please look up linguistic histories before adding this to the conversations - this is detracting from the rest of the conversation and not worth a -1. "Blacklist" and "whitelist" have no racial histories, and it is functionally descriptive (it is based upon blackball vote in written form, reaching back to greece; a simple google search shows this). 

Please be careful about adding this type of information into the review process, it tacitly means we must search and proactively defend ourselves in all forms from any potential attacks warranted or not. This all stems from a bad understanding of language via a tweet -- lets not use twitter as a source of truth here.'}, {'account_id': 2218, 'date': '2018-03-27 17:15:54.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 20:

I can support using the term Capability list.  I think it is the proper term to use here.  The items of the list are capabilities in a security context.'}, {'account_id': 5046, 'date': '2018-03-27 17:31:19.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 20:

We discussed during the keystone meeting [0].

TL;DR was to use capability list instead of whitelist for the following reasons:

- Capabilities are more descriptive of what's actually being stored. Even though whitelist is descriptive, people still have to ask what the whitelist is for.
- Specifying whitelist also implies blacklist support, which we don't plan and doesn't necessarily make sense with the direction of this feature

We should use "whitelist" to describe the functionality of the capability list in documentation.


[0] http://eavesdrop.openstack.org/meetings/keystone/2018/keystone.2018-03-27-16.00.log.html#l-44'}, {'account_id': 12542, 'date': '2018-03-28 16:39:07.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 20:

(5 comments)

Ok, I reworked this now to talk about capabilities instead of a whitelist. Works pretty well because it allows for substituting "whitelist entry" for "capability" in lots of places.

I switched the blueprint URL back to the original whitelist one so as not to have a 404ing URL in there if needed I can create a new blueprint, too.

One notable change I also made: I added a version string payload to the Header sent by keystonemiddleware. That way we can extend this thing later and invalidate tokens that use features added later if the capability implementation in keystonemiddleware cannot handle them.'}, {'account_id': 12542, 'date': '2018-03-28 16:39:11.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 21.'}, {'account_id': 5046, 'date': '2018-03-29 14:57:40.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 21: Code-Review-1

(10 comments)

Just a couple comments and questions. Otherwise this is looking good. Thanks, Johannes.'}, {'account_id': 2218, 'date': '2018-03-30 16:42:57.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 22.'}, {'account_id': 2218, 'date': '2018-03-30 16:43:40.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 22:

FIxed the JSON formatting to pass the tox checks.'}, {'account_id': 8482, 'date': '2018-04-03 19:18:27.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 22:

(2 comments)

I'm pretty happy with this, just a couple small suggestions along with Lance's comments."}, {'account_id': 2218, 'date': '2018-04-07 21:50:18.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 22: Code-Review+2

Ready to go with this myself.  We can continue to tweak, but the bones are good.'}, {'account_id': 12542, 'date': '2018-04-09 16:25:57.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 23.'}, {'account_id': 12542, 'date': '2018-04-09 16:26:52.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 23:

(12 comments)'}, {'account_id': 2903, 'date': '2018-04-09 17:32:09.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 23: Code-Review+1

(1 comment)

Minor nit that can be fixed in a follow-up, but needs to be addressed (if you propose a followup, I'll bump to +2)"}, {'account_id': 5046, 'date': '2018-04-09 19:35:46.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 23: Code-Review+2

(1 comment)

I think this is good to go. One minor comment inline, but that can be fixed in a follow up.'}, {'account_id': 12542, 'date': '2018-04-10 12:29:23.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 24.'}, {'account_id': 12542, 'date': '2018-04-10 12:29:27.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 23:

(2 comments)'}, {'account_id': 2218, 'date': '2018-04-10 14:05:02.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 24: Code-Review+2

Good job here, Johannes.'}, {'account_id': 5046, 'date': '2018-04-10 14:06:46.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 24: Code-Review+2

(1 comment)

Looks good, thanks for pushing this forward. Waiting for a few others to give it a once over.'}, {'account_id': 2903, 'date': '2018-04-10 16:05:31.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 24: Workflow+1 Code-Review+2'}]

commit_message:
Add capabilities to application credentials

This spec describes a capability list extension for
application credentials that allows their creator to restrict
their usage to a white list of capabilities, each of which
consists of HTTP methods and permitted URL paths. Any request
using the application credential must match an entry in this
list. All other requests are rejected.

Change-Id: Iffc853971e909bd3ca8829b410a7014929c8b7e6

commit_message:
Fix overcloud services connectivity validation

The overcloud services validation uses the Keystone API version 2 to generate a
token. This doesn't work anymore since Queens.

This patch changes the validation to use  API version 3 instead.

Closes-Bug: #1757187

Change-Id: I4e080521a334fca4999b9bc6e3e1bcacd24c476b
(cherry picked from commit 496ab519fede40d6cac188d33f56c016b83937e0)

commit_message:
Support --ssh-user argument to upgrade/update run command

To allow upgrading both Nova based and Deployed Server based
environments, we introduced --ssh-user argument (until all envs have
tripleo-admin user).

Note: CLI for FFWD upgrade is being implemented, so a --ssh-user patch
to tripleo-upgrade FFWD will have to follow later.

Related-Bug: #1759845
Depends-On: I0df57002b2305c1e2504c9f7a7d0c326d8ffcaf7
Change-Id: Ib486a812aa9fd96bc753eda122cd05682d97b209
(cherry picked from commit 6415178b25559032d51fa8c6722c5cd99306bd32)

commit_message:
Make sure we keep using tripleo-admin as ssh user in CI

First we switched the user to tripleo-admin [1] which made CI on
updates job green, but broke Nova-based environments. We're now
switching the default back to heat-admin [2] which will break updates
job again, so we add support to tripleo-upgrade [3] to customize the
user name and set it here to the value for CI (deployed server
environments).

Fear not, when we switch to --config-download as our only supported
deployment method, tripleo-admin should become unconditionally present
in all environments, and we'll be able to converge to a single method
of logging into the overcloud nodes.

[1] I1ec66886d6d61ccf528e5e27872cf68c7a603727
[2] I0df57002b2305c1e2504c9f7a7d0c326d8ffcaf7
[3] Ib486a812aa9fd96bc753eda122cd05682d97b209

Co-Authored-By: Jose Luis Franco <jfrancoa@redhat.com>
Change-Id: I063d438fbeeded28134658aaefc6c8b7119aee43
Related-Bug: #1759845
Depends-On: I0df57002b2305c1e2504c9f7a7d0c326d8ffcaf7

commit_message:
repo-use.yml: Scope host groups properly

When using multi-region swift or when including more
thank just OpenStack-related hosts in the inventory,
it's important to scope where these tasks are run
properly to prevent attempts at doing things on the
wrong hosts.

The sope of the play now runs against the same scope
for hosts as the openstack-hosts playbook. This is
more consistent and will help prevent unwanted side-
effects.

Change-Id: Ia755845ac2b04f080db45905263059b92072d194
(cherry picked from commit 8841cf379769dc710a9a00c8f82a4223ccda5ed0)

commit_message:
Added network enabled check in multiple nic role rendering file

Without this check, even though network is disabled in
network_data file, network configuration is present in role file.

Change-Id: I03c361f3549f2d0bb9367f7fcd77349b3249fa70
Closes-Bug: 1761484

and upgrades playbooks. We default to heat-admin for now, as that's

commit_message:
Allow providing --ssh-user for update/upgrade run commands

When config-download becomes our only way of deploying, we'll be able
to assume that tripleo-admin user always exists. Until then it's not a
given, so we need to allow using custom user names for running updates
and upgrades playbooks. We default to heat-admin for now, as that's
expected to work on majority of current production environments.

Change-Id: I0df57002b2305c1e2504c9f7a7d0c326d8ffcaf7
Closes-Bug: #1759845
(cherry picked from commit 17cd14114ffc8ca3e51fde550483aa0e21f19ffc)

subject: Generate inventory with tripleo-admin user
messages: [{'account_id': 8042, 'date': '2018-04-06 11:16:09.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Cherry Picked from branch master.'}, {'account_id': 8042, 'date': '2018-04-06 11:25:50.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:\n\n(1 comment)'}, {'account_id': 20775, 'date': '2018-04-10 10:54:26.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Workflow+1 Code-Review+2'}]
revisions:
[{'created': '2018-04-06 11:16:09.000000000', 'message': 'Generate inventory with tripleo-admin user

This is already the default when we generate the inventory via Mistral
workflow [1]. By using heat-admin we cannot connect to Deployed Server
environments, which e.g. affects CI, so we should use the same default
that the Mistral workflow uses nowadays.

commit_message:
Generate inventory with tripleo-admin user

This is already the default when we generate the inventory via Mistral
workflow [1]. By using heat-admin we cannot connect to Deployed Server
environments, which e.g. affects CI, so we should use the same default
that the Mistral workflow uses nowadays.

[1] https://git.openstack.org/cgit/openstack/tripleo-common/tree/tripleo_common/actions/ansible.py#n526

Partial-Bug: #1757090
Change-Id: Idc0dba7a119efedae7f762d3a351419c22584b61
(cherry picked from commit 02a49c90599e8ce10f82fddfbea6be1f0fa2a24f)

[{'created': '2018-04-06 16:14:05.000000000', 'message': '[queens] Put back (now empty) fluentd-client.yaml

This will allow us to get around a tricky error in heatclient template
processing with persisted user-environment.yaml on
upgrade. Interestingly, we need the old file to exist in the plan so
that we can map the resource to OS::Heat::None during the upgrade
process (heatclient tries to fetch it even though a subsequent env
file would map the resource to None), and all alternative solutions
are considerably worse than just putting the file back in place.

We will not need this file in Rocky as the resource will be mapped to
None before upgrading Q->R. This commit is specific for P->Q upgrade.

commit_message:
[queens] Put back (now empty) fluentd-client.yaml

This will allow us to get around a tricky error in heatclient template
processing with persisted user-environment.yaml on
upgrade. Interestingly, we need the old file to exist in the plan so
that we can map the resource to OS::Heat::None during the upgrade
process (heatclient tries to fetch it even though a subsequent env
file would map the resource to None), and all alternative solutions
are considerably worse than just putting the file back in place.

We will not need this file in Rocky as the resource will be mapped to
None before upgrading Q->R. This commit is specific for P->Q upgrade.

Change-Id: I39573cca4dc16a024582de562b850ecfa9bb1dfd
Co-Authored-By: Jose Luis Franco <jfrancoa@redhat.com>
Co-Authored-By: Sofer Athlan-Guyot <sathlang@redhat.com>
Closes-Bug: #1758406

[{'created': '2018-04-09 07:48:13.000000000', 'message': 'Make keepalived initialization more predictable

This prevents forcing keepalived to renegotiate roles between amps more
times than necessary.

Keepalived is already running at the point that we do our initial "amp
start" command, so if we actually force a restart it loses its state and
has to renegotiate. I would consider the fact that this works without
issue right now "very good luck". Let's make this more sane, and only
reload if that's what we need to do.

Change-Id: Ie920bba9b2d718c59c6ce00c0f013058ed2634bb
(cherry picked from commit d4474e8943d29d6c46f40631ae291dd47baa7927)

commit_message:
Make keepalived initialization more predictable

This prevents forcing keepalived to renegotiate roles between amps more
times than necessary.

Keepalived is already running at the point that we do our initial "amp
start" command, so if we actually force a restart it loses its state and
has to renegotiate. I would consider the fact that this works without
issue right now "very good luck". Let's make this more sane, and only
reload if that's what we need to do.

Change-Id: Ie920bba9b2d718c59c6ce00c0f013058ed2634bb
(cherry picked from commit d4474e8943d29d6c46f40631ae291dd47baa7927)

revisions:
[{'created': '2018-03-26 14:11:25.000000000', 'message': "Make monasca-ui python3 compatible

In order to make monasca-ui python3 compatible this
patch set:
- Add six to requirements.txt
- Add py35 to tox.ini
- Replace dict.iteritems() with six.iteritems(dict)
- Replace prit msg with print(msg)
- Replace unicode with six.text_type(msg)
- Replaces urlparse with six.moves.urllib
- Python 3 getting the keys() of a dict returns
  a dict_keys object instead of a list
- python 2.x calling keys makes a copy of the key
  that you can iterate over while modifying the dict.
  This doesn't work in python 3.x because keys
  returns an iterator instead of a list.
  Another way is to use list to force a copy of the keys
  to be made.
Signed-off-by: Charles Short <zulcss@gmail.com>

Change-Id: Ibc644a734edceea0b36f2df2c73300d1e4db925f

commit_message:
Make monasca-ui python3 compatible

In order to make monasca-ui python3 compatible this
patch set:
- Add six to requirements.txt
- Add py35 to tox.ini
- Replace dict.iteritems() with six.iteritems(dict)
- Replace prit msg with print(msg)
- Replace unicode with six.text_type(msg)
- Replaces urlparse with six.moves.urllib
- Python 3 getting the keys() of a dict returns
  a dict_keys object instead of a list
- python 2.x calling keys makes a copy of the key
  that you can iterate over while modifying the dict.
  This doesn't work in python 3.x because keys
  returns an iterator instead of a list.
  Another way is to use list to force a copy of the keys
  to be made.

Story: 2000975
Task: 4129

Signed-off-by: Charles Short <zulcss@gmail.com>

Change-Id: Ibc644a734edceea0b36f2df2c73300d1e4db925f

I appreciate your attention to detail by including a metadefs update as part of your implementation, but I'd prefer you hold off on proposing changes to the metadefs until after the nova spec has been approved.  We at the Glance project cannot assess the accuracy of the property name and description until after the nova community has approved the spec.  > I'm not saying "don't do this", I'm saying "don't do this *now*".

Apologies, I never meant to put any pressure, I just wanted to check whether the CI was now working. I won't recheck anymore.'}, {'account_id': 5314, 'date': '2018-04-10 15:17:46.000000000', 'content': "Abandoned

There's been no movement on the nova side.  Feel free to restore this when that happens."}]

commit_message:
Add libvirt image metadef for hw_power_governor

As part of the vm-power-management blueprint in Nova
(https://blueprints.launchpad.net/nova/+spec/vm-power-management), add
to the metadef registry the 'hw_power_governor' property, used to flag
images requiring a power management communication channel.

Implements: blueprint vm-power-management
Depends-on: I909827bdb542bffeecd0e694fadd94f650445db2
Change-Id: Id904c8fc27333c9f06088a79359461b3d83d1ec8

commit_message:
Revert "Use the new PTI for document build"

This reverts commit 4f81c419947e2793e3eda4ce8f3664058b5a5d2c.

This uses pbr's autodoc feature, as seen in the '[pbr]' section of
'setup.cfg'. This ensures that the 'sphinx-apidoc' command is run
automatically when building docs with the 'build_sphinx' setuptools
command. However, this is not run when building docs using
'sphinx-build' directly. We need to migrate away from this pbr feature
first before we can use the new PTI. This was not seen in the gate
because the zuul jobs don't run 'tox' directly anymore.

Change-Id: If4c7a89c8bcc3bfec1d777b42f4b40a69af9845a

commit_message:
Revert "Follow the new PTI for document build"

This reverts commit e52c99825cd888c9e7771697e189bfdba8cbe406.

This uses pbr's autodoc feature, as seen in the '[pbr]' section of
'setup.cfg'. This ensures that the 'sphinx-apidoc' command is run
automatically when building docs with the 'build_sphinx' setuptools
command. However, this is not run when building docs using
'sphinx-build' directly. We need to migrate away from this pbr feature
first before we can use the new PTI. This was not seen in the gate
because the zuul jobs don't run 'tox' directly anymore.

Change-Id: Icfcd8884b633b3c47fc8821c7597ec8e53870d1a

messages:
[{'account_id': 15334, 'date': '2018-03-21 10:21:58.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 1.'}, {'account_id': 11904, 'date': '2018-03-21 12:50:53.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Code-Review-1

This actually moved things away from using pbr. Can you explain what you are seeing and why you are doing his? Unless the PTI has changed, this is undoing compliance to that.'}, {'account_id': 15334, 'date': '2018-03-21 17:46:18.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1:

> This actually moved things away from using pbr. Can you explain
 > what you are seeing and why you are doing his? Unless the PTI has
 > changed, this is undoing compliance to that.

The issues are these lines:

https://github.com/openstack/oslo.cache/blob/1.29.0/setup.cfg#L43-L45

As noted on openstack-dev earlier today, this ensures 'sphinx-apidoc' or something close to it is run _before_ docs are built. By moving to 'sphinx-build', we lose that and start getting warnings because reference/api is not populated. You can see this if you add '-W' to the 'sphinx-build' call and either (a) remove the '[pbr]' and '[build_sphinx]' sections from 'setup.cfg' (to test this in the gate) or run 'tox -e docs' locally."}, {'account_id': 15334, 'date': '2018-04-10 15:12:03.000000000', 'content': "Abandoned

We've got the sphinxcontrib-apidoc extension to fix this for us now. Actually fixing that will have to be done elsewhere"}]

commit_message:
Revert "Use the new PTI for document build"

This reverts commit 5ae8e69b4126ae408e0c4d354ee25b34b009c932.

This uses pbr's autodoc feature, as seen in the '[pbr]' section of
'setup.cfg'. This ensures that the 'sphinx-apidoc' command is run
automatically when building docs with the 'build_sphinx' setuptools
command. However, this is not run when building docs using
'sphinx-build' directly. We need to migrate away from this pbr feature
first before we can use the new PTI. This was not seen in the gate
because the zuul jobs don't run 'tox' directly anymore.

Change-Id: I363f543ea7091f6832f242e6a8062f1d42c200b8

commit_message:
Wrap the cib file deletion commands in a function

Let's avoid a bunch of duplicated code by wrapping the following
 FileUtils.rm(cib, :force => true)
 FileUtils.rm("#{cib}.orig", :force => true)

In a single delete_cib(cib) function. This will also be useful for some
upcoming module rework

Change-Id: Iccc19e75387fc187dfac4909b594581f1d1511a6

[{'created': '2018-04-09 07:06:34.000000000', 'message': "Don't indent TC candidate lists

The Sphinx directive '   *' generates a blockquote'd list which isn't
needed for TC elections as we don't need nested lists like we do for PTL
elections.

Switch to a std. ul

Change-Id: I999a2823d421b24e80aacf71af41475a26c9888d
"}]
commit_message:
Don't indent TC candidate lists

The Sphinx directive '   *' generates a blockquote'd list which isn't
needed for TC elections as we don't need nested lists like we do for PTL
elections.

Switch to a std. ul

Change-Id: I999a2823d421b24e80aacf71af41475a26c9888d

revisions:
[{'created': '2018-04-10 09:11:35.000000000', 'message': "Improve idempotency of block device processing

Resync charms.ceph to pickup improvements in recording
of block devices that have been processed as OSD devices
to support better idempotency of block device processing
codepaths.

This fixes a particularly nasty issue with osd-reformat
is set to True where the charm can wipe and re-prepare
an OSD device prior to the systemd unit actually booting
and mounting the OSD's associated filesystem.

This change also makes the osd-reformat option a boolean
option which is more accessible to users of the charm
via the CLI and the Juju GUI.

Change-Id: I578203aeebf6da2efc21a10d2e157324186e2a66
Depends-On: I2c6e9d5670c8d1d70584ae19b34eaf16be5dea19

commit_message:
Improve idempotency of block device processing

Resync charms.ceph to pickup improvements in recording
of block devices that have been processed as OSD devices
to support better idempotency of block device processing
codepaths.

This fixes a particularly nasty issue with osd-reformat
is set to True where the charm can wipe and re-prepare
an OSD device prior to the systemd unit actually booting
and mounting the OSD's associated filesystem.

This change also makes the osd-reformat option a boolean
option which is more accessible to users of the charm
via the CLI and the Juju GUI.

Change-Id: I578203aeebf6da2efc21a10d2e157324186e2a66
Depends-On: I2c6e9d5670c8d1d70584ae19b34eaf16be5dea19

revisions:
[{'created': '2018-04-06 19:27:25.000000000', 'message': 'tempest: fix test_bgpvpn_port_association_bgpvpn_route

The test as initially written was realizing route leaking
in a way that was not avoiding the leaked routes from being
also imported by the VRF for the intermediate VMs. These
routes competing with direct routes to the ultimate destination
were sometimes (depending on route selection and load balancing)
preventing connectivity.

This change modifies the way leaking is done and the way RTs are
used to avoid this.

Change-Id: I1b9a8bca500eedbe2c42cb8acfc6f37f12a51a5f
Needed-By: I144b01c5870f2b26f15dcd63eb90c2674bd1abc2

commit_message:
tempest: fix test_bgpvpn_port_association_bgpvpn_route

The test as initially written was realizing route leaking
in a way that was not avoiding the leaked routes from being
also imported by the VRF for the intermediate VMs. These
routes competing with direct routes to the ultimate destination
were sometimes (depending on route selection and load balancing)
preventing connectivity.

This change modifies the way leaking is done and the way RTs are
used to avoid this.

Closes-Bug: 1762649
Change-Id: I1b9a8bca500eedbe2c42cb8acfc6f37f12a51a5f

commit_message:
add lower-constraints job

Create a tox environment for running the unit tests against the lower
bounds of the dependencies.

Create a lower-constraints.txt to be used to enforce the lower bounds
in those tests.

Add openstack-tox-lower-constraints job to the zuul configuration.

See http://lists.openstack.org/pipermail/openstack-dev/2018-March/128352.html
for more details.

Change-Id: I425974aa60496e635517e64ab900ec2fa66c0e12
Depends-On: https://review.openstack.org/555034
Signed-off-by: Doug Hellmann <doug@doughellmann.com>

commit_message:
Add roles-data into overcloud upgrade prepare.

The major upgrade command 'overcloud upgrade
prepare needs the roles data to be passed,
as otherwise it will try to obtain the
one from the swift container which is not
updated.

This patchs adds the option of passing it
as role variable, or look for it withing
oooq overcloud-deploy.sh script.

Change-Id: I4ec165742b8667ffa8ee92f572bec7fe74bef1ed

commit_message:
Add nova/ironic/glance cross-service vars to group_vars/all

Given that nova implements a compute service for ironic
it needs access to some of the vars. This moves the vars
out of isolation back into the all space. The same goes
for a glance var which ironic needs.

While this is not ideal, it is the established pattern
and this patch needs to be ported back to Queens.

Change-Id: I2f65a0b26e8d46729959d87ae0dafcdba61c619f

The vhostuser_mode parameter was incorrectly defined as the

VIF port/QEMU mode.  Therefore a value of 'client' will actually

commit_message:
Corrects ODL-OVS vhostusermode default and docs

The vhostuser_mode parameter was incorrectly defined as the
client/server mode of OVS, when actually it is the configuration of the
VIF port/QEMU mode.  Therefore a value of 'client' will actually
configure OVS to be in 'server' mode.  This type of port is deprecated
and the correct value should be 'server' (where QEMU creates the port).

Partial-Bug: 1762473

Change-Id: Idda82cae48b11eae1c79c6bbdd85827e3e43e56b
Signed-off-by: Tim Rozet <trozet@redhat.com>

 > This looks good, but I'd like an answer to whether we need to

I think we should remove it also. element_config.json is the file in  /usr/libexec/os-apply-config/templates/etc/os-net-config/ in pike+queens since https://review.openstack.org/#/c/470014/."}, {'account_id': 12398, 'date': '2018-03-26 20:18:16.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2: Code-Review+2'}, {'account_id': 8449, 'date': '2018-03-27 07:09:13.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 2: Code-Review+2

thanks, I'm not sure if that element_config.json will be re-generated by the os-net-config element https://review.openstack.org/#/c/470014/2/elements/os-net-config/os-refresh-config/configure.d/20-os-net-config assuming we still have that on the overcloud?"}, {'account_id': 21909, 'date': '2018-03-27 16:39:05.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 2:

> thanks, I'm not sure if that element_config.json will be
 > re-generated by the os-net-config element https://review.openstack.org/#/c/470014/2/elements/os-net-config/os-refresh-config/configure.d/20-os-net-config
 > assuming we still have that on the overcloud?

So when we use new style config files, this run-os-net-config.sh script will be used and will use /etc/os-net-config/config.json.  In that case os-apply-config will not need to run and element_config.json will not be needed.  When using old style configs prior to Queens this script will not be invoked so element_config.json will not be removed."}, {'account_id': 12398, 'date': '2018-03-29 18:12:48.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2:

commit_message:
Remove config.json for old style nic config files when using new style

This removes the config.json used by os-apply-config for old style nic
config files in the script invoked for new style nic config files.
This will avoid the case when the network files are set up by
run-os-net-config.sh and then later overwritten by os-apply-config.

Change-Id: I8f17a53c392aac657b00afdecbb5e58a2e192787
Closes-Bug: 1758161

commit_message:
Bug fix: fwaas_v2 was missing in the pip task

Closes-Bug:#1752073

The neutron_optional_fwaas_pip_packages was never used because only
neutron_fwaas was checked. This patch adds neutron_fwaas_v2 to the
list

Change-Id: I45247cd4fe9a54dde6c866e23b1a62a0632467a3
Signed-off-by: Manuel Buil <mbuil@suse.com>
Depends-On: Ifa33e5aedd06e1c0cc44d03354d56de18db46932

commit_message:
Sanitize validations output

Ensure the output module methods call _dump_results() in order to
sanitize validations output.

Change-Id: I5fbb92474d1e3ed19251e615c883f6d889865bab
(cherry picked from commit 81e7fcec29c0101326e9b6d1e2eaf32af218649d)

subject: Create driverfixes/pike branch for Cinder
messages:
[{'account_id': 7198, 'date': '2018-03-09 15:14:47.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 1.'}, {'account_id': 1736, 'date': '2018-03-09 16:08:27.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Code-Review+1'}, {'account_id': 2472, 'date': '2018-03-09 17:58:39.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1: Code-Review-1

As part of the discussion of extended maintenance releases [1] we talked about no longer needing driverfixes branches. Let's give that discussion a chance to play out a bit before we create this branch.

[1] https://review.openstack.org/#/c/548916/"}, {'account_id': 7198, 'date': '2018-03-09 19:45:29.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Workflow-1

Hold this for now as we wait for a decision in the discussion that Doug references.'}, {'account_id': 12898, 'date': '2018-03-13 04:00:08.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

> As part of the discussion of extended maintenance releases [1] we
 > talked about no longer needing driverfixes branches. Let's give
 > that discussion a chance to play out a bit before we create this
 > branch.
 > 
 > [1] https://review.openstack.org/#/c/548916/

I thought driverfixes was still more "open" than 'Phase I' allows which would be the state of the new stable/extended-maintenance policy.'}, {'account_id': 2472, 'date': '2018-03-14 12:52:48.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

> > As part of the discussion of extended maintenance releases [1] we
 > > talked about no longer needing driverfixes branches. Let's give
 > > that discussion a chance to play out a bit before we create this
 > > branch.
 > >
 > > [1] https://review.openstack.org/#/c/548916/
 > 
 > I thought driverfixes was still more "open" than 'Phase I' allows
 > which would be the state of the new stable/extended-maintenance
 > policy.

Maybe? It seems like a potential source of confusion, though, esp. if users need to get most of their software from stable/foo and then a driver from driverfixes/foo.

What sort of fixes do we think might land in a driverfixes branch that we wouldn't take in a stable branch under the new policies?'}, {'account_id': 7198, 'date': '2018-03-14 15:34:35.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1:

I actually agree that having both driverfixes and stable open at the same time is confusing.  driverfixes is actually more restrictive than stable.  In stable we will allow changes to base Cinder code if it meets the backport rules.  Driverfixes we only allow changes to drivers.  So, I don't think we would have a driverfixes branch until after we have decided that stable is restricted to security fixes only."}, {'account_id': 12898, 'date': '2018-03-14 21:11:19.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1:

> I actually agree that having both driverfixes and stable open at
 > the same time is confusing.  driverfixes is actually more
 > restrictive than stable.  In stable we will allow changes to base
 > Cinder code if it meets the backport rules.  Driverfixes we only
 > allow changes to drivers.  So, I don't think we would have a
 > driverfixes branch until after we have decided that stable is
 > restricted to security fixes only.

But are all the changes on a driversfixes branch required to be cherry-pick from master->$series?  I thought when we discussed this in Barcelona there was additional flexibility there?

And do all changes on driverfixes meet: https://docs.openstack.org/project-team-guide/stable-branches.html#appropriate-fixes  again I thought the driverfixes branch was a little more relaxed on those criteria?


I agree that having 2 branches will add to confusion and if they're compatible then we can certainly drop (well not create) the driverfixes branch"}, {'account_id': 7198, 'date': '2018-03-15 14:06:28.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

For Cinder the proposed changes need to be in master and any stable branches that are still open as well as any of the driverfixes branches that are open.  So, yes it still need to meet the acceptable backport criteria.  No new features, etc.

So, right now, if I wanted a change in driverfixes/newton it would need to be in master and then cherry-picked to stable/queens, stable/pike and driverfixes/ocata first.'}, {'account_id': 12898, 'date': '2018-03-28 23:39:55.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

> For Cinder the proposed changes need to be in master and any stable
 > branches that are still open as well as any of the driverfixes
 > branches that are open.  So, yes it still need to meet the
 > acceptable backport criteria.  No new features, etc.
 > 
 > So, right now, if I wanted a change in driverfixes/newton it would
 > need to be in master and then cherry-picked to stable/queens,
 > stable/pike and driverfixes/ocata first.

Okay well given that and the fact that the Extended Maintenance stuff is settling in I think we can abandon this and just use the stable/* branches for ocata and beyond.'}, {'account_id': 2472, 'date': '2018-04-10 12:59:44.000000000', 'content': 'Abandoned

Since we seem to agree that we will just use the EM stable branches for these patches now, I am abandoning this patch to remove it from the review dashboard. Please restore it if you feel this is a mistake.'}]

Create driverfixes/pike branch for Cinder

pike.

Change-Id: Id8bf1781ed1ed97586d20f18877bf86905e3e811

ternary, the condition must be inside parenthesis

commit_message:
Bug fix: Parenthesis needed when using ternary

neutron_fwaas and neutron_fwaas_v2 where always false. When using
ternary, the condition must be inside parenthesis

Change-Id: Ifa33e5aedd06e1c0cc44d03354d56de18db46932

commit_message:
masquerade-networks: update defaults

Update the defaults in environments/services/masquerade-networks.yaml
so it'll configure correct IPtables rules to allow overcloud nodes in
OVB jobs to reach external network (via 10.0.0.0/24).

Change-Id: I58c846ebe22b7bfd9115963250305be95f2503cb

[{'created': '2018-03-30 15:59:23.000000000', 'message': 'Revert "FFU: Add support for panko service upgrade"

This reverts commit bd48087520c5f0846363bdc0c025508ba450ceb3.

After further inspection It seems that panko dbsync shouldn't be needed, as it will upgrade an newly empty db.  

And this is assuming we have a way to:
 - configure panko database connection properly
 - create the db

So all that to upgrade a newly (I guess empty) database seems like too much trouble.

The db will be created in the last step of the FFU. 

Change-Id: Ie68849a7033c199c339d28cdb10c3dba9419904b
Related-Bug: #1760135

commit_message:
Revert "FFU: Add support for panko service upgrade"

This reverts commit bd48087520c5f0846363bdc0c025508ba450ceb3.

After further inspection It seems that panko dbsync shouldn't be
needed, as it will upgrade an newly created empty db.

And this is assuming we find a way to:
 - configure panko database connection properly
 - create the db

Knowing that we don't have access to this information[1] as the
new hieradata haven't been rendered at this stage.

So all that to upgrade a newly (I guess empty) database seems like too
much trouble.

The db will be created in the last step of the FFU.

[1] https://github.com/openstack/tripleo-heat-templates/blob/stable/ocata/puppet/services/panko-base.yaml#L39..L75

Change-Id: Ie68849a7033c199c339d28cdb10c3dba9419904b
Closes-Bug: #1760135
(cherry picked from commit f3d340fea7f484b893d880b7ee6c876a5c219089)

commit_message:
[Grafana] Add openstack-tox-lower-constraints to neutron dashboard

Patch [1] added openstack-tox-lower-constraints job to Neutron's
gate and check queues.
This patch adds results of this job to Neutron failure rates grafana
dashboard.

[1] https://review.openstack.org/#/c/555939/

Change-Id: Ib5985d35c6f33cf93b163f73965ee992fffe0a66

revisions:
[{'created': '2018-04-09 12:51:30.000000000', 'message': 'Ensure package cache is updated appropriately

When the repo container is removed, the apt cache config
is still in place and causes problems. This is due to the
tasks running to remove the cache configuration not
executing early enough in the deployment.

This patch re-orders the tasks so that the removal can
be done and the cache is updated afterwards to confirm
a working state.

It also makes the configuration happen on all hosts, then
all containers, at the right timings to ensure that if the
container is removed, the proxy config will also be removed
automatically.

Conflicts:
- playbooks/containers-nspawn-create.yml

Change-Id: I0d1bf9617594d9a5c7c2ea3335c80cc2478df985
(cherry picked from commit 1d731cdd89b660983e5c55e7798dee21557e8fbd)
'}]
commit_message:
Ensure package cache is updated appropriately

When the repo container is removed, the apt cache config
is still in place and causes problems. This is due to the
tasks running to remove the cache configuration not
executing early enough in the deployment.

This patch re-orders the tasks so that the removal can
be done and the cache is updated afterwards to confirm
a working state.

It also makes the configuration happen on all hosts, then
all containers, at the right timings to ensure that if the
container is removed, the proxy config will also be removed
automatically.

Conflicts:
- playbooks/containers-nspawn-create.yml

Change-Id: I0d1bf9617594d9a5c7c2ea3335c80cc2478df985
(cherry picked from commit 1d731cdd89b660983e5c55e7798dee21557e8fbd)

OK, sure.'}, {'account_id': 6469, 'date': '2018-03-12 17:17:55.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 13.'}, {'account_id': 11628, 'date': '2018-03-12 17:46:01.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 13: Code-Review-1

I have two issues with this.
1. I don't think we should have a gate against Octavia that is testing OVSFW. This is a bug and compatibility issue in OVSFW and not Octavia, so this gate should be running against OVSFW patches (neutron?) and not Octavia.
2. We should not be adding new gates with "legacy", those were jobs migrated from zuulv2. This should be a implemented as a native gate.'}, {'account_id': 10273, 'date': '2018-03-12 18:01:03.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 13:

Yeah I guess I agree, though you can continue to use this CR to test your depends-on change and verify if it fixes the issue, without actually merging this. Not honestly sure if this one bug requires a whole gate test in the ovsfw repo...'}, {'account_id': 14885, 'date': '2018-03-12 18:48:02.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 13:

Hi Michael,

Just two comments to yours ;)
1) Adding an experimental gate is quite cheap, so this won't be triggered unless being explicit
2) Carlos mentioned that he planned to migrate to native syntax in a follow-up patch.

wdyt?"}, {'account_id': 6469, 'date': '2018-03-12 19:39:58.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 14: Commit message was updated.'}, {'account_id': 6469, 'date': '2018-03-12 19:43:28.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 14: Workflow-1

Michael and I have discussed and agreed on IRC now to keep this patch open and trigger a check experimental until the Depends-On patch gets merged. The Neutron patch should be validated elsewhere not in Octavia. This patch was a good exercise to verify the Neutron patch, which works as-is now :)'}, {'account_id': 11628, 'date': '2018-03-12 19:47:14.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 14:

Daniel,
Yeah, it's experimental, but doesn't do any good testing OVSFW patches here in the Octavia gates. It should be experimental or non-voting in the OVSFW gates to test patches there.
Leaving here means they have to merge a patch or continually update the depends-on to test their patches."}, {'account_id': 6469, 'date': '2018-04-10 12:51:39.000000000', 'content': 'Abandoned'}]

commit_message:
ceph-volume: Add missing pkgs

Ensure lvm2 and parted packages are installed to support
use of ceph-volume for luminous or later releases.

Change-Id: I4a258c856b0070b07b4bb3003e45a7611bc64fba

This patch adds a function that does the following :
1. create two pods 

2. create service of type LoadBalancer (that will include pods from step 1)

3. wait for LB to be fully provisioned in Openstack (status/ingress/loadbalancer/ip)

4. curl service's IP


I assume that you"ll add more tests that check services functionality, so you"ll can re-use parts of this codes.

I would suggest splitting the common part into common functions for that reason.

saying that, I'm fine if you"ll decide split this function only when introducing the other service tests'}, {'account_id': 21041, 'date': '2018-03-25 11:32:42.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 10: Code-Review-1

Testing service creation and connectivity

Creating functions to create delete and get ip from the service
Updating creation of pod to have a label
Testing connectivity to the service

commit_message:
Allow for single tempest image upload

If 'tempest_images' has been overridden to only contain a single image,
setting a fact for a secondary image will fail since it always expects
'tempest_image_create' to contain two elements. Instead, set the
'tempest_glance_image_id_2' fact as the last element.

Change-Id: If4bbd73f70bfb59695bb7d5f167ed6555e6de16a

revisions:
[{'created': '2018-04-06 05:40:09.000000000', 'message': 'Set ulimit for neutron agent containers

Neutron agents are using oslo-rootwrap-daemon to run
privileged commands. Containers inherit file descriptor
limit from docker daemon(currently:1048576) which is too
high and leading to performance issues. This patch set
nofile limit for neutron agent containers to 1024 which is
reasonable as before containers they were using host defaults
i.e 1024.

Depends-On: I0cfcf4e3e3e13578ec42e12f459732992fb3a760
Change-Id: Iec722cdfd7642ff3149f50d940d8079b9e1b7147
Related-Bug: #1760471

Neutron agents are using oslo-rootwrap-daemon to run
privileged commands. Containers inherit file descriptor
limit from docker daemon(currently:1048576) which is too

nofile limit for neutron agent containers to 1024 which is
reasonable as before containers they were using host defaults
i.e 1024.

Depends-On: I0cfcf4e3e3e13578ec42e12f459732992fb3a760

commit_message:
Set ulimit for neutron agent containers

Neutron agents are using oslo-rootwrap-daemon to run
privileged commands. Containers inherit file descriptor
limit from docker daemon(currently:1048576) which is too
high and leading to performance issues. This patch set
nofile limit for neutron agent containers to 1024 which is
reasonable as before containers they were using host defaults
i.e 1024.

Depends-On: I0cfcf4e3e3e13578ec42e12f459732992fb3a760
Change-Id: Iec722cdfd7642ff3149f50d940d8079b9e1b7147
Related-Bug: #1760471

commit_message:
Ensure to show security groups only from current project

Previously when logging in as a user with admin role,
if we visit "Edit Security Group" action of the instance table,
security groups from all projects are listed.

Change-Id: I71ff940434ef8dc146e934dc833c4d26829930c0
Closes-Bug: #1750140

commit_message:
Fix osa_toolkit dictutils import

Currently the inventory-manage tooling does
not work correctly because it cannot find the
dictutils/filesystem libraries in its path.

Change-Id: I6055df3da794439fb65ad2244445135dafb1cecf

commit_message:
luminous: ceph-volume switch

Switch to using ceph-volume + LVM for managing block devices
for Luminous and later; this is the upstream preferred approach
to managing OSD devices, allowing for more flexibility in terms
of use of crypto and logical volumes.

Change-Id: I30c4d29e6f568ac2e30a45b1a7bc0e68685c3707
Depends-On: I1675b67d364ae6042129a8a717d4bdffff5bde92

Add neutron_tempest_plugin to tempest dependencies

This is required for the bgp tests to succeed.
Without it, tests fail as follows:
Failed to import test module: neutron_dynamic_routing.tests.tempest.api.test_bgp_speaker_extensions
Traceback (most recent call last):
  File "/usr/local/lib/python2.7/dist-packages/unittest2/loader.py", line 456, in _find_test_path
    module = self._get_module_from_name(name)
  File "/usr/local/lib/python2.7/dist-packages/unittest2/loader.py", line 395, in _get_module_from_name
    __import__(name)
  File "/opt/stack/new/neutron-dynamic-routing/neutron_dynamic_routing/tests/tempest/api/test_bgp_speaker_extensions.py", line 21, in <module>
    from neutron_tempest_plugin.api import base
ImportError: No module named neutron_tempest_plugin.api

Resolves-Bug: #1762176
Change-Id: I1d15fe4b1aa43cbb40c85ba448702e3f72052573

subject: Improve idempotency of block device processing
messages: [{'account_id': 935, 'date': '2018-04-10 09:01:57.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 1.'}, {'account_id': 20634, 'date': '2018-04-10 11:57:10.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Workflow+1 Code-Review+2'}]
revisions:
[{'created': '2018-04-10 09:01:57.000000000', 'message': 'Improve idempotency of block device processing

Record details of each device that is successfully processed as
an OSD data device to ensure that they are not re-processed
during subsequent hook executions.

"successfully processed" in this case means that the call to
either ceph-disk or ceph-volume to prepare (and potentially
activate) the OSD completed without error.

This avoids potential data loss on reboot when osd-reformat is
set to True as the charm will only every process a block device
once.

Change-Id: I2c6e9d5670c8d1d70584ae19b34eaf16be5dea19
'}]
commit_message:
Improve idempotency of block device processing

Record details of each device that is successfully processed as
an OSD data device to ensure that they are not re-processed
during subsequent hook executions.

"successfully processed" in this case means that the call to
either ceph-disk or ceph-volume to prepare (and potentially
activate) the OSD completed without error.

This avoids potential data loss on reboot when osd-reformat is
set to True as the charm will only every process a block device
once.

Change-Id: I2c6e9d5670c8d1d70584ae19b34eaf16be5dea19

commit_message:
Defend against neutron error response missing keys

I *have* seen this in the wild (it caused problems in our cloud with
Liberty neutron), and while I am unsure of the exact cause, it can't
hurt to code a little bit defensively!

Change-Id: I46ec944f7035fd7a5a09b7e7e4a4a38692039ab7

(2 comments)

Will this be part of Swift - or completely independent?'}, {'account_id': 330, 'date': '2018-03-14 21:43:39.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 2:

As discussed with the swift community, both at the ptg and in our weekly meeting, we want to see slogging separate for matters of governance (patch merging, releases, etc) but we'd love to have slogging updates go to the #openstack-swift channel. We're happy to consolidate day-to-day dev activity into one IRC channel.

Personally, as the current owner of the slogging codebase, I think it's great that Kei-ichi-san is taking over development of the project and enhancing it."}, {'account_id': 25936, 'date': '2018-04-06 04:08:06.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 3.'}, {'account_id': 25936, 'date': '2018-04-06 04:09:48.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 3:

Add slogging projects

Current slogging is managed in Swift PTLs GitHub.
Ive discussed in Dublin PTG and decide migrate
this repository as one of OpenStack project.

messages: [{'account_id': 17280, 'date': '2018-04-09 16:46:34.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 1.'}, {'account_id': 7144, 'date': '2018-04-09 18:07:17.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Code-Review+2'}, {'account_id': 14985, 'date': '2018-04-09 20:01:44.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Workflow+1 Code-Review+2'}, {'account_id': 20866, 'date': '2018-04-10 00:52:17.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Code-Review+1'}, {'account_id': 18575, 'date': '2018-04-10 11:03:49.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Cherry Picked\n\nThis patchset was cherry picked to branch stable/queens as commit c80ce856476d56d36f643c415c049fccdf498762'}]
revisions:
[{'created': '2018-04-09 16:46:34.000000000', 'message': "Fixes the OvsVhostuserMode heat parameter

The mode was incorrectly defined as configuring the mode for OVS when it
is really configuring the client/server mode for QEMU.  A value of
'client' here will cause OVS to create the  vhostuser socket, and
actually make OVS the server.  This type of port is deprecated so the
default should be 'server' (QEMU creates the port).

Closes-Bug: 1762473

Change-Id: I7cd34b30f54766fe35e4a40a57b278166d0197cb
Signed-off-by: Tim Rozet <trozet@redhat.com>
"}]
commit_message:
Fixes the OvsVhostuserMode heat parameter

The mode was incorrectly defined as configuring the mode for OVS when it
is really configuring the client/server mode for QEMU.  A value of
'client' here will cause OVS to create the  vhostuser socket, and
actually make OVS the server.  This type of port is deprecated so the
default should be 'server' (QEMU creates the port).

Closes-Bug: 1762473

Change-Id: I7cd34b30f54766fe35e4a40a57b278166d0197cb
Signed-off-by: Tim Rozet <trozet@redhat.com>

commit_message:
VNC harcoded server name removed

  VNC server can be other than WebSockify, so there is a need to
  configure it once in a while for various deployments

    - added config option
    - updated test

Change-Id: I938bae347eaa9fcf76e4118188b325ba6d3efa77
Closes-Bug: #1748339

(1 comment)

In my understanding, you are trying to keep a boot source already selected when switching a boot source.

However, in my testing, it seems not to work expectedly.

What I did are:
- Open AngularJS launch instance form
- Go to "Source" tab
- Select "cirros-0.3.5-x86_64-disk" as boot source image
- Switch the boot source to "Image Snapshot"
- Switch the boot source back to "Image"
- No image is selected. I think you expect "cirros-0.3.5-x86_64-disk" (I selected above) is selected.

Could you check?'}, {'account_id': 1736, 'date': '2018-03-16 11:33:14.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2: -Code-Review'}, {'account_id': 14676, 'date': '2018-04-10 10:02:38.000000000', 'content': 'Abandoned

seems issues was fixed by another patch somehow.'}]

commit_message:
Do not update boot source on selection

This fix Iaa2e37bae02c9ce5ab654ac8a3327c0834e7b49e
introduced inconsistent behavior:
Once we have an image selecete d we rewrite it with boot source default.
We must not update boot source if selection has already provided
(we laucnhed form from volume or image)

commit_message:
Dont use local connection for kibana post config

We should not assume the VIP is accessible from the deploy node.

Change-Id: I39640f98b4adddb9cb8dfdd09d9fb7ecba15a820
Closes-Bug: #1730651

commit_message:
Force ANSIBLE_CALLBACK_WHITELIST to empty list for collect_nodes_uuid

The collect_nodes_uuid parses ansible json output which might contain
spurious lines if additional output callbacks are enabled. This change
explicitly sets the callback whitelist to empty string before
lauching ansible-playbook to ensure only the json plugin is loaded.

Change-Id: Ic133f99988fcc4f6e20ef327b6f2e753c3fff394
Closes-Bug: 1755539

subject: Fix nc syntax in guides/devstack-with-lbaas-v2.rst
reviewers: [{'_account_id': 10385, 'name': 'Citrix XenServer CI', 'username': 'citrix_xenserver_ci', 'tags': ['SERVICE_USER']}, {'_account_id': 13252, 'name': 'Dr. Jens Harbott', 'display_name': 'Dr. Jens Harbott (frickler)', 'email': 'frickler@offenerstapel.de', 'username': 'jrosenboom'}, {'_account_id': 14595, 'name': 'z Systems KVM', 'email': 'zkvm-ci@linux.vnet.ibm.com', 'username': 'ibm-zkvm-ci', 'tags': ['SERVICE_USER']}, {'_account_id': 16376, 'name': 'Intel NFV CI', 'email': 'openstack-nfv-ci@intel.com', 'username': 'intel-nfv-ci', 'tags': ['SERVICE_USER']}, {'_account_id': 22348, 'name': 'Zuul', 'username': 'zuul', 'tags': ['SERVICE_USER']}, {'_account_id': 23913, 'name': 'David Rabel', 'email': 'rabel@b1-systems.de', 'username': 'rabel'}]
messages:
[{'account_id': 23913, 'date': '2018-04-09 11:27:38.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 1.'}, {'account_id': 13252, 'date': '2018-04-10 08:52:02.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1: Code-Review-1

Actually, the syntax is not wrong per se, there are two different versions of netcat with different options. Since in this case the example seems to be made explicitly for cirros, the current version seems to be correct:

$ cat /etc/cirros/version                                                                                                                                                                                                                     
0.3.5                                                                                                                                                                                                                                         
$ nc                                                                                                                                                                                                                                          
BusyBox v1.20.1 (2017-02-09 03:07:02 UTC) multi-call binary.                                                                                                                                                                                  

Usage: nc [OPTIONS] HOST PORT  - connect
nc [OPTIONS] -l -p PORT [HOST] [PORT]  - listen

        -e PROG Run PROG after connect (must be last)
        -l      Listen mode, for inbound connects
        -lk     With -e, provides persistent server
        -p PORT Local port
        -s ADDR Local address
        -w SEC  Timeout for connects and final net reads
        -i SEC  Delay interval for lines sent
        -n      Don't do DNS resolution
        -u      UDP mode
        -v      Verbose
        -o FILE Hex dump traffic
        -z      Zero-I/O mode (scanning)

$ sudo nc -l 80
nc: bad address '80'
$ sudo nc -l -p 80

... works"}, {'account_id': 23913, 'date': '2018-04-10 09:04:17.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1:

You're right. My fault!"}, {'account_id': 23913, 'date': '2018-04-10 09:04:25.000000000', 'content': 'Abandoned'}]
revisions:
[{'created': '2018-04-09 11:27:38.000000000', 'message': "Fix nc syntax in guides/devstack-with-lbaas-v2.rst

nc -l does not require an additional -p. It's actually
wrong syntax.

Change-Id: I240f10304e3e875e6fe3f48f3ff13161600abb77
Source: https://linux.die.net/man/1/nc
"}]
commit_message:
Fix nc syntax in guides/devstack-with-lbaas-v2.rst

nc -l does not require an additional -p. It's actually
wrong syntax.

Change-Id: I240f10304e3e875e6fe3f48f3ff13161600abb77
Source: https://linux.die.net/man/1/nc

commit_message:
Perform multiple container image prepares and merge result

Given the full heat environment and roles data, perform multiple image
prepare operations. The data to drive the multiple prepares is taken
from the ContainerImagePrepare parameter in the provided environment.
If push_destination is specified, uploads will be performed during the
preparation.

This will be used by undercloud install and workflow driven image
prepare

Change-Id: Ife6b6eb753272e3b074cf14669642af140986fc4
Blueprint: container-prepare-workflow

[{'account_id': 27329, 'date': '2018-03-21 14:52:42.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 1.'}, {'account_id': 10068, 'date': '2018-03-21 14:53:11.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1:

Thank you for your first contribution to OpenStack.

    Your patch will now be tested automatically by OpenStack testing frameworks
    and once the automatic tests pass, it will be reviewed by other friendly
    developers. They will give you feedback and may require you to refine it.

    People seldom get their patch approved on the first try, so don't be
    concerned if requested to make corrections. Feel free to modify your patch
    and resubmit a new change-set.

    Patches usually take 3 to 7 days to be reviewed so be patient and be
    available on IRC to ask and answer questions about your work. Also it
    takes generally at least a couple of weeks for cores to get around to
    reviewing code. The more you participate in the community the more
    rewarding it is for you. You may also notice that the more you get to know
    people and get to be known, the faster your patches will be reviewed and
    eventually approved. Get to know others and become known by doing code
    reviews: anybody can do it, and it's a great way to learn the code base.

    Thanks again for supporting OpenStack, we look forward to working with you.

    IRC: https://wiki.openstack.org/wiki/IRC
    Workflow: http://docs.openstack.org/infra/manual/developers.html
    Commit Messages: https://wiki.openstack.org/wiki/GitCommitMessages"}, {'account_id': 27329, 'date': '2018-03-21 14:56:04.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 2: Commit message was updated.'}, {'account_id': 27329, 'date': '2018-03-21 15:25:29.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 3: Commit message was updated.'}, {'account_id': 27329, 'date': '2018-03-21 15:30:43.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 4: Commit message was updated.'}, {'account_id': 27329, 'date': '2018-03-21 15:35:21.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 5: Commit message was updated.'}, {'account_id': 10459, 'date': '2018-03-21 16:13:36.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 5:

I can't commit too much on the content, but you don't need to add Closes-Bug: #1594868, because it is already closed as duplicate (even if the launchpad interface is not exactly clear)."}, {'account_id': 27329, 'date': '2018-03-22 08:28:41.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 5:

Bugs #1556864 and #1594868 wasn't actually fixed as environment variables http_proxy and https_proxy are not taken in a account when making HTTP requests."}, {'account_id': 10459, 'date': '2018-03-22 08:38:19.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 5:

If you think that it's not a duplicate, please unduplicate it first. I'm not sure we should support the environment variables, too. I actually feel the environment variables are sometimes problematic like the following situation.

   A tempest user who needs an http_proxy/https_proxy to access the internet. But he doesn't need his OpenStack cloud.

This is not a strong opinion. I think we have a workaround for this situation with unsetting the variables when we run it.

So, for my main -1 reason is that I think a reno is necessary at least."}, {'account_id': 27329, 'date': '2018-04-05 10:51:11.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 35:

What a 'reno' is?"}, {'account_id': 10459, 'date': '2018-04-05 11:03:55.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 35:

Release notes: https://docs.openstack.org/reno/latest/user/usage.html'}, {'account_id': 27329, 'date': '2018-04-05 12:27:20.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 36.'}, {'account_id': 27329, 'date': '2018-04-05 13:07:09.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 35: Workflow-1

I take out from this change the code that fixes the fixes for proxy_url support (without env variables):

https://review.openstack.org/#/c/559069/

This change has to be rebased on top of that one.'}, {'account_id': 27329, 'date': '2018-04-05 13:40:41.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 36: Workflow-1'}, {'account_id': 27329, 'date': '2018-04-10 08:49:30.000000000', 'content': 'Abandoned

This change has been split and reduced to below one:
https://review.openstack.org/#/c/559069/'}]

[{'created': '2018-03-21 14:52:42.000000000', 'message': 'Take proxy URL from http(s)_proxy or HTTP(S)_PROXY env variables when no proxy is given.

Closes-Bug: 1594868
Change-Id: I32ec6c329446bf04994b39740b7e70dd2255b885
'}, {'created': '2018-03-21 14:56:04.000000000', 'message': 'Take proxy URL from http(s)_proxy or HTTP(S)_PROXY env variables

When no proxy_url is given on tempest configuration file then
the URL it is taken from environment variables.

When ClosingHttp class instance is created and a proxy URL is
detected from environmen variables then it creates ClosingProxyHttp
class instead.

Closes-Bug: 1594868
Change-Id: I32ec6c329446bf04994b39740b7e70dd2255b885

commit_message:
Take proxy URL from http(s)_proxy or HTTP(S)_PROXY env variables

When no proxy_url is given via tempest configuration then
the URL is taken from standard environment variables.

When ClosingHttp class instance is being created and a proxy URL
is found in standard environment variables then it creates
ClosingProxyHttp class instead.

Closes-Bug: #1556864
Change-Id: I32ec6c329446bf04994b39740b7e70dd2255b885

Updated pep8 checks

* set the maximum line length to 100
* removed unnecessary ignores

* added apache 2.0 license for missed files

messages:
[{'account_id': 28062, 'date': '2018-04-05 11:17:58.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 1.'}, {'account_id': 10068, 'date': '2018-04-05 11:18:10.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1:

Thank you for your first contribution to OpenStack.

    Your patch will now be tested automatically by OpenStack testing frameworks
    and once the automatic tests pass, it will be reviewed by other friendly
    developers. They will give you feedback and may require you to refine it.

    People seldom get their patch approved on the first try, so don't be
    concerned if requested to make corrections. Feel free to modify your patch
    and resubmit a new change-set.

    Patches usually take 3 to 7 days to be reviewed so be patient and be
    available on IRC to ask and answer questions about your work. Also it
    takes generally at least a couple of weeks for cores to get around to
    reviewing code. The more you participate in the community the more
    rewarding it is for you. You may also notice that the more you get to know
    people and get to be known, the faster your patches will be reviewed and
    eventually approved. Get to know others and become known by doing code
    reviews: anybody can do it, and it's a great way to learn the code base.

    Thanks again for supporting OpenStack, we look forward to working with you.

    IRC: https://wiki.openstack.org/wiki/IRC
    Workflow: http://docs.openstack.org/infra/manual/developers.html
    Commit Messages: https://wiki.openstack.org/wiki/GitCommitMessages"}, {'account_id': 26141, 'date': '2018-04-05 11:23:39.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Code-Review+1'}, {'account_id': 16171, 'date': '2018-04-05 12:23:05.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1: Code-Review+1

commit_message:
devstack: add kubelet iface to openshift nodes

OpenShift container probes in baremetal deployments are also necessary
as well as enabling routing to the service network for the OpenShift API
to be reachable by host networking pods.

Closes-Bug: 1757993
Closes-Bug: 1762166
Change-Id: I73ab7d4ad660cb109ad3469c9a0ea0de35be8179
Signed-off-by: Antoni Segura Puimedon <antonisp@celebdor.com>
(cherry picked from commit f4e9e3019861b392eb8bccf68080fd02ee7ea48b)

revisions:
[{'created': '2018-04-08 12:00:29.000000000', 'message': "devstack: Make service subnet routable

We currently have a pod subnet ovs internal port created in devstack.
This allows the kubelet to do the necessary container probes. The
problem is that if we run host networking pods that need to access the
API they won't be able to do it in the expected way (sending HTTP
requests to the clusterIP of the API).

This patch addresses it via routing, so the kubelet iface is used for
the service access.

Closes-Bug: 1743081
Change-Id: I899c925610b69affc5a43bc6ba8ecb8fdee67e90
Signed-off-by: Antoni Segura Puimedon <antonisp@celebdor.com>
(cherry picked from commit 5bfcc756956eb4e1709255f277c2d71e27f82df8)
"}]
commit_message:
devstack: Make service subnet routable

We currently have a pod subnet ovs internal port created in devstack.
This allows the kubelet to do the necessary container probes. The
problem is that if we run host networking pods that need to access the
API they won't be able to do it in the expected way (sending HTTP
requests to the clusterIP of the API).

This patch addresses it via routing, so the kubelet iface is used for
the service access.

Closes-Bug: 1743081
Change-Id: I899c925610b69affc5a43bc6ba8ecb8fdee67e90
Signed-off-by: Antoni Segura Puimedon <antonisp@celebdor.com>
(cherry picked from commit 5bfcc756956eb4e1709255f277c2d71e27f82df8)

commit_message:
Clean up ping list

There are a number of people who are no longer active on OpenStack
and/or Oslo that are still being courtesy pinged for meetings.
Let's stop doing that.

This is probably not a complete cleanup, but it's a step in the
right direction.

Change-Id: I719b4ad605b52005394f823650230b906e7dbd13

commit_message:
Re-attach configuration after resize flavor

When I resize instance,it call function "save_configuration" in guest_agent at last.
Save_configuration removes some configurations whitch were configured before,
and doesn't recover them.Than, the replica doesn't work.
This patch try to configure as before after new instance's datastore
takes effect.

Closes-Bug: #1654673
Change-Id: Ibf18658872a09ba5a63416ce3370e1c75233a4a3

messages:
[{'account_id': 15343, 'date': '2018-03-26 22:02:17.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 1.'}, {'account_id': 2622, 'date': '2018-03-26 22:04:14.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Code-Review+2'}, {'account_id': 15343, 'date': '2018-03-27 00:09:36.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

(1 comment)'}, {'account_id': 7233, 'date': '2018-04-10 06:47:26.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Workflow+1 Code-Review+2

Nice, always good to comply with rfcs :)'}]
revisions:
[{'created': '2018-03-26 22:02:17.000000000', 'message': 'swob.Match: Optional whitespace is optional

https://tools.ietf.org/html/rfc7232#section-3 defines the form for
If-Match and If-None-Match as

    If-Match = "*" / 1#entity-tag
    If-None-Match = "*" / 1#entity-tag

https://tools.ietf.org/html/rfc7230#section-7 in turn defines the
1#<type> syntax as

    1#element => element *( OWS "," OWS element )

where OWS is *optional* whitespace. Our swob.Match object should respect
that optionality.

Change-Id: I6ee1c6674e0e9c156149319022fd289504bd3722
'}]
commit_message:
swob.Match: Optional whitespace is optional

https://tools.ietf.org/html/rfc7232#section-3 defines the form for
If-Match and If-None-Match as

    If-Match = "*" / 1#entity-tag
    If-None-Match = "*" / 1#entity-tag

https://tools.ietf.org/html/rfc7230#section-7 in turn defines the
1#<type> syntax as

    1#element => element *( OWS "," OWS element )

where OWS is *optional* whitespace. Our swob.Match object should respect
that optionality.

Change-Id: I6ee1c6674e0e9c156149319022fd289504bd3722

messages:
[{'account_id': 21420, 'date': '2018-03-23 21:13:44.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 1.'}, {'account_id': 2472, 'date': '2018-03-23 21:25:55.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

Is the point of contact for security issues documented somewhere? I see https://launchpad.net/~keystone-coresec is that the group?'}, {'account_id': 5046, 'date': '2018-03-23 21:32:26.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1:

> Is the point of contact for security issues documented somewhere? I
 > see https://launchpad.net/~keystone-coresec is that the group?

Good question. Since Gage has stepped up and taken point on a lot of the security work we've been pushing, I've added him as a member of keystone-coresec."}, {'account_id': 2472, 'date': '2018-03-23 21:37:47.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1:

> > Is the point of contact for security issues documented somewhere?
 > I
 > > see https://launchpad.net/~keystone-coresec is that the group?
 > 
 > Good question. Since Gage has stepped up and taken point on a lot
 > of the security work we've been pushing, I've added him as a member
 > of keystone-coresec.

OK. And that group name appears in documentation somewhere? I had to guess the name based on the tag definition and the fact that keystonemiddleware-coresec does not exist."}, {'account_id': 17893, 'date': '2018-03-26 16:05:14.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Code-Review+1'}, {'account_id': 308, 'date': '2018-03-27 08:37:18.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

We need VMT review on this one'}, {'account_id': 5263, 'date': '2018-04-03 14:15:51.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1:

Doug Hellmann wrote:

> OK. And that group name appears in documentation somewhere? I had to
> guess the name based on the tag definition and the fact that
> keystonemiddleware-coresec does not exist.

Convention has been (so far) that there is one security review group covering all vulnerability:managed deliverables for a given project team, and so they have traditionally been named <projectteam>-coresec. It wouldn't hurt to create an actual registry of these in the openstack/ossa repository for clarity, but since we only rely on those as the initial set of subscribers after triage by the VMT and we are fairly familiar with the (presently small) set of teams involved, figuring out which one we should use hasn't yet been an issue in practice."}, {'account_id': 5263, 'date': '2018-04-03 14:21:28.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1:

Lance Bragstad wrote:

> Since Gage has stepped up and taken point on a lot of
> the security work we've been pushing, I've added him as a member of
> keystone-coresec.

Thanks! As he's the vulnerability management liaison listed at https://wiki.openstack.org/wiki/CrossProjectLiaisons#Vulnerability_management it's good that he's included in the corresponding core security review group. Otherwise our escalation process documented at https://security.openstack.org/vmt-process.html#patch-development would get sort of weird. Perhaps it's worth updating https://governance.openstack.org/tc/reference/tags/vulnerability_managed.html#requirements item #3 to indicate that the liaison should be included in the security issue point of contact team described in #2."}, {'account_id': 5263, 'date': '2018-04-05 17:48:05.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1: Rollcall-Vote+1 Code-Review+1

Now that the security analysis mentioned in the commit message has merged, I'm voting in favor of this under two hats (VMT and TC). I'll take a todo for proposing the couple of minor amendments to the vulnerability:managed tag I noted in my earlier review comments."}, {'account_id': 308, 'date': '2018-04-06 07:36:06.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Rollcall-Vote+1'}, {'account_id': 9311, 'date': '2018-04-06 09:45:42.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Code-Review+1'}, {'account_id': 2472, 'date': '2018-04-06 11:30:04.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Rollcall-Vote+1'}, {'account_id': 308, 'date': '2018-04-10 08:01:12.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Workflow+1'}]
