subject: Separate the TC and PTL elections
revisions:
[{'created': '2018-04-09 07:06:34.000000000', 'message': 'Separate the TC and PTL elections

Currently even if we have closed an election when we build the docs we
still determine the full name, email address and IRC nick for all
candidates for a series (i.e both PTL and TC candidates for Rocky while
only running the rocky TC election)

Stop doing that.  This means that we reduce the REST-API hits during doc
builds, generally speed up the docs generation and importantly allow us
to change the process from looking this up from git to probing the
OpenStack Foundation membership DB.

Adding a flag to state the election type (or phase) will also allow us
to, in future changes, auto-validate candidates and generally streamline
the process.

NOTE: This change also forces all calls to filter() to be "listified" to
work the same under py2 and py3

As you can see from the results below, before we were looking up PTL data
from git, which this change stops.  After this change the expected git
queries still happen:

Before:
[tony@thor election]$ time strace -fo ./strace -s200 tox -e docs
<SNIP>
___________________________________ summary ____________________________________
  docs: commands succeeded
  congratulations :)

real	1m21.627s
user	0m16.268s
sys	0m9.921s
[tony@thor election]$ grep -Erin '/usr/bin/git.*--follow' strace | wc -l
125
[tony@thor election]$ grep -Erin '/usr/bin/git.*--follow' strace | head -n1
395670:6892  execve("/usr/bin/git", ["git", "log", "--follow", "--format=%aE", "candidates/rocky/Barbican/alee.txt"], 0x56333426b590 /* 8 vars */ <unfinished ...>
After (PTL)
[tony@thor election]$ time strace -fo ./strace -s200 tox -e docs
<SNIP>
___________________________________ summary ____________________________________
  docs: commands succeeded
  congratulations :)

real	1m23.211s
user	0m17.283s
sys	0m10.573s
[tony@thor election]$ grep -Erin '/usr/bin/git.*--follow' strace | wc -l
125
After (TC / no TC candidates)
[tony@thor election]$ time strace -fo ./strace -s200 tox -e docs
<SNIP>
___________________________________ summary ____________________________________
  docs: commands succeeded
  congratulations :)

real	0m35.943s
user	0m9.443s
sys	0m5.897s
[tony@thor election]$ grep -Erin '/usr/bin/git.*--follow' strace | wc -l
0
After (TC / 1 fake TC candidate)
[tony@thor election]$ time strace -fo ./strace -s200 tox -e docs
<SNIP>
___________________________________ summary ____________________________________
  docs: commands succeeded
  congratulations :)

real	0m15.497s
user	0m9.623s
sys	0m5.991s
[tony@thor election]$ grep -Erin '/usr/bin/git.*--follow' strace | wc -l
2
[tony@thor election]$ grep -Erin '/usr/bin/git.*--follow' strace
397279:9143  execve("/usr/bin/git", ["git", "log", "--follow", "--format=%aE", "candidates/rocky/TC/tonyb.txt"], 0x55cfc3ca9590 /* 8 vars */ <unfinished ...>
397686:9144  execve("/usr/bin/git", ["git", "log", "--follow", "--format=%aE", "candidates/rocky/TC/tonyb.txt"], 0x55cfc3ca9590 /* 8 vars */ <unfinished ...>

Change-Id: I81fc2df78c48aea1b594a7c9f174eee32a7b4128
'}]
commit_message:
Separate the TC and PTL elections

Currently even if we have closed an election when we build the docs we
still determine the full name, email address and IRC nick for all
candidates for a series (i.e both PTL and TC candidates for Rocky while
only running the rocky TC election)

Stop doing that.  This means that we reduce the REST-API hits during doc
builds, generally speed up the docs generation and importantly allow us
to change the process from looking this up from git to probing the
OpenStack Foundation membership DB.

Adding a flag to state the election type (or phase) will also allow us
to, in future changes, auto-validate candidates and generally streamline
the process.

NOTE: This change also forces all calls to filter() to be "listified" to
work the same under py2 and py3

As you can see from the results below, before we were looking up PTL data
from git, which this change stops.  After this change the expected git
queries still happen:

Before:
[tony@thor election]$ time strace -fo ./strace -s200 tox -e docs
<SNIP>
___________________________________ summary ____________________________________
  docs: commands succeeded
  congratulations :)

real	1m21.627s
user	0m16.268s
sys	0m9.921s
[tony@thor election]$ grep -Erin '/usr/bin/git.*--follow' strace | wc -l
125
[tony@thor election]$ grep -Erin '/usr/bin/git.*--follow' strace | head -n1
395670:6892  execve("/usr/bin/git", ["git", "log", "--follow", "--format=%aE", "candidates/rocky/Barbican/alee.txt"], 0x56333426b590 /* 8 vars */ <unfinished ...>
After (PTL)

<SNIP>

  docs: commands succeeded

real	0m35.943s

One more question, this displays the number of items current fetched from the server, but not really the total available if there are more than currently fetched. [{'created': '2015-09-02 18:31:59.000000000', 'message': "WIP Angular tables get page size from horizon settings

To test,
1. Change API_RESULT_PAGE_SIZE in local_settings.py
2. Append 'API_RESULT_PAGE_SIZE' to REST_API_REQUIRED_SETTINGS
3. Set DISABLED = False in _1051_project_ng_images_panel.py
4. Go to the last Images Panel in Project menu
5. See that the pagination controls are set to the value you
set in local_settings.py

Change-Id: Ie5307e335ca3251a342d370e7277fe16067f7949
Partially-Implements: blueprint angularize-identity-tables

"}, {'created': '2016-02-25 00:58:54.000000000', 'message': 'Angular tables get page size from a client-size settings file

1. Change table pageSize in conf.py (default is 20)
3. Set DISABLED = False in _1051_project_ng_images_panel.py
4. Go to the last Images Panel in Project menu
5. See that the pagination controls are set to the value you set in conf.js

Future: pass API_RESULT_PAGE_SIZE from local_settings.py to framework.

Also, st-displayed-pages has been changed from 20 --> 5.
This shows the number of pages 1 | 2 | 3 | etc. Showing up to 20 links at one time
is unnecessary.

Change-Id: Ie5307e335ca3251a342d370e7277fe16067f7949
Partially-Implements: blueprint angularize-identity-tables

'}, {'created': '2016-07-16 07:05:52.000000000', 'message': 'Angular tables get page size from cookie or variable

Make NG table get page size from cookie or variable
instead of a static number, and use pagination template.

Snapshot: http://pasteboard.co/c42Nsb3Cg.png

Now we use $templateCache to override the pagination template,
after xstatic-angular-smart-table-1.4.13 released, we will use
stConfig.pagination.template to override.

Future: pass API_RESULT_PAGE_SIZE from local_settings.py to framework.

Co-Authored-By: Liuqing Jing <jing.liuqing@99cloud.net>

Change-Id: Ie5307e335ca3251a342d370e7277fe16067f7949
Partially-Implements: blueprint angularize-identity-tables

commit_message:
Use items per page setting on Angular tables

Make NG table get page size from the items per page setting
instead of a fixed number which is 20.

The styling of the pagination control is the same as the
django table with the prev and next links.

Co-Authored-By: Liuqing Jing <jing.liuqing@99cloud.net>
Co-Authored-By: Vladislav Kuzmin <vkuzmin@mirantis.com>

Change-Id: Ie5307e335ca3251a342d370e7277fe16067f7949
Closes-Bug: #1647677

commit_message:
Add debian stretch nodes to arm64/amd64 clouds

Stretch is the latest stable debian release.  So add debian stretch
nodes to arm64 and amd64 clouds.

Note we're updating to use our internal debian mirrors, which now have
arm64 too.

Depends-On: https://review.openstack.org/557942
Change-Id: Idb88d863b5b13286d791970be396c92eff470a81

Assuming this is necessary (and it sounds like it is at least very helpful), the spec is fine, but the sort of duplication of data is bit unnerving, but such is progress."}, {'account_id': 1063, 'date': '2018-03-26 15:22:55.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 6: Code-Review+1

I'm burned out on spec reviews for the day, I'll come back to this."}, {'account_id': 5754, 'date': '2018-03-29 05:11:54.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 6:

Emm....Actually, it is worse than the proxy, it is sync. Like we have sync between cells in cellv1.But I'm not try to stop this spec I just want to understand why this is good choice, to help me learn how to make a decision. This is the way people learn new thing from the review."}, {'account_id': 7, 'date': '2018-03-29 17:17:51.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 6:

Alex, yes, it is syncing information. This is for exactly the same reason why we sync information from the compute nodes to the placement service for inventory information. Placement is the owner of that information. I would like information about the grouping of resource providers to also be owned by placement. Thus, the need for this spec.

Hope that's clear.

-jay"}, {'account_id': 5754, 'date': '2018-03-30 02:48:35.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 6:

(3 comments)

Left some comments inline on the possibility of adding a periodic task in nova-scheduler rather than the nova-manage CLI, but like discover_hosts, we could always start with the CLI and add a periodic task later if needed.

Doc impact is what I'd expect (thanks for being thorough there).

And as noted inline, I don't think we need a new microversion for this, as this isn't something I think an admin should be opting into, it should just be turned on when they get there.

One thing on the upgrade impact is that nova-api depending on placement config will be new. I was wondering if we could have a nova-status check for that, but there isn't a good way with nova-status to check per-service config, so not really something we can add. We could, however, make the sync optional in Rocky and then make it fail hard in Stein."}, {'account_id': 6873, 'date': '2018-04-09 14:04:07.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 8:

commit_message:
Add ceph integrated repo testing

Ceph client should exercise the integrated ceph job on demand.
This allows to see if a ceph client change breaks the ceph
jobs.

Depends-On: https://review.openstack.org/559693
Change-Id: I91a23b9b79c497d48cbe6837dd8c9eaaa65e23bf

subject: Ensure /etc/resolv.conf is a regular file in final image
reviewers: [{'_account_id': 4146, 'name': 'Clark Boylan', 'email': 'cboylan@sapwetik.org', 'username': 'cboylan'}, {'_account_id': 4162, 'name': 'Paul Belanger', 'email': 'pabelanger@redhat.com', 'username': 'pabelanger'}, {'_account_id': 6547, 'name': 'Andreas Jaeger', 'email': 'jaegerandi@gmail.com', 'username': 'jaegerandi'}, {'_account_id': 7069, 'name': 'Joshua Hesketh', 'email': 'josh@nitrotech.org', 'username': 'jhesketh'}, {'_account_id': 7118, 'name': 'Ian Wienand', 'email': 'iwienand@redhat.com', 'username': 'iwienand'}, {'_account_id': 13252, 'name': 'Dr. Jens Harbott', 'display_name': 'Dr. Jens Harbott (frickler)', 'email': 'frickler@offenerstapel.de', 'username': 'jrosenboom'}, {'_account_id': 22348, 'name': 'Zuul', 'username': 'zuul', 'tags': ['SERVICE_USER']}]
messages:
[{'account_id': 4146, 'date': '2018-03-29 22:21:23.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 1.'}, {'account_id': 4162, 'date': '2018-03-29 22:29:31.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

(1 comment)'}, {'account_id': 4146, 'date': '2018-03-29 22:38:23.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 2.'}, {'account_id': 4162, 'date': '2018-03-29 22:39:42.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2: Code-Review+2'}, {'account_id': 7118, 'date': '2018-04-02 22:04:04.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2:

(1 comment)'}, {'account_id': 4162, 'date': '2018-04-02 22:08:18.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2:

(1 comment)'}, {'account_id': 7118, 'date': '2018-04-03 00:55:19.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 2:

Ok, so maybe this is an accurate summary

we don't install resolvconf in trusty, xenial or bionic (checked dib logs).  it's actually a suggestion of a range of packages; but i guess we don't install suggested packages.  you can see where systemd is trying to sort out it's removal in [1].

so i think it's an open question of what is setting up this symlink, and not resolvconf as suggested?

---

that said, systemd-resolved doesn't seem to get too involved in /etc/resolv.conf.  the summary seems to be [2]

* it doesn't care about resolv.conf by default
* but, if it is there, it will read it for compatability purposes
* if nothing else is providing it, you can symlink /etc/resolv.conf to some files in /var/run that it provides if *other* tools need a /etc/resolv.conf

[1] https://bugs.launchpad.net/ubuntu/+source/systemd/+bug/1713803
[2] http://manpages.ubuntu.com/manpages/bionic/man8/systemd-resolved.service.8.html"}, {'account_id': 7118, 'date': '2018-04-03 01:20:17.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2:

right, here's the smoking gun from systemd.postinst ($2 being unset as it's not an upgrade)

---
 # Use stub resolve.conf by default on new installs
 if [ -z "$2" ]; then
    mkdir -p /run/systemd/resolve
    if [ -e /etc/resolv.conf ]; then
            cp /etc/resolv.conf /run/systemd/resolve/stub-resolv.conf
    fi
    # If /etc/resolv.conf is a bind-mount, moving or replacing
    # /etc/resolv.conf may fail
    ln -snf ../run/systemd/resolve/stub-resolv.conf /etc/resolv.conf || true
fi
---'}, {'account_id': 7118, 'date': '2018-04-03 04:55:58.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 2: Code-Review-1

arrgh, so i now think this is actually wrong thanks to what dib does

after we do the initial install into the chroot, we move any created resolv.conf out of the way [1].  then we put it back with [2].

I believe what happens with bionic is that systemd-resolved is installed in the early chroot, which runs the aforementioned test and creates its /etc/resolv.conf symlink.  [1] will then save that to the ORIG file, and [2] will restore it.  thus dib ends up restoring the symlink anyway.

it's a little hard to confirm, because we have lost a bunch of tracing due to I586fc95517926025705ce376ec5c4aaf4122773f.  

i suspect the correct solution is for dib to leave behind a blank /etc/resolv.conf file.  of course, we could just look at [1],[2] and delete that orig file -- my concern with that is that it's not really an interface in dib, so we're just as likely to fiddle with it and regress.  So I think dib wants an actual flag or similar to handle this case.


[1] https://git.openstack.org/cgit/openstack/diskimage-builder/tree/diskimage_builder/lib/common-functions#n341
[2] https://git.openstack.org/cgit/openstack/diskimage-builder/tree/diskimage_builder/lib/img-functions#n94"}, {'account_id': 7118, 'date': '2018-04-03 05:31:19.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2:

So I think what we want to do is use Ie0e97d8072e2b21a54b053fa6fb07b62960c686d and write 127.0.0.1 into "/etc/resolv.conf.DIB_ORIG" during this.  then dib will move that into place as one of the final image creation steps'}, {'account_id': 7118, 'date': '2018-04-05 00:31:24.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 3.'}, {'account_id': 7118, 'date': '2018-04-05 00:36:22.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 4.'}, {'account_id': 6547, 'date': '2018-04-05 05:10:45.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 4: Code-Review+2

I expect this needs a new release of dib so that we use the depends-on?'}, {'account_id': 7118, 'date': '2018-04-05 05:31:09.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 4:

@Andreas actually it has really just ended up as a documentation change, because I found that other people had already hooked into this interface anyway.  So it should work regardless of release'}, {'account_id': 7069, 'date': '2018-04-05 10:13:09.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 4: Code-Review+1'}, {'account_id': 4146, 'date': '2018-04-06 15:46:40.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 4:

(1 comment)'}, {'account_id': 4162, 'date': '2018-04-06 16:27:17.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 4:

(1 comment)'}, {'account_id': 4146, 'date': '2018-04-06 16:30:17.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 4:

(1 comment)'}, {'account_id': 4162, 'date': '2018-04-06 17:14:07.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 4:

revisions:
[{'created': '2018-03-29 22:21:23.000000000', 'message': 'Write resolv.conf safely during image build

/etc/resolv.conf may be a symlink to some other location. If this is the
case we remove the symlink then write to a proper file at
/etc/resolv.conf to set the resolver to localhost. This way we avoid
odd configuration states on Bionic which attempts to use
systemd resolved by default.

Change-Id: I1e1d285787f88370fec6e9e21701164cc232e153
'}, {'created': '2018-03-29 22:38:23.000000000', 'message': 'Write resolv.conf safely during image build

/etc/resolv.conf may be a symlink to some other location. If this is the
case we remove the symlink then write to a proper file at
/etc/resolv.conf to set the resolver to localhost. This way we avoid
odd configuration states on Bionic which attempts to use resolvconf
and systemd in a way that makes it difficult for us to explicitly use
our localhost unbound resolver.

Change-Id: I1e1d285787f88370fec6e9e21701164cc232e153

commit_message:
Ensure /etc/resolv.conf is a regular file in final image

As described in the inline comment, this ensures that on Bionic (and
any similar platform using systemd-resolved) we use a regular
/etc/resolv.conf file for nameserver configuration.

Depends-On: https://review.openstack.org/#/c/558362/
Change-Id: I1e1d285787f88370fec6e9e21701164cc232e153

commit_message:
Update cut_list() to return the specified number of characters

This patch updates cut_list() to ensure that it does not return
more than the number of characters specified in the limit
parameter.

Change-Id: I9dbd061a5ba1976aae9d1acf1e501a3c98782972
Closes-Bug: 1761246

[{'created': '2018-04-04 09:46:15.000000000', 'message': "Always include certmonger_user

This makes sure we always include the certmonger_user profile, which
installs the local CA (if that's the one we're using). This is necessary
for when we deploy TLS by default in the overcloud.

It also makes the setting of the certificate specification to be
optional and to depend on the generate_service_certificate flag.

Change-Id: I8b46ce3f9cd6e36d0b8f604b49e4113301461a4c
"}]
commit_message:
Always include certmonger_user

This makes sure we always include the certmonger_user profile, which
installs the local CA (if that's the one we're using). This is necessary
for when we deploy TLS by default in the overcloud.

It also makes the setting of the certificate specification to be
optional and to depend on the generate_service_certificate flag.

Change-Id: I8b46ce3f9cd6e36d0b8f604b49e4113301461a4c

commit_message:
Update neutron cli calls

Neutron cli calls are deprecated, and will be removed soon, this patch
change all the neutron cli calls to openstack cli calls, the new command
line client for openstack.

Change-Id: I96431c6d28386f3f2be83be3e079a4b9fd015939

Hi John. It looks fine right now. Please evaluate Code-Review again. Thanks.'}, {'account_id': 14760, 'date': '2018-03-16 19:57:53.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 9:

Hmmm. When I run this test locally it fails.

It passes in gate because of this:
https://github.com/openstack-infra/zuul-jobs/blob/d28c326b36df44a7d84891609e88d3ccf976b4d5/roles/sphinx/tasks/main.yaml#L50-L62

So it is not running our tox command. Should ping mordred to find out what to do.'}, {'account_id': 14760, 'date': '2018-03-16 23:18:40.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 9: Code-Review-2

I'm going to block this until we figure out the correct action."}, {'account_id': 14760, 'date': '2018-03-17 00:40:48.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 9:

Had a conversation in IRC about it, but I don't fully understand at the moment. Need to research more.

<jlvillal> mordred, Had a question on the PTI document build. There is a patch: https://review.openstack.org/#/c/553473/ trying to use the new way.

<jlvillal> mordred, But notice that the job runs it the old way. Only problem is that when run tox now, it fails. But doesn't fail in the gate since it doesn't use tox. It runs the "python setup.py build_sphinx" in the gate.

<jlvillal> mordred, So seems when things switch the job will fail.

<clarkb> jlvillal: it should be self testing

<clarkb> jlvillal: what makes you think the job runs the old way?

<jlvillal> clarkb, Because of: https://github.com/openstack-infra/zuul-jobs/blob/d28c326b36df44a7d84891609e88d3ccf976b4d5/roles/sphinx/tasks/main.yaml#L50-L62

<jlvillal> clarkb, From the job run: http://logs.openstack.org/73/553473/9/check/build-openstack-sphinx-docs/64f6c24/job-output.txt.gz#_2018-03-16_17_23_42_449126

<clarkb> ah I see you have the legacy autodoc

<clarkb> I think you just turn that off and it will use the new thing?

<jlvillal> clarkb, How do we turn it off?

<clarkb> jlvillal: I think you have to remove the config for it from your setup.cfg then add it into your sphinx config

<jlvillal> clarkb, Thanks I will look

<clarkb> jlvillal: but also note that once the change merges it will continue to use that pbr method aiui so won't break

<clarkb> its just your new tox.ini command won't line up with what is run

<jlvillal> clarkb, Thanks. Will investigate it more.'}, {'account_id': 27153, 'date': '2018-03-18 09:16:18.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 9:

Hi, any further comments?'}, {'account_id': 27153, 'date': '2018-03-19 07:57:12.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 10: Patch Set 9 was rebased'}, {'account_id': 19339, 'date': '2018-03-19 08:49:01.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 10:

Build succeeded.

Thanks."}, {'account_id': 14760, 'date': '2018-03-19 15:13:07.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 11:

> You actually don't understand about new PTI.
 > 
 > In case ironic docs, I remove the pbr works because it isn't
 > needed.

Please explain it then. Why are some using Legacy PBR runner and some are not. That is why I said more info is needed in the commit message.

Thanks"}, {'account_id': 27153, 'date': '2018-03-19 15:18:43.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 11:

I just made a change based on the guide at [2] in the commit message. In both links, they didn't say anything about changes in setup.cfg. I remove the pbr setup because they aren't needed in the special case of ironic docs.

In the other patches of other projects, what do you mean by "This is still using the legacy PBR runner". Then, what should I do with those patches?'}, {'account_id': 14760, 'date': '2018-03-19 15:22:13.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 11:

> I just made a change based on the guide at [2] in the commit
 > message. In both links, they didn't say anything about changes in
 > setup.cfg. I remove the pbr setup because they aren't needed in the
 > special case of ironic docs.
 > 
 > In the other patches of other projects, what do you mean by "This
 > is still using the legacy PBR runner". Then, what should I do with
 > those patches?

I believe the change that is needed is to remove:

 [pbr]
 autodoc_index_modules = True
 <and anything else related to doc generation>'}, {'account_id': 27153, 'date': '2018-03-19 15:28:26.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 11:

In the case that they want to generate api docs, removing it will raise error also.

I still don't get the idea about your comment "This is still using the legacy PBR runner". What should I do then?'}, {'account_id': 14760, 'date': '2018-03-19 15:30:06.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 11:

Please go to #openstack-doc'}, {'account_id': 27153, 'date': '2018-03-19 16:02:12.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 11:

> Ok then, this patch already removes [pbr] section, please give the
 > reason why (-1) so that I can further work.

I left comments on why the -1.

Basically in the commit message it should say:

 * What has been changed
 * Why it has been changed

This commit message says "why" it has been changed but not what.'}, {'account_id': 27153, 'date': '2018-03-19 16:50:58.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 12: Published edit on patch set 11.'}, {'account_id': 27153, 'date': '2018-03-19 16:51:32.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 13: Patch Set 12 was rebased'}, {'account_id': 14760, 'date': '2018-03-19 17:07:58.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 13:

commit_message:
Follow the new PTI for document build

For compliance with the Project Testing Interface as described in:
[1] https://governance.openstack.org/tc/reference/project-testing-interface.html
[2] http://lists.openstack.org/pipermail/openstack-dev/2017-December/125710.html

[doc/requirements.txt] & [test-requirements.txt]
To support documentation generation in new PTI, project should have
list python dependencies needed for documentation in
doc/requirements.txt which are move from test-requirements.txt

[doc/source/contributor/index.rst] & [setup.cfg]
- Remove [pbr] section in setup.cfg [3], and unrelated lines in
contributor/index.rst
[3] http://lists.openstack.org/pipermail/openstack-dev/2018-March/128594.html
- Add sphinxcontrib.apidoc to replace pbr autodoc

[tox.ini]
--ignore D000: pep8 require sphinx (which move to doc/requirements.txt)
to test doc/source files, however, docs already test the doc/source.
Therefore we can ignore the D000 error code.

Depends-On: https://review.openstack.org/#/c/559327/
Change-Id: Iee90f19a5e46978a97035eab7e4b1e0ec68b8684

commit_message:
Disable automated cleaning in grenade

Grenade has seven nodes, and chances that at least one of them will
fail PXE booting is quite high. Ironic itself already has automated
cleaning disabled in its grenade jobs.

Change-Id: I89fab35848801ebd57a772fc4efa637cfb81844f
(cherry picked from commit 1ae010bb708138f17ffcd8b8cfa9fe974dfac0b2)

commit_message:
Update properties URL

Help text for some image properties (architecture, os_distro) is
pulled from the glanceclient's local version of the image schema.
The URL for those property definitions has gotten out of sync with
Glance.  This patch updates the URL to be the same as that given
in the Glance image-schema response.

Change-Id: I4e46e78525fe5c00e031a98c47cacc17e5693d53
Closes-bug: #1757918
(cherry picked from commit 0661da1ee903da930b326daaa7d5deb5707d7ca3)

commit_message:
Avoid popup blocker after key-pair creation

Chrome version 64 blocks new window popup for
downloading created private key.

This problem occurs in Angularized panels that
uses text-download service.

This patch fixes not to open new window.

Change-Id: Ib37eb492bc5704ca1487830b6181458ee40b5d1d
Closes-Bug: #1757919

commit_message:
Developer docs refactor

This is a combined cherry-pick from:
- https://review.openstack.org/#/c/557650/
- https://review.openstack.org/#/c/559027/

This refactor has the intent of guiding a new OpenStack-Ansible
user towards his first contributions.

The deploy guide is now pointing towards the Developer Guide,
but there is was no guidance given, just a series of topics.

Here, the first page of the developer guide is an onboarding
page, explaining our repos, what's inside them, and how to
contribute. It then links towards all the sections, which
had to be restructured to match a wizard-style flow.

Change-Id: Ib2a5f2063c4dc58fc249ac94c3cd85bb281f28a5
(cherry picked from commit 3a4ca09d11830ce51c79a04b94170604d73b4eda)

commit_message:
Add a test for cleaning up stale group assignments

This commit just adds a test for cleaning up group assignments when
the group has disappeared from the backend. We take the same approach
with user assignments.

Change-Id: Ie57612c261d12e00482d06162ef715725f3cd970

commit_message:
Default environment/services/* to docker

This updates the relevant environment/services-docker code
for undercloud-deploy to default to dockerish environment/services.

Change-Id: I8f452e34bffb269741f0831a6d61aece9722f860
Signed-off-by: Bogdan Dobrelya <bdobreli@redhat.com>

commit_message:
Deprecates tripleo.roles.list action

The tripleo.roles.list action is deprecated.  Please use the
tripleo.plan_management.v1.list_roles workflow instead.  Calling actions
directly is no longer supported.

This patch adds a deprecation notice to the action code, the file
where the action is registered and an associated release note.

Change-Id: I233be93b5a22008fbbfae8a49f24c3a79b9e2df2

commit_message:
Switch Zaqar to use Redis

Zaqar was using mongodb by default but we haven't supported mongodb
since pike.  This change switches Zaqar to use redis by default.

Change-Id: If6ed9fddf4a4fcff3bb9105b04df777ec8a8990e
Closes-Bug: #1761239

The ceph cookbook on Supermarket has not been updated for Chef 13.
Instead, a more alive iteration[0] should be used.

[0] https://github.com/ceph/ceph-chef

Change-Id: I1eee3dfb765a542c4cefe1f4bc21cd9e9bc10008
Implements: blueprint reimplement-ceph
Depends-On: https://review.openstack.org/553937

revisions:
[{'created': '2018-04-06 16:51:40.000000000', 'message': 'Run xstatic version checker in project repo

The xstatic version checker script expects to be able to ls contents
relative to the root of the project repo otherwise it fails with:

  Traceback (most recent call last):
    File "xstatic_check_version.py", line 26, in <module>
      for name in os.listdir('xstatic/pkg'):
  OSError: [Errno 2] No such file or directory: 'xstatic/pkg'

Fix this by running the script after chdir'ing into the repo.

Change-Id: Ifd8f3db93b8c600b361ec894a404c54255b888de
'}]
commit_message:
Run xstatic version checker in project repo

The xstatic version checker script expects to be able to ls contents
relative to the root of the project repo otherwise it fails with:

  Traceback (most recent call last):
    File "xstatic_check_version.py", line 26, in <module>
      for name in os.listdir('xstatic/pkg'):
  OSError: [Errno 2] No such file or directory: 'xstatic/pkg'

Fix this by running the script after chdir'ing into the repo.

Change-Id: Ifd8f3db93b8c600b361ec894a404c54255b888de

commit_message:
Change pxe dhcp options name to codes.

There is difference between dhcp option names in different backends.
This patch changes options name to code according to [0].

[0] https://www.iana.org/assignments/bootp-dhcp-parameters/bootp-dhcp-parameters.xhtml

Closes-Bug: 1717236

This is an updated version of c377f5cbbd034e16b68a3fc30e138b03badc9c94
which problems with PXE and dnsmasq due to buggy dnsmasq code which uses
siaddr field to specify tftp server. They are addressed now by always
sending server-ip-address to make sure that dnsmasq works.

More information about siaddr and option 150,66 can be found in
informational RFC https://tools.ietf.org/html/rfc5859

Change-Id: I55487d867979bf6bb4cf228fcf6408beae955d2b
(cherry picked from commit 228a2a7885e1b04d4180fe8daa2992884decaf6d)

commit_message:
add lower-constraints job

Create a tox environment for running the unit tests against the lower
bounds of the dependencies.

Create a lower-constraints.txt to be used to enforce the lower bounds
in those tests.

Add openstack-tox-lower-constraints job to the zuul configuration.

See http://lists.openstack.org/pipermail/openstack-dev/2018-March/128352.html
for more details.

Change-Id: I39ad6aa578434d803d481d67c4ae67f06e376834
Depends-On: https://review.openstack.org/555034
Signed-off-by: Doug Hellmann <doug@doughellmann.com>

commit_message:
tempest: dynamic RT allocation

The BGP RTs used in the tests were initially constants, reused
by the different tests.  This is safe only if tests are not
run in parallel, but not when they are concurrently run, because
some routes advertised by one test may be imported in routing
tables from another test.

To solve this, we need to dynamic allocation of RTs so that
different tests use different RTs, to ensure isolation
between the different tests.

Change-Id: Ib1b461a7f6d6d949993c07129f24fbffe92990bb

revisions:
[{'created': '2018-04-09 14:33:50.000000000', 'message': "Use 'Default' as sample install domain name

The Glance install guide suggests using 'default' as the
user_domain_name and project_domain_name, whereas the Keystone
install guide, which people would be consulting earlier, instructs
the installer to use 'Default'.  Since the name is case-sensitive,
this is causing problems for first-time installers of OpenStack.

Change-Id: Iade47bcd69b7a2a99b990885a0270c962de282a1
Closes-bug: #1747181
(cherry picked from commit 57310ad88f64214869ab1962184e74583e0845b6)
"}]
commit_message:
Use 'Default' as sample install domain name

The Glance install guide suggests using 'default' as the
user_domain_name and project_domain_name, whereas the Keystone
install guide, which people would be consulting earlier, instructs
the installer to use 'Default'.  Since the name is case-sensitive,
this is causing problems for first-time installers of OpenStack.

Change-Id: Iade47bcd69b7a2a99b990885a0270c962de282a1
Closes-bug: #1747181
(cherry picked from commit 57310ad88f64214869ab1962184e74583e0845b6)

Support extending attached ScaleIO volumes

Adding ability to extend ScaleIO volumes which are
attached to an instance.

Change-Id: Ib2debfe481d4c1921d14546f81b60d070e8f9f39

commit_message:
add lower-constraints job

Create a tox environment for running the unit tests against the lower
bounds of the dependencies.

Create a lower-constraints.txt to be used to enforce the lower bounds
in those tests.

Add openstack-tox-lower-constraints job to the zuul configuration.

See http://lists.openstack.org/pipermail/openstack-dev/2018-March/128352.html
for more details.

Co-Authored-By: Nguyen Hai <nguyentrihai93@gmail.com>
Change-Id: Ida2bb7e0de8ca646af2da8c4bc3ed1708f69b184
Depends-On: https://review.openstack.org/555034
Depends-On: https://review.openstack.org/558566
Signed-off-by: Doug Hellmann <doug@doughellmann.com>

(11 comments)

Thanks for you comments, most of them are related to what is already approved and implemented. That is said I understand it's difficult to see what I have updated on the spec. I'm still going to address any of the suggestions related to the phrasing you have proposed since I did not see any discord."}, {'account_id': 7730, 'date': '2017-10-19 07:35:36.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 2.'}, {'account_id': 8768, 'date': '2017-10-19 15:41:58.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

(2 comments)

I had forgotten that much of this was already approved in pike, otherwise I wouldn't have commented on the approved stuff.  Oops.

I gave a suggestion for rewriting one of the new sections for more clarity.

One final thing...while this is the simplest way to do it, it has the disadvantage that it reserves at nova-compute startup a set of CPUs that are only used if the flavor specifies a certain option.  It seems like it would have been more flexible to specify a "hypervisor_overhead_ratio" or similar (specifying how many instances/vcpus are allowed to run their hypervisor work on a host CPU) and have nova-compute automatically allocate host CPUs as needed to keep within that ratio.  That way if nobody uses "hw:cpu_emulator_threads=host" then there would be no overhead.  The logic would be more complicated though...'}, {'account_id': 7730, 'date': '2017-10-19 18:14:44.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 3.'}, {'account_id': 7730, 'date': '2017-10-19 18:15:44.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

(1 comment)'}, {'account_id': 9708, 'date': '2017-10-20 07:41:36.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 3: Code-Review-1

(3 comments)

My employer also interested in this feature. I left couple of question inline.

Cheers,
gibi'}, {'account_id': 15334, 'date': '2017-10-20 08:53:48.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 3: Code-Review-1

It looks like you've taken the spec from the last cycle and added the new stuff. Could you strip out the stuff from last cycle and simply link to the previous spec early on?"}, {'account_id': 7730, 'date': '2017-10-20 13:21:36.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 3:

(3 comments)

(6 comments)

I just realised this is nit a new spec but one from last cycle this was nit clear at all by hope the spec was submitted. There is no easy way to see the delta here since we are way past the spec freeze im assuming this work will not be done in queens or this spec is just documenting how the implementation deviated from what was approved last cycle'}, {'account_id': 15334, 'date': '2017-11-02 14:55:10.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 4: Code-Review-1

Yeah, the way you have done this makes it super confusing to figure out what exactly you're planning to do in Queens (now Rocky). When you repropose this, can you please filter out the old stuff and focus only on what you want to do in the upcoming cycle"}, {'account_id': 8768, 'date': '2017-11-02 18:26:11.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

Agree that it is a good idea to keep the whole context. So, why not do that in flavor document? We can keep whole context extracting important parts from here to the flavor document.
Because spec is where we discuss and supply info to users about new features we add, it should be a document where we can distinguish what is already done and what is new.'}, {'account_id': 7730, 'date': '2018-01-30 08:48:26.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 5.'}, {'account_id': 7730, 'date': '2018-02-01 08:36:59.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 6.'}, {'account_id': 15334, 'date': '2018-02-01 11:49:44.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 6: Code-Review-1

Keeping the whole context looks reasonable as we know that most of the time spec are used as documentation."}, {'account_id': 25625, 'date': '2018-02-12 05:52:48.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 6: Code-Review-1

As an OpenStack user, I would refer specs as documents to know what is the new feature of the release, why the new feature is added, and what would be the problem without the new feature (i.e. the problems with the previous release).

In short, wed like to see the exact delta between the releases in specs, not the whole context. For the whole context, we just refer the admin/user guide.'}, {'account_id': 7730, 'date': '2018-02-21 09:59:02.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 7.'}, {'account_id': 7730, 'date': '2018-02-27 07:11:16.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 8: Patch Set 7 was rebased'}, {'account_id': 8768, 'date': '2018-02-27 11:56:12.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 8: Code-Review-1

commit_message:
update: isolate guests emulthreads on CONF.cpu_shared_set

This updates the original spec to accept the guest emulthreads running
on CONF.cpu_shared_set when hw:emulator_threads_policy=share is
configured.

Change-Id: I222b27f8bcb6e692c64bb28b9d948af1366dbcd5
related: blueprint overhead-pin-set
Signed-off-by: Sahid Orentino Ferdjaoui <sahid.ferdjaoui@redhat.com>

revisions:
[{'created': '2018-04-07 22:05:47.000000000', 'message': "Use 'Default' as sample install domain name

The Glance install guide suggests using 'default' as the
user_domain_name and project_domain_name, whereas the Keystone
install guide, which people would be consulting earlier, instructs
the installer to use 'Default'.  Since the name is case-sensitive,
this is causing problems for first-time installers of OpenStack.

Change-Id: Iade47bcd69b7a2a99b990885a0270c962de282a1
Closes-bug: #1747181
"}]
commit_message:
Use 'Default' as sample install domain name

The Glance install guide suggests using 'default' as the
user_domain_name and project_domain_name, whereas the Keystone
install guide, which people would be consulting earlier, instructs
the installer to use 'Default'.  Since the name is case-sensitive,
this is causing problems for first-time installers of OpenStack.

Change-Id: Iade47bcd69b7a2a99b990885a0270c962de282a1
Closes-bug: #1747181

@Abhishek: we do need these changes for the case where a user is doing the import workflow manually.  But I agree with Erno that we can gate some of the validation checks since we have a way to know whether the function is being triggered by image-create-via-import or directly.

New PS up shortly.'}, {'account_id': 5314, 'date': '2018-04-03 17:02:58.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 3.'}, {'account_id': 5314, 'date': '2018-04-03 17:05:02.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 3:

This patch set is rebased onto PS5 of https://review.openstack.org/#/c/555550/ , so it's running all the updated unit tests for image-create-via-import."}, {'account_id': 5314, 'date': '2018-04-03 20:19:53.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 3:

Bunch of timeouts in legacy-tempest-dsvm-neutron-src ... after 3 hours.'}, {'account_id': 5314, 'date': '2018-04-03 20:20:03.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 3:

recheck'}, {'account_id': 5314, 'date': '2018-04-03 22:43:46.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 3:

I was all bent out of shape and started looking into whether glanceclient really needs to be running the lib-forward-testing job (that's where legacy-tempest-dsvm-neutron-src comes from), but it looks like this failure was just way more extreme than usual (there were something like 8 timeouts on the run that failed).  Looks like it usually finishes ok:
http://zuul.openstack.org/builds.html?job_name=legacy-tempest-dsvm-neutron-src&project=openstack%2Fpython-glanceclient"}, {'account_id': 5314, 'date': '2018-04-04 14:43:37.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 3:

@Abhishek: I just realized I was looking at the wrong review.  I think we still need this patch for stable/queens glanceclient.'}, {'account_id': 5314, 'date': '2018-04-04 14:54:17.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 4: Patch Set 3 was rebased.'}, {'account_id': 5314, 'date': '2018-04-04 18:36:30.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 5: Patch Set 4 was rebased.'}, {'account_id': 11904, 'date': '2018-04-05 14:33:31.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 5: Code-Review+2

commit_message:
Make image-import fail faster

Add checks to image-import command so that it provides better user
feedback in failure situations.

Change-Id: I8b6b32c3d1d1a745aa68ff8dc629419dff9bb130
Closes-bug: #1758718

by the stable-maint team like every other stable/* branch.

http://logs.openstack.org/51/554651/10/check/kayobe-seed-centos/2371a94/primary/logs/ansible/seed-deploy'}, {'account_id': 14826, 'date': '2018-04-04 13:40:25.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 11.'}, {'account_id': 14826, 'date': '2018-04-04 18:32:21.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 12.'}, {'account_id': 14826, 'date': '2018-04-07 09:52:29.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 13.'}, {'account_id': 14826, 'date': '2018-04-09 11:11:51.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 14.'}, {'account_id': 14826, 'date': '2018-04-09 12:19:57.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 14:

I'm sure you've seen this patch go past often in IRC, and it's finally ready.

I ended up using the Zuul VM itself as a seed, rather than as a hypervisor with nested virt for a seed VM. The nested VM approach seemed to have a number of issues and failed in many different ways. I've added a WIP patch to revert to that scheme [1], which could replace this job or alternatively add a new job.

I've seen a few consecutive successes (and no failures) with this code now, it seems much more stable.

[1] https://review.openstack.org/#/c/559706"}, {'account_id': 16984, 'date': '2018-04-09 12:49:00.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 14: Code-Review+2

Looks like a sensible tradeoff.'}, {'account_id': 17669, 'date': '2018-04-09 13:02:04.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 14: Code-Review-1

(1 comment)'}, {'account_id': 14826, 'date': '2018-04-09 13:05:49.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 14:

(1 comment)'}, {'account_id': 17669, 'date': '2018-04-09 13:25:12.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 14: Workflow+1 Code-Review+2

(1 comment)'}]

seed host. The VM provided by Zuul is configured as the seed, rather

This approach should be more reliable, faster, and easier to get

commit_message:
Add a job for seed deployment

Adds a new CI job, kayobe-seed-centos, that deploys a single VM as a
seed host. The VM provided by Zuul is configured as the seed, rather
than a seed hypervisor that provisions a seed VM using nested virt.

This approach should be more reliable, faster, and easier to get
working, at the expense of not testing the seed hypervisor code paths.

Currently the seed services are deployed, but not tested. A future
change could test discovery and provisioning of an overcloud host using
the seed.

Change-Id: Iefe16215af6f1a9fb8ec78094cd6bd76a82a040a
Story: 2001655
Task: 6683

commit_message:
Add [baremetal] available_nodes configuration option

This patch adds the available_nodes configuration option so that when a
test requires more than one node it can be skipped if it is known that
there are not enough nodes in the environment to test that test.

Change-Id: I3a7809b2c4b06f429900bd40f4576b1bf8a50891

commit_message:
Copy port[group] VIF info from extra to internal_info

For API versions >= 1.28, Port & portgroup's .extra['vif_port_id'] was
deprecated in Ocata. Before we can remove support for this, we need to
copy that information to the object's internal_info['tenant_vif_port_id'].

This copy/migration is done at the API layer when the user specifies the
.extra[] value, as well as when the 'ironic db-sync online_data-migrations'
is run.

In order to know whether the ports and port groups have been migrated,
their IronicObject versions are incremented.

This also fixes it so that for API versions < 1.28, the deprecation
warning is not shown, since we still need to support extra['vif_port_id']
in this case.

When a port or portgroup's .extra['vif_port_id'] is removed via a
PATCH API request, that VIF is removed from that object's internal_info.

Change-Id: I69468c935e68dd9d37a474c318c3ceb9cdfc5868
Partial-Bug: 1722850

commit_message:
Bump the Cinder LVM backing file size to 24Gb.

This follows a change made to devstack-gate in commit 841ebc3 to allow
tempest to succeed even if it happens to run several volume tests in
parallel.  Right now it's possible for a tempest-full test (run without
devstack-gate) to fail with an "Insufficient free virtual space" error in
the cinder-scheduler log.

Suggested by: Clark Boylan <clark.boylan@gmail.com>
Closes-Bug: 1743597
Change-Id: I16ccb9976d1bc7c9f56a6a4d73e35042a5867ef9

commit_message:
Use six.text_type instead of str in NovaException __repr__

This change set is a follow up to change set
I653282a030d03362dfca0fd1026cebe920d54e37. In that change
set it was realized after merging that unicode values in
Exceptions would break when cast to a str. This change set
addresses that failure by using six.text_type instead of str.

Change-Id: I207ea18852d8b515e0c9034ec6df37094bf0b7d4
Closes-Bug: #1756360

commit_message:
Fix parameter name for removing compute host

The compute parameter name is incorrect in the docs for removing
compute host from openstack. It should be 'host_to_be_removed'.

Change-Id: I0c35183215a6a776e13710ebdbc23fefe61f339b

commit_message:
[Docs] Restructure inventory documentation

The documentation of the inventory started to be spread out, but
also massive to be inside one page.

This moves it to the inventory section of the reference, but at the
same time, to improve readability, moves the previous content into
sub pages.

Change-Id: If2c6b83abafdc66879d818df4c9690142389a965

[{'created': '2017-07-31 15:59:00.000000000', 'message': 'Fix python 3.6 escape char warning

In python 3.6, escape sequences that are not
recognized in string literals issue DeprecationWarnings.

Convert these to raw strings.

Change-Id: I508a9147b932e219069eeee756bcbc43c7e961c5
'}]
commit_message:
Fix python 3.6 escape char warning

In python 3.6, escape sequences that are not
recognized in string literals issue DeprecationWarnings.

Convert these to raw strings.

Change-Id: I508a9147b932e219069eeee756bcbc43c7e961c5

subject: Make image-create-via-import fail faster
messages: [{'account_id': 5314, 'date': '2018-04-05 12:11:13.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Cherry Picked from branch master.'}, {'account_id': 11904, 'date': '2018-04-05 14:29:11.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Code-Review+2\n\nMerged to master and appropriate for backport.'}, {'account_id': 5202, 'date': '2018-04-09 11:36:57.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Workflow+1 Code-Review+2'}]
revisions:
[{'created': '2018-04-05 12:11:13.000000000', 'message': "Make image-create-via-import fail faster

Add checks to the image-create-via-import commmand so that it provides
better user feedback and doesn't begin the import workflow unless the
input has a chance of succeeding.  Preserves backward compatibility
with the current image-create command by (1) allowing an image record
only to be created when no import-method is specified AND no data is
supplied, and (2) doing the glance-direct workflow when no import-
method is specified AND data is provided.  Also adds the ability for
the import-method to be set as an env var OS_IMAGE_IMPORT_METHOD.

Change-Id: I0a225f5471a9311217b5d90ebb5fd415c369129a
Closes-bug: #1758149
(cherry picked from commit 79543a67edd7a15aa23426548d3be9ac5b99366d)
"}]
commit_message:
Make image-create-via-import fail faster

Add checks to the image-create-via-import commmand so that it provides
better user feedback and doesn't begin the import workflow unless the
input has a chance of succeeding.  Preserves backward compatibility
with the current image-create command by (1) allowing an image record
only to be created when no import-method is specified AND no data is
supplied, and (2) doing the glance-direct workflow when no import-
method is specified AND data is provided.  Also adds the ability for
the import-method to be set as an env var OS_IMAGE_IMPORT_METHOD.

Change-Id: I0a225f5471a9311217b5d90ebb5fd415c369129a
Closes-bug: #1758149
(cherry picked from commit 79543a67edd7a15aa23426548d3be9ac5b99366d)

Rename s3api's response module as s3response

swift.common.middleware.s3api.response.Response class is renamed
as S3Response too.

Change-Id: I9f3f1ac7136210930aac71ec26ca63b2502b8723

commit_message:
Reference architecture: small cloud with trusted tenants

This document describes the design of a small bare metal cloud with
flat networking and conductors as part of (HA) controller nodes.

Also adds missing information about rescuing network to the common
reference architecture guide.

Change-Id: Ifd3bfcc89263cd9810cd5cfb459ffeeaf146caf7
Story: 2001745
Task: 12108

commit_message:
Extend linters time out

Linters are extended to 15 minutes. A few jobs have been just
reaching the 10 minute deadline, so using 15 minutes should
leave plenty of wiggle room.

Change-Id: I1473d55498d72f5611ae09e0d2e7b709954bb363

revisions:
[{'created': '2018-03-21 02:04:43.000000000', 'message': 'Change a parameter key for CIFS mounting command

While Huawei driver mounting CIFS filesystem, the username parameter
key passed to the mount command is by the form of "user=***", which's
compatible as "username=***" in Ubuntu. However, for some other
systems, such as Redhat, it is not valid.

This patch changes it to the more compatible form "username=***".

Change-Id: Ifa2ca7bcdceef2d47e2841a27ddf51d86f1ef63c
Closes-Bug: #1740816
(cherry picked from commit 5ef160ca7511ca92d8735cfca7bd176dee8ed995)
(cherry picked from commit 0b2ac684a8a91c3eee62872f512989a1abc77e3f)

commit_message:
Change a parameter key for CIFS mounting command

While Huawei driver mounting CIFS filesystem, the username parameter
key passed to the mount command is by the form of "user=***", which's
compatible as "username=***" in Ubuntu. However, for some other
systems, such as Redhat, it is not valid.

This patch changes it to the more compatible form "username=***".

Change-Id: Ifa2ca7bcdceef2d47e2841a27ddf51d86f1ef63c
Closes-Bug: #1740816
(cherry picked from commit 5ef160ca7511ca92d8735cfca7bd176dee8ed995)
(cherry picked from commit 0b2ac684a8a91c3eee62872f512989a1abc77e3f)

revisions:
[{'created': '2018-04-04 18:32:21.000000000', 'message': 'WIP: Use the Zuul VM as the seed

Rather than configuring the Zuul VM as a seed hypervisor, and using
nested virt to provision a seed VM, we use the zuul VM as the seed. This
should be more reliable, faster, and easier to get working, at the
expense of not testing the seed hypervisor code paths.

Change-Id: I038934930f431d824cd23d56f894f0afbd52a57b

Task: 6683

commit_message:
WIP: Use the Zuul VM as the seed

Rather than configuring the Zuul VM as a seed hypervisor, and using
nested virt to provision a seed VM, we use the zuul VM as the seed. This
should be more reliable, faster, and easier to get working, at the
expense of not testing the seed hypervisor code paths.

Change-Id: I038934930f431d824cd23d56f894f0afbd52a57b
Story: 2001655
Task: 6683

commit_message:
Added monitoring tag to monitoring user creation task.

Without that tag, the monitoring user doesn't have the proper privileges
to access the management API to collect metrics. Check the Permission
section in RabbitMQ documentation at https://www.rabbitmq.com/management.html
for futher precision regarding the permission model.

Closes-Bug: 1750582
Change-Id: Iebf279ca591e646656f8411934fd58dc43d5f002
(cherry picked from commit 45cebe81c267951c2ebff07ec371751dc26c2d22)

commit_message:
rebuild a container with a different image

rebuild a container with a different image.
by this way, you can upgrade the container.
For example, rebuild a ubuntu:14.04 container to ubuntu:16.04 for upgrade.

Change-Id: Id08f7dca5de019da33695561f69976aaed6a022c
Implements:blueprint replace-image

Testing completed on the zVM Driver CI system check-nova pipeline and failed.  To recheck only the zVM driver plugins, submit a comment with only  zvm: recheck in the comment.. Contact information: zvmosci@us.ibm.com. For information see https://wiki.openstack.org/wiki/ZVMDriver.

- check-nova-master http://extbasicopstackcilog01.podc.sl.edst.ibm.com/test_logs/jenkins-check-nova-master-12560 : FAILURE in 1h 06m 15s'}, {'account_id': 26515, 'date': '2018-01-17 06:51:43.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2:

Build succeeded.

- nova-dsvm-full-tempest http://cloudbase-ci.com/nova/534384/2/ : SUCCESS in 2h 53m 28s'}, {'account_id': 6962, 'date': '2018-01-18 10:51:25.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 2:

From a chat with Dan Berrange on IRC, he makes a good point that given the Spectre fix --- i.e. anyone using a named CPU model will need to use the '*-IBRS' variants, which already includes the PCID feature.  These models were recently added in the upstream libvirt added[*]:

  cpu: Add Nehalem-IBRS CPU model
  cpu: Add Westmere-IBRS CPU model
  cpu: Add SandyBridge-IBRS CPU model
  cpu: Add IvyBridge-IBRS CPU model
  cpu: Add Haswell-noTSX-IBRS CPU model
  cpu: Add Haswell-IBRS CPU model
  cpu: Add Broadwell-noTSX-IBRS CPU model
  cpu: Add Broadwell-IBRS CPU model
  cpu: Add Skylake-Client-IBRS CPU model
  cpu: Add Skylake-Server-IBRS CPU model
  [...]

But of course they don't exist in the current libvirt versions that the Gate uses.  So we need to sort _that_ out.

[*] https://www.redhat.com/archives/libvir-list/2018-January/msg00282.html"}, {'account_id': 9555, 'date': '2018-01-18 11:09:00.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 2: Code-Review-1

(1 comment)

Couple of things. Firstly mechanical: I don't immediately see how you've hooked up the changes in driver to the output domain xml. Given that it's a WIP with no tests, though... whatever. Assume you'll figure that out.

Given the usage as I've understood it, I'd call the config option cpu_model_extra_features. Might be worth a conversation with xen/vmware folks to see if this could be a cross-driver feature, but given that this is currently an extension to a libvirt feature I wouldn't block on that.

Secondly, although I really appreciated your commit message, I don't think it lives in this commit. This commit should say something like:

Allow operators to configure additional cpu features. This is specifically useful for X, Y, and Z, and possibly other things.

X, Y, and Z should be a sentence or so.

As discussed on IRC, though, it sounds very much to me like the PCID thing is something we want to enable for users by default wherever that's safe. I suggest a subsequent patch to do that. I would cut/paste the detail in this commit message into the subsequent patch, where it would absolutely be relevant.

In the follow on patch, I'd say the config option should be top-level and on by default. e.g. cpu_enable_pcid_by_default(default='yes'). From your linked article, seems the same issue affects KVM, Xen, and VMware, so no reason we couldn't all use the same config option."}, {'account_id': 6962, 'date': '2018-01-22 09:11:07.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 2:

> From a chat with Dan Berrange on IRC, he makes a good point that
 > given the Spectre fix --- i.e. anyone using a named CPU model will
 > need to use the '*-IBRS' variants, which already includes the PCID
 > feature.  

The above comment is actually *wrong* (after a bit of clarification from the QEMU / libvirt folks).  Because the '-IBRS' CPU model variants *doesn't* have the PCID feature included in them.

[...]

 > [*] https://www.redhat.com/archives/libvir-list/2018-January/msg00282.html"}, {'account_id': 6962, 'date': '2018-01-22 09:43:19.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2:

First, thanks for taking time to review, even if this is not fully read yet.

 > (1 comment)
 > 
 > Couple of things. Firstly mechanical: I don't immediately see how
 > you've hooked up the changes in driver to the output domain xml.
 > Given that it's a WIP with no tests, though... whatever. Assume
 > you'll figure that out.

Yes, still figuring it out.  Last week, I was only sporadically available, but I wanted to just kick-start something.

 > Given the usage as I've understood it, I'd call the config option
 > cpu_model_extra_features. Might be worth a conversation with
 > xen/vmware folks to see if this could be a cross-driver feature,
 > but given that this is currently an extension to a libvirt feature
 > I wouldn't block on that.

Hmm, good point.  So far I haven't looked at the impact of other hypervisors.

 > 
 > Secondly, although I really appreciated your commit message, I
 > don't think it lives in this commit. This commit should say
 > something like:
 > 
 > Allow operators to configure additional cpu features. This is
 > specifically useful for X, Y, and Z, and possibly other things.
 > 
 > X, Y, and Z should be a sentence or so.

Yep, I'll reword it appropriately.

 > 
 > As discussed on IRC, though, it sounds very much to me like the
 > PCID thing is something we want to enable for users by default
 > wherever that's safe. I suggest a subsequent patch to do that.

This part is still debatable.  I'm not sure we should do "magic" by default at Nova-level.  As it might be better to defer to the installer-level tools like Triple-O that can handle the cold boot + config change stuff more gracefully.

 > I would cut/paste the detail in this commit message into the
 > subsequent patch, where it would absolutely be relevant.

 >

Thanks for the reviews so far, John & Chris.'}, {'account_id': 6873, 'date': '2018-03-15 22:45:23.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 5:

Can we split this into two changes?

This is really munging a workaround for a CVE fix in QEMU/libvirt, right, at least for the PCID part of it - along with the ability to specify other stuff, like the 'other use cases' section.

We'd want to backport the PCID workaround, right? But backporting a blueprint to enable extra flags seems wrong.

So what if we:

1. Wrote a patch with a [workarounds]set_pcid_flag=False option and we could backport that to stable.

2. On master-only, we deprecate the workarounds option and replace it with the one that you have here, which is the free-form CPU flags thing."}, {'account_id': 6962, 'date': '2018-03-16 08:22:30.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 5:

> Can we split this into two changes?
 > 
 > This is really munging a workaround for a CVE fix in QEMU/libvirt,
 > right, at least for the PCID part of it - along with the ability to
 > specify other stuff, like the 'other use cases' section.

I see where you're coming from.  It can _seem_ like we're munging, but  the 'other use cases' are the result of the all the possible CPU flags.  But let's think through the point you raised.

 > We'd want to backport the PCID workaround, right? 

I'd think so (given the exceptional circumstance).

> But backporting a blueprint to enable extra flags seems wrong.

I can see how it can come across as we're sneaking in a feature, but I'm in two minds.  Because, note the distinction  if we _enabled_ random CPU flags with this config attribute, yes, it's wrong.  But we're merely making the config option _available_; operators have to take explicit action here.

Hmm, then you can probably argue: "if you make the config option available, then users might try something that can break their setup"  in that case, we just have to document for backports that the config option is to be used only for PCID? Yeah, that sounds a bit unclean.  Other ideas welcome.

 > So what if we:
 > 
 > 1. Wrote a patch with a [workarounds]set_pcid_flag=False option and
 > we could backport that to stable.

I could write one, but let's ensure if this is what we really want.  So with the above 'workarounds' approach, what is being implied here is: just allow 'pcid' CPU flag, but disallow every other flag.  This is a workaround for the 'Meltdown' effect; fair game to backport.

 > 2. On master-only, we deprecate the workarounds option and replace
 > it with the one that you have here, which is the free-form CPU
 > flags thing.

And with this options, allow the free-form CPU flags, which is a "feature".

At first sight, sounds reasonable.  /me thinks a bit more if he can punch any holes in this approach.'}, {'account_id': 6962, 'date': '2018-03-16 10:23:01.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 5:

[...]

 > At first sight, sounds reasonable.  /me thinks a bit more if he can
 > punch any holes in this approach.

Rethinking a bit more: The two patches approach from Matt seems like we're needlessly complicating things and creating churn.  IMHO, we should stick with one change.  The ability to set extra flags (besides PCID) is just a side effect of the options available for the config attribute. I'm not really seeing a downside, unless I'm missing something glaring."}, {'account_id': 6873, 'date': '2018-03-16 14:50:16.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 5:

Adding tonyb for his thoughts on the backportability of this as-is.'}, {'account_id': 8768, 'date': '2018-03-16 16:10:16.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 5:

Dan Smith made the (valid) point that this gets no more or less experimental in the current branch, operators will always be able to shoot themselves in the foot by specifying invalid or broken CPU features, and it's up to them to validate that everything works in their specific environment.

Any bugs exposed by this should be libvirt or qemu or kernel bugs, not nova bugs."}, {'account_id': 6873, 'date': '2018-03-16 21:09:18.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 5:

> Dan Smith made the (valid) point that this gets no more or less experimental in the current branch, operators will always be able to shoot themselves in the foot by specifying invalid or broken CPU features, and it's up to them to validate that everything works in their specific environment.

I'm OK with that on master+. I'm less comfortable with that on stable because of the precedent it would also set, because I could see people coming along later and using that as justification for backporting blueprint changes that are no-op's by default, but are still features, and I'd rather not have to have discussions/arguments with people about what is appropriate for stable backports when they are tied to blueprints. I'm not -2 on this, but I'm not in love with the idea of backporting it in it's current form (tied to a blueprint nonetheless)."}, {'account_id': 12898, 'date': '2018-03-16 23:29:40.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 5: Code-Review-1

> [...]
 > 
 > > At first sight, sounds reasonable.  /me thinks a bit more if he
 > can
 > > punch any holes in this approach.
 > 
 > Rethinking a bit more: The two patches approach from Matt seems
 > like we're needlessly complicating things and creating churn. 
 > IMHO, we should stick with one change.  The ability to set extra
 > flags (besides PCID) is just a side effect of the options available
 > for the config attribute. I'm not really seeing a downside, unless
 > I'm missing something glaring.

Yup I'm totally backing Matt here.  His proposal to add an immediately deprecated workaround is the right way here.  This blueprint is a feature and trying to mask it with "Oh we only did it for PCID we didn't really think operators would do *that* with it" isn't going to work.  Sorry.

Yes is adds a little complexity and cleanup work but we need something that's backportable here.'}, {'account_id': 27970, 'date': '2018-03-17 02:57:25.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 5:

(1 comment)'}, {'account_id': 6962, 'date': '2018-03-18 10:09:14.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 5:

[...]

 > > Rethinking a bit more: The two patches approach from Matt seems
 > > like we're needlessly complicating things and creating churn.
 > > IMHO, we should stick with one change.  The ability to set extra
 > > flags (besides PCID) is just a side effect of the options
 > available
 > > for the config attribute. I'm not really seeing a downside,
 > unless
 > > I'm missing something glaring.
 > 
 > Yup I'm totally backing Matt here.  His proposal to add an
 > immediately deprecated workaround is the right way here.  This
 > blueprint is a feature and trying to mask it with "Oh we only did
 > it for PCID we didn't really think operators would do *that* with
 > it" isn't going to work.  Sorry.

Hang on a moment.  First, try to assume _good spirit_ instead of making bogus assertions & being too eager to misinterpret: "You're masking a feature as a bug fix!"  I was just thinking out loud and reasoning here.

 > Yes is adds a little complexity and cleanup work but we need
 > something that's backportable here.

I understand the backportability aspect, and I took it into account from the beginning.  I'm just trying to see if we we avoid *needless* churn & confusion / rules for the sake of rules.

You haven't told anything new that Matt or I haven't already said.  I'd like to hear other opinions too.'}, {'account_id': 12898, 'date': '2018-03-18 22:46:53.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 5:

> Hang on a moment.  First, try to assume _good spirit_ instead of
 > making bogus assertions & being too eager to misinterpret: "You're
 > masking a feature as a bug fix!"  I was just thinking out loud and
 > reasoning here.

No one is assuming _bad spirit_.  You said you were of 2 minds on the topic of how to approach backportability, I'm trying to clarify that doing this in a single change hurts backportability.  Yes it is a small amount of code churn, yes it's sub-optimal.  Do I like it? no but I like it more than the performance issues we have today, from where I stand/sit if we want to backport this then we're going to need to compromise

I'm sure we agree there is a line between "feature" and "bug", I'm sorry we disagree which side of the line that falls on

Drawing a slightly longer bow ... We're in a state where we're considering how to enable extended maintenance, part of the reason we've gotten to that point is careful consideration to backports.  We've shown again and again that our docs/release notes are a terrible way to communicate feature/limitations to consumers (witness the current issues with glance and uwsgi)

 > > Yes is adds a little complexity and cleanup work but we need
 > > something that's backportable here.
 > 
 > I understand the backportability aspect, and I took it into account
 > from the beginning.  I'm just trying to see if we we avoid
 > *needless* churn & confusion / rules for the sake of rules.

Yup If I thought it was *needless* then we wouldn't be having this conversation.  I don't like conflict, I don't like saying "no" but sadly sometimes, more often than I'd like, I have to.
 
 > You haven't told anything new that Matt or I haven't already said. 
 > I'd like to hear other opinions too.

Sure, Like I said I'm trying to make it clear why I don't consider there to be 2 options here.  I'm sorry that wasn't clear.

I'll try to be as clear and brief as possible.  "The change as described in the commit message does not in my opinion meet the appropriate fixes criteria[1].  I am making not statements about the quality of the code or the intent of the author."

[1] https://docs.openstack.org/project-team-guide/stable-branches.html#appropriate-fixes'}, {'account_id': 27552, 'date': '2018-03-19 10:09:14.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 5: Code-Review-1'}, {'account_id': 6962, 'date': '2018-03-19 11:01:06.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 5:

Hey Tony, I've read your comments.  Afraid, I am still not convinced.  Two things:

(a) It is not sensible to create an intentionally incompatible syntax in the Nova config file when the actual Nova code to process the config options is largely identical in both cases.

(b) Imagine, if it were so that only two CPU flags were ever possible: "PCID" and some "ABCD"  would it be a feature or a bug fix?  It can be spun either ways.

I don't want to get hung up this discussion; /me crawls back into the unit test cave & getting the technical bits right first.'}, {'account_id': 6962, 'date': '2018-03-19 11:11:12.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 5:

(1 comment)'}, {'account_id': 7730, 'date': '2018-03-19 14:55:23.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 5:

Even if I can understand the arguments saying we want to limit the scope. Introducing a different option is going to use the exact same components in libvirt driver.

Also that In all case we are going to backport an option, which could be considered as an improvement.

I think Kayshap is already limiting the scope by focusing only on introducing that new option in nova.conf which would result to fix the issue in the right way and that even if it provides more flexibility for operators.

The real feature would be to provide such flexibility for users.

As Dan Smith indicated it's an important fix and I think that Kayshap we are all waiting for your to provide the right patch :)"}, {'account_id': 6962, 'date': '2018-03-20 17:20:40.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 6.'}, {'account_id': 6962, 'date': '2018-03-20 17:28:35.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 6: Workflow-1'}, {'account_id': 26515, 'date': '2018-03-20 22:34:42.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 6:

> Hey Tony, I've read your comments.  Afraid, I am still not
 > convinced.  Two things:
 > 
 > (a) It is not sensible to create an intentionally incompatible
 > syntax in the Nova config file when the actual Nova code to process
 > the config options is largely identical in both cases.

I'm not sure I understand "intentionally incompatible syntax" here I'd expect utilising the workarounds config option to be very small amount of code.  There would of course be 'UpgradeImpact' on going from queens -> rocky which we'd have to describe in the release notes, but I'm not sure where we're incompatible, but we can discuss that once the rest of the bits are in place.

 > (b) Imagine, if it were so that only two CPU flags were ever
 > possible: "PCID" and some "ABCD"  would it be a feature or a bug
 > fix?  It can be spun either ways.

It seems to be that anything that allows operators to turn on an arbitrary list (albeit in your example a small list) of CPU flags landing in a released service a feature not a bug.

I've already said that I think we should just backport this as-is, and made my arguments. All the risk is in the code itself, and not what people will do with it in queens vs. rocky.

That said, my primary concern is over the upgrade churn that backporting a workaround flag for one release causes for the deployment teams. Thus, I wonder if we couldn't agree on a compromise which will allow people in pre-rocky releases to enable the PCID, but without having to use a different flag until/after rocky. What if we just make the first version of this that we land restrict the valid values of that config option to *only* PCID, and then land a subsequent change to open it up wide? Then we can just backport the first patch, call it a fix (because that matters for some reason) and not have to impart a bunch of pre-planning on people for when they roll to/past rocky. Is that reasonable?"}, {'account_id': 7730, 'date': '2018-03-22 09:15:31.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 8: Code-Review-1

(1 comment)'}, {'account_id': 7730, 'date': '2018-03-22 09:21:23.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 8:

 > rocky. What if we just make the first version of this that we land

 > then land a subsequent change to open it up wide? Then we can just
 > backport the first patch, call it a fix (because that matters for
 > some reason) and not have to impart a bunch of pre-planning on
 > people for when they roll to/past rocky. Is that reasonable?

Hmm, the idea to restricting the first version of the configuration attribute to only PCID is slightly more palatable for backport-ability (FWIW, I too thought out loud about it in one of my earlier comments here). revisions:
[{'created': '2018-01-16 17:10:45.000000000', 'message': '[WIP] libvirt: Allow to specify granular CPU feature flags

With this change, it will be possible to set granular CPU features flags
as below, in /etc/nova.conf:

    ...
    [libvirt]
    cpu_model=IvyBridge
    cpu_model_extra_flags="pcid"
    ...

The list of known CPU feature flags ('vmx', 'xtpr', 'pcid', et cetera)
can be found in /usr/share/libvirt/cpu_map.xml.

Note that before specifying extra CPU feature flags, one should check if
the named CPU models (provided by libvirt) already includes the said
flags --- otherwise, it'd be pointless to do so.

Change-Id: I6bb956808aa3df58747c865c92e5b276e61aff44
'}, {'created': '2018-01-16 21:07:19.000000000', 'message': '[WIP] libvirt: Allow to specify granular CPU feature flags

tl;dr: Mitigate the performance penalty of the "Meltdown" CVE fixes by
       allowing to specify individual CPU feature flags (in this case,
       'PCID') via a Nova config attribute: `cpu_model_extra_flags`

Background
----------

The recent "Meltdown" CVE fixes resulted in criticial performance
penalty, From here[1]:

    [...] However, in examining both the various fixes rolled out in
    actual Linux distros over the past few days and doing some very
    informal surveying of environments I have access to, I discovered
    that the PCID ["process-context identifiers"] processor feature,
    which used to be a virtual no-op, is now a performance AND security
    critical item.[...]

So if a Nova user has applied all the CVE fixes, and is using a named
CPU model (like "IvyBridge", or "Westmere" --- which specifically lack
the said obscure "PCID" feature) they will incur severe performance
impact.

This change
-----------

With this patch, it will be possible to set granular CPU feature flags
for named CPU models, as below, in /etc/nova.conf:

    ...
    [libvirt]
    cpu_model=IvyBridge
    cpu_model_extra_flags="pcid"
    ...

The list of known CPU feature flags ('vmx', 'xtpr', 'pcid', et cetera)
can be found in /usr/share/libvirt/cpu_map.xml.

Note that before specifying extra CPU feature flags, one should check if
the named CPU models (provided by libvirt) already include the said
flags.

Other use cases
---------------

  - Nested Virtualization --- an operator can specify the Intel 'vmx' or
    AMD 'svm' flags in the level-1 guest (i.e. the guest hypervisor)

  - Ability to use 1GB huge pages with Haswell model as one use case for
    extra flags:

        cpu_model_extra_flags="pdpe1gb"

    (Thanks: Daniel Berrang, for mentioning this.)

[1] https://groups.google.com/forum/m/#!topic/mechanical-sympathy/L9mHTbeQLNU

Change-Id: I6bb956808aa3df58747c865c92e5b276e61aff44
'}, {'created': '2018-01-30 10:37:20.000000000', 'message': '[WIP] libvirt: Allow to specify granular CPU feature flags

The motivation for this change is to mitigate the performance penalty of
the "Meltdown" CVE fixes by allowing to specify individual CPU feature
flags (in this case, 'PCID') via a new Nova config attribute:
`cpu_model_extra_flags`.

E.g. with this change, to explicitly specify the 'pcid' feature with
Intel IvyBridge CPU model, set the following in /etc/nova.conf:

    ...
    [libvirt]
    cpu_model=IvyBridge
    cpu_model_extra_flags="pcid"
    ...

The list of known CPU feature flags ('vmx', 'xtpr', 'pcid', et cetera)
can be found in /usr/share/libvirt/cpu_map.xml.  Note that before
specifying extra CPU flags, it's useful to check if the named CPU models
provided by libvirt already include the said flags.

Other use cases:

  - Ability to use 1GB huge pages with Haswell model as one use case for
    extra flags:

        cpu_model_extra_flags="pdpe1gb"

    (Thanks: Daniel Berrang, for mentioning this.)

  - Nested Virtualization -- an operator can specify the Intel 'vmx' or
    AMD 'svm' flags in the level-1 Nova guest.

Change-Id: I6bb956808aa3df58747c865c92e5b276e61aff44
'}, {'created': '2018-02-21 14:15:14.000000000', 'message': '[WIP] libvirt: Allow to specify granular CPU feature flags

The motivation for this change is to mitigate the performance penalty of
the "Meltdown" CVE fixes by allowing to specify individual CPU feature
flags (in this case, 'PCID') via a new Nova config attribute:
`cpu_model_extra_flags`.

E.g. with this change, to explicitly specify the 'pcid' feature with
Intel IvyBridge CPU model, set the following in /etc/nova.conf:

    ...
    [libvirt]
    cpu_model=IvyBridge
    cpu_model_extra_flags="pcid"
    ...

The list of known CPU feature flags ('vmx', 'xtpr', 'pcid', et cetera)
can be found in /usr/share/libvirt/cpu_map.xml.  Note that before
specifying extra CPU flags, it's useful to check if the named CPU models
provided by libvirt already include the said flags.

Other use cases:

  - Ability to use 1GB huge pages with Haswell model as one use case for
    extra flags (thanks: Daniel Berrang, for mentioning this scenario):

        cpu_model_extra_flags=Haswell-noTSX-IBRS
        cpu_model_extra_flags="pdpe1gb"

  - Nested Virtualization  an operator can specify the Intel 'vmx' or
    AMD 'svm' flags in the level-1 Nova guest.

Closes-bug: #1750829
Change-Id: I6bb956808aa3df58747c865c92e5b276e61aff44
