'}, {'created': '2018-03-20 17:20:40.000000000', 'message': 'libvirt: Allow to specify granular CPU feature flags

The recent "Meltdown" CVE fixes have resulted in a critical performance
penalty[*] that will impact every Nova guest.

E.g. assuming an Operator has applied all the "Meltdown" CVE fixes the
following way: update 'microcode', host / guest kernels, libvirt, and
QEMU packages; followed by a cold reboot (explicit stop & start) of
guests.  Now, if any guests that are booted with certain named virtual
CPU models, e.g. "IvyBridge", or "Westmere", they (the guests) now will
incur the above mentioned performance degradation[*], while being
protected from the CVE itself.

To alleviate this performance degradation, it is now important to
specify an obscure CPU feature flag, "PCID"  for the virtual CPU models
that don't already include it.  To that end, this change will let Nova
to specificing CPU feature flags via a new configuration attribute,
'cpu_model_extra_flags', in 'nova.conf':

    ...
    [libvirt]
    cpu_model=IvyBridge
    cpu_model_extra_flags="pcid"
    ...

The list of known CPU feature flags (e.g. 'vmx', 'xtpr', 'pcid', et
cetera) can be found in /usr/share/libvirt/cpu_map.xml.  Note that
before specifying extra CPU flags, it is useful to check if the named
CPU models provided by libvirt already include the said flags.

NB: Hardcoding the PCID CPU flag into Nova is not a good idea, because:

(1) Not every Intel CPU model has PCID:

     - The only Intel CPU models that include the PCID capability are:
       'Haswell', 'Broadwell', and 'Skylake' variants.

     - The libvirt / QEMU Intel CPU models: 'Nehalem', 'Westmere',
       'SandyBridge', and 'IvyBridge' will *not* expose the PCID
       capability, even if the host CPUs by the same name include it.

(2) Magically adding new CPU feature flags under the user's feet
    impacts live migration.

[*] https://groups.google.com/forum/m/#!topic/mechanical-sympathy/L9mHTbeQLNU

Closes-Bug: #1750829
Change-Id: I6bb956808aa3df58747c865c92e5b276e61aff44
BluePrint: libvirt-cpu-model-extra-flags

'}, {'created': '2018-03-25 13:39:55.000000000', 'message': 'libvirt: Allow to specify granular CPU feature flags

The recent "Meltdown" CVE fixes have resulted in a critical performance
penalty[*] that will impact every Nova guest with certain CPU models.

I.e. assume you have applied all the "Meltdown" CVE fixes, and performed
a cold reboot (explicit stop & start) of all Nova guests, for the
updates to take effect.  Now, if any guests that are booted with certain
named virtual CPU models (e.g. "IvyBridge", "Westmere", etc), then those
guests, will incur noticeable performance degradation[*], while being
protected from the CVE itself.

To alleviate this guest performance impact, it is now important to
specify an obscure CPU feature flag, 'PCID' (Processor-Context ID) --
for the virtual CPU models that don't already include it (more on this
below).  To that end, this change will allow Nova to specify explicit
CPU feature flags via a new configuration attribute,
`cpu_model_extra_flags`, in 'nova.conf':

    ...
    [libvirt]
    cpu_mode = custom
    cpu_model = IvyBridge
    cpu_model_extra_flags = pcid
    ...

NB: In the first iteration, the choices for `cpu_model_extra_flags` is
restricted to only 'PCID', to address the earlier mentioned guest
performance degradation.  A future patch will remove this restriction,
allowing multiple CPU feature flags, thus making way for other useful
features.

Some have asked: "Why not simply hardcode the 'PCID' CPU feature flag
into Nova?"  That is not a viable option, because:

(1) Not every Intel CPU model has PCID:

    - The only Intel CPU models that include the PCID capability are:
      "Haswell", "Broadwell", and "Skylake" variants.

    - The libvirt / QEMU Intel CPU models: "Nehalem", "Westmere",
      "SandyBridge", and "IvyBridge" will *not* expose the PCID
      capability, even if the host CPUs by the same name include it.
      I.e.  'PCID' needs to be explicitly when using the said virtual
      CPU models.

(2) Magically adding new CPU feature flags under the user's feet impacts
    live migration.

[*] https://groups.google.com/forum/m/#!topic/mechanical-sympathy/L9mHTbeQLNU

Closes-Bug: #1750829
Change-Id: I6bb956808aa3df58747c865c92e5b276e61aff44
BluePrint: libvirt-cpu-model-extra-flags

'}, {'created': '2018-03-27 07:05:33.000000000', 'message': 'libvirt: Allow to specify granular CPU feature flags

The recent "Meltdown" CVE fixes have resulted in a critical performance
penalty[*] that will impact every Nova guest with certain CPU models.

I.e. assume you have applied all the "Meltdown" CVE fixes, and performed
a cold reboot (explicit stop & start) of all Nova guests, for the
updates to take effect.  Now, if any guests that are booted with certain
named virtual CPU models (e.g. "IvyBridge", "Westmere", etc), then those
guests, will incur noticeable performance degradation[*], while being
protected from the CVE itself.

To alleviate this guest performance impact, it is now important to
specify an obscure CPU feature flag, 'PCID' (Processor-Context ID) --
for the virtual CPU models that don't already include it (more on this
below).  To that end, this change will allow Nova to specify explicit
CPU feature flags via a new configuration attribute,
`cpu_model_extra_flags`, e.g. in `nova.conf`:

    ...
    [libvirt]
    cpu_mode = custom
    cpu_model = IvyBridge
    cpu_model_extra_flags = pcid
    ...

NB: In the first iteration, the choices for `cpu_model_extra_flags` is
restricted to only 'PCID' -- to address the earlier mentioned guest
performance degradation.  A future patch will remove this restriction,
allowing to add / remove multiple CPU feature flags, thus making way for
other useful features.

Some have asked: "Why not simply hardcode the 'PCID' CPU feature flag
into Nova?"  That's not graceful, and more importantly, impractical:

  (1) Not every Intel CPU model has 'PCID':

       - The only Intel CPU models that include the 'PCID' capability
         are: "Haswell", "Broadwell", and "Skylake" variants.

       - The libvirt / QEMU Intel CPU models: "Nehalem", "Westmere",
         "SandyBridge", and "IvyBridge" will *not* expose the 'PCID'
         capability, even if the host CPUs by the same name include it.
         I.e. 'PCID' needs to be explicitly when using the said virtual
         CPU models.

  (2) Magically adding new CPU feature flags under the user's feet
      impacts live migration.

'}, {'created': '2018-03-27 15:26:54.000000000', 'message': 'libvirt: Allow to specify granular CPU feature flags

The recent "Meltdown" CVE fixes have resulted in a critical performance
penalty[*] that will impact every Nova guest with certain CPU models.

I.e. assume you have applied all the "Meltdown" CVE fixes, and performed
a cold reboot (explicit stop & start) of all Nova guests, for the
updates to take effect.  Now, if any guests that are booted with certain
named virtual CPU models (e.g. "IvyBridge", "Westmere", etc), then those
guests, will incur noticeable performance degradation[*], while being
protected from the CVE itself.

To alleviate this guest performance impact, it is now important to
specify an obscure CPU feature flag, 'PCID' (Processor-Context ID) --
for the virtual CPU models that don't already include it (more on this
below).  To that end, this change will allow Nova to specify explicit
CPU feature flags via a new configuration attribute,
`cpu_model_extra_flags`, e.g. in `nova.conf`:

    ...
    [libvirt]
    cpu_mode = custom
    cpu_model = IvyBridge
    cpu_model_extra_flags = pcid
    ...

NB: In the first iteration, the choices for `cpu_model_extra_flags` is
restricted to only 'PCID' -- to address the earlier mentioned guest
performance degradation.  A future patch will remove this restriction,
allowing to add / remove multiple CPU feature flags, thus making way for
other useful features.

Some have asked: "Why not simply hardcode the 'PCID' CPU feature flag
into Nova?"  That's not graceful, and more importantly, impractical:

  (1) Not every Intel CPU model has 'PCID':

       - The only Intel CPU models that include the 'PCID' capability
         are: "Haswell", "Broadwell", and "Skylake" variants.

       - The libvirt / QEMU Intel CPU models: "Nehalem", "Westmere",
         "SandyBridge", and "IvyBridge" will *not* expose the 'PCID'
         capability, even if the host CPUs by the same name include it.
         I.e. 'PCID' needs to be explicitly when using the said virtual
         CPU models.

  (2) Magically adding new CPU feature flags under the user's feet
      impacts live migration.

[*] https://groups.google.com/forum/m/#!topic/mechanical-sympathy/L9mHTbeQLNU

Closes-Bug: #1750829
Change-Id: I6bb956808aa3df58747c865c92e5b276e61aff44
BluePrint: libvirt-cpu-model-extra-flags

commit_message:
libvirt: Allow to specify granular CPU feature flags

The recent "Meltdown" CVE fixes have resulted in a critical performance
penalty[*] that will impact every Nova guest with certain CPU models.

I.e. assume you have applied all the "Meltdown" CVE fixes, and performed
a cold reboot (explicit stop & start) of all Nova guests, for the
updates to take effect.  Now, if any guests that are booted with certain
named virtual CPU models (e.g. "IvyBridge", "Westmere", etc), then those
guests, will incur noticeable performance degradation[*], while being
protected from the CVE itself.

To alleviate this guest performance impact, it is now important to
specify an obscure Intel CPU feature flag, 'PCID' (Process-Context ID)
-- for the virtual CPU models that don't already include it (more on
this below).  To that end, this change will allow Nova to explicitly
specify CPU feature flags via a new configuration attribute,
`cpu_model_extra_flags`, e.g. in `nova.conf`:

    ...
    [libvirt]
    cpu_mode = custom
    cpu_model = IvyBridge
    cpu_model_extra_flags = pcid
    ...

NB: In the first iteration, the choices for `cpu_model_extra_flags` is
restricted to only 'pcid' (the option is case-insensitive) -- to address
the earlier mentioned guest performance degradation.  A future patch
will remove this restriction, allowing to add / remove multiple CPU
feature flags, thus making way for other useful features.

Some have asked: "Why not simply hardcode the 'PCID' CPU feature flag
into Nova?"  That's not graceful, and more importantly, impractical:

  (1) Not every Intel CPU model has 'PCID':

       - The only Intel CPU models that include the 'PCID' capability
         are: "Haswell", "Broadwell", and "Skylake" variants.

       - The libvirt / QEMU Intel CPU models: "Nehalem", "Westmere",
         "SandyBridge", and "IvyBridge" will *not* expose the 'PCID'
         capability, even if the host CPUs by the same name include it.
         I.e. 'PCID' needs to be explicitly when using the said virtual
         CPU models.

  (2) Magically adding new CPU feature flags under the user's feet
      impacts live migration.

[*] https://groups.google.com/forum/m/#!topic/mechanical-sympathy/L9mHTbeQLNU

Closes-Bug: #1750829
Change-Id: I6bb956808aa3df58747c865c92e5b276e61aff44
BluePrint: libvirt-cpu-model-extra-flags

commit_message:
Add reno, doc build job for valence

Valence team is planning first release for
valence and below patch is adding the reno for
the same.
- https://review.openstack.org/#/c/559010/3

let's add reno and doc build job for valence.

revisions:
[{'created': '2018-04-06 18:18:04.000000000', 'message': "Fix join examples and text

The 'join' example for using a number did not have a proper workflow.
It looks like it was copied from the 'all' example and not completely
changed. Also, disambiguate the wording of the description for that
example. It used the word 'once' in a place where it looked as though
it meant 'one time' instead of 'as soon as'.

Change-Id: I9b89768c0f0b7d325db08ea9345965a9263a64c8
Closes-Bug: #1761827
"}]
commit_message:
Fix join examples and text

The 'join' example for using a number did not have a proper workflow.
It looks like it was copied from the 'all' example and not completely
changed. Also, disambiguate the wording of the description for that
example. It used the word 'once' in a place where it looked as though
it meant 'one time' instead of 'as soon as'.

Change-Id: I9b89768c0f0b7d325db08ea9345965a9263a64c8
Closes-Bug: #1761827

commit_message:
Fix mode for openstack services

OpenStack services are generally http services. The mode for
these endpoints should be http otherwise logging will fallback
tcplog.

Change-Id: If3b50718027a4a52df3453feb6fc332d2966ffd0
Closes-Bug: #1759690

commit_message:
Repair htmlify-log.py command

This command seems to have been left behind when the rest of the project
updated to use generators and filters. This patch updates that command
to use the new way of processing a log file.

Change-Id: Id04b4d4f571110faa0f32079defab94f4491f344

[{'created': '2018-03-14 15:30:51.000000000', 'message': "Fix logic to require external bridge for computes in dvr mode

With introduction of 'dvr_no_external' mode and new groups of
compute nodes (https://review.openstack.org/#/c/510327) the

commit_message:
Fix logic to require external bridge for computes in dvr mode

With introduction of 'dvr_no_external' mode and new groups of
compute nodes (https://review.openstack.org/#/c/510327) the
logic for requiring external bridges should take into account
what group a particular compute node is in. If it is
'inner-compute' then an external bridge is not required.

Change-Id: I9c9c0854ad93a92ca93e68ed26603061521ad621
Closes-Bug: #1755840

commit_message:
Clean up tox.ini

* execute unit tests in lower-contraints job
* move `ostestr` to [testenv] section
* remove redundant configuration
* wrap long lines

Change-Id: I2f698e19f19fb6d37c2062c5d9c2c252a7ad0be1

commit_message:
Adding test_unicode to skip list

* Due to migration unicode_messages code, the unicode tests are
  failing. We are adding it to skip list to block tempest
  plugin split goal.

Depends-On: https://review.openstack.org/#/c/540852/

Change-Id: Idb6ba9326ac97310c00aab31a042515d16023219
Story: 2001517
Task: 6317

commit_message:
Add heat dashboard for deb/ubuntu binary

The python-heat-dashboard was missing from Debian/Ubuntu binary horizon
images. This commit adds it since the deb package is now available in
the repositories.

Change-Id: Id0462419b97b8f1027a3ed9190b3ef57af8a7e3d
(cherry picked from commit 0c7b34962026c23c5badbf7a42aa6b8ba6be6c53)

commit_message:
add lower-constraints job

Create a tox environment for running the unit tests against the lower
bounds of the dependencies.

Create a lower-constraints.txt to be used to enforce the lower bounds
in those tests.

Add openstack-tox-lower-constraints job to the zuul configuration.

See http://lists.openstack.org/pipermail/openstack-dev/2018-March/128352.html
for more details.

Change-Id: I14210959ffc1488a6422c6f254f92298bbcaab4b
Depends-On: https://review.openstack.org/555034
Signed-off-by: Doug Hellmann <doug@doughellmann.com>

commit_message:
Move coverage reports to `cover` directory

Zuul's fetch-coverage-output role [1] expects coverage reports in `cover`
directory. This commit updates the target directory in the `run_test.sh` script.

[1] http://git.openstack.org/cgit/openstack-infra/zuul-jobs/tree/roles/fetch-coverage-output

Change-Id: I5375e6136222aa1be4dce207e4cc9e1d0ed0f13c

commit_message:
When copying glance-swift.conf ensure mode and become used

This makes it so that the file copied has the same perms
as the other copied files and that become is used so that the
copy works (otherwise it does not).

Change-Id: I22f39ef30760701e174f304de6ff959ff60607ad

commit_message:
Defend against neutron error response missing keys

I *have* seen this in the wild (it caused problems in our cloud with
Liberty neutron), and while I am unsure of the exact cause, it can't
hurt to code a little bit defensively!

Change-Id: I46ec944f7035fd7a5a09b7e7e4a4a38692039ab7

revisions:
[{'created': '2018-04-04 22:32:34.000000000', 'message': 'Make keepalived initialization more predictable

This prevents forcing keepalived to renegotiate roles between amps more
times than necessary.

Keepalived is already running at the point that we do our initial "amp
start" command, so if we actually force a restart it loses its state and
has to renegotiate. I would consider the fact that this works without
issue right now "very good luck". Let's make this more sane, and only
reload if that's what we need to do.

Change-Id: Ie920bba9b2d718c59c6ce00c0f013058ed2634bb
'}, {'created': '2018-04-08 12:29:10.000000000', 'message': 'Make keepalived initialization more predictable

This prevents forcing keepalived to renegotiate roles between amps more
times than necessary.

Keepalived is already running at the point that we do our initial "amp
start" command, so if we actually force a restart it loses its state and
has to renegotiate. I would consider the fact that this works without
issue right now "very good luck". Let's make this more sane, and only
reload if that's what we need to do.

Change-Id: Ie920bba9b2d718c59c6ce00c0f013058ed2634bb
'}]
commit_message:
Make keepalived initialization more predictable

This prevents forcing keepalived to renegotiate roles between amps more
times than necessary.

Keepalived is already running at the point that we do our initial "amp
start" command, so if we actually force a restart it loses its state and
has to renegotiate. I would consider the fact that this works without
issue right now "very good luck". Let's make this more sane, and only
reload if that's what we need to do.

Change-Id: Ie920bba9b2d718c59c6ce00c0f013058ed2634bb

commit_message:
Change sysmeta name from swift3 to s3api

And add a magic to translate existing swift3 sysmeta to s3api sysmeta
at swift.common.middleware.s3api.response.Response to upgrade easy from swift3
to s3api.

Change-Id: I4c11274a69863be04fd2b1ca4c1d4d9aadbff2de

Specification for allowing Kolla Ceph to deploy bluestore OSDs

Describes the proposed approach to introduce Ceph blustore[1] OSDs
in Kolla.

[{'account_id': 11278, 'date': '2018-03-28 04:25:14.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 1.'}, {'account_id': 18591, 'date': '2018-03-29 01:07:40.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1: Code-Review+1

Congress won't be able to reflect many of the other options without restart, so it could create some complication for deployers who can't be sure which mutations in config will and which won't be reflected. commit_message:
Enable mutable config in Congress

New releases of oslo.config support a 'mutable' parameter to Opts.
oslo.service provides an option here Icec3e664f3fe72614e373b2938e8dee53cf8bc5e
allows services to tell oslo.service they want mutate_config_files to be
called by passing a parameter. This commit is to use the same.

This allows Congress to benefit from
I1e7a69de169cc85f4c09954b2f46ce2da7106d90, where the 'debug' option
(owned by oslo.log) is made mutable. we should be able to turn debug logging
on and off by changing the config.

tc goal: https://governance.openstack.org/tc/goals/rocky/enable-mutable-configuration.html
Change-Id: Ia82715af8a8174e4f0d89ee1d9609487654e4e03

subject: Adds configuration for notification-format
messages:
[{'account_id': 12767, 'date': '2018-04-06 06:01:49.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 1.'}, {'account_id': 20634, 'date': '2018-04-09 06:49:40.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1: Code-Review-1

Echoing James Page's comments in the linked launchpad bug, I think it would make more sense for us to take an opinionated stance here and not add a new charm configuration option"}, {'account_id': 12767, 'date': '2018-04-09 07:07:55.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1:

I'd seen and understood the opinionated stance, I just felt there was still value in being able to configure notification-format as needed.

Happy to abandon this change though, if it's not deemed desirable."}, {'account_id': 20634, 'date': '2018-04-09 07:09:47.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1:

In the long run, I think we'll be able to infer the need for versioned / unversioned / both as juju goal-state comes into being; however, if we add this configuration option, it becomes very difficult to ever remove it"}, {'account_id': 12767, 'date': '2018-04-09 07:15:53.000000000', 'content': 'Abandoned

Deferring to an opinionated stance on the setting.'}]

commit_message:
Adds configuration for notification-format

Provides the ability for configure the oslo_messaging_notifications
setting notification-format to either versioned or unversioned from the
default, both.

Relies on charm-helpers pull #145
https://github.com/juju/charm-helpers/pull/145

Change-Id: Ib3034f3da4b92c4780b215b444ea2a40cae25807
Closes-Bug: #1731828

[{'created': '2018-03-16 18:43:29.000000000', 'message': 'Add a devstack variable for legacy RBAC

This patch adds the OCTAVIA_USE_LEGACY_RBAC variable to our devstack plugin.
When set to True it will install the legacy Admin/Owner RBAC policy.json file
for the devstack Octavia install.
This is useful for tempest testing the neutron-lbaas proxy driver that passes
neutron LBaaSv2 API requests through to the Octavia API.

Change-Id: I5f112131b9c57e394349f29fa1b675643784b867
'}]
commit_message:
Add a devstack variable for legacy RBAC

This patch adds the OCTAVIA_USE_LEGACY_RBAC variable to our devstack plugin.
When set to True it will install the legacy Admin/Owner RBAC policy.json file
for the devstack Octavia install.
This is useful for tempest testing the neutron-lbaas proxy driver that passes
neutron LBaaSv2 API requests through to the Octavia API.

Change-Id: I5f112131b9c57e394349f29fa1b675643784b867

subject: Correct the InternalTLSVncCAFile to comply with selinux policy
reviewers: [{'_account_id': 3153, 'name': 'Emilien Macchi', 'email': 'emilien@redhat.com', 'username': 'emilienm'}, {'_account_id': 8161, 'name': 'Lon Hohberger', 'email': 'lhh@redhat.com', 'username': 'lon'}, {'_account_id': 9414, 'name': 'zhongshengping', 'email': 'chdzsp@163.com', 'username': 'ZhongShengping'}, {'_account_id': 10873, 'name': 'Juan Antonio Osorio Robles', 'email': 'jaosorior@redhat.com', 'username': 'ejuaoso'}, {'_account_id': 14985, 'name': 'Alex Schultz', 'email': 'aschultz@next-development.com', 'username': 'mwhahaha'}, {'_account_id': 22348, 'name': 'Zuul', 'username': 'zuul', 'tags': ['SERVICE_USER']}, {'_account_id': 23181, 'name': 'RDO Third Party CI', 'email': 'dmsimard+rdothirdparty@redhat.com', 'username': 'rdothirdparty', 'tags': ['SERVICE_USER']}, {'_account_id': 23811, 'name': 'Oliver Walsh', 'email': 'owalsh@redhat.com', 'username': 'owalsh'}]
revisions:
[{'created': '2018-04-06 16:42:34.000000000', 'message': 'Correct the InternalTLSVncCAFile to comply with selinux policy

InternalTLSVncCAFile currently defaults to /etc/ipa/vnc.crt.
Certmonger attempts to save the CA cert to this path as cert_t, however
/etc/ipa is etc_t.
Moving to /etc/pki/CA/certs which is cert_t resolves the issue, and is
arugably a more suitable location.

Change-Id: Ib275fc43dd772851511598a4932c19fcda706479
'}]
commit_message:
Correct the InternalTLSVncCAFile to comply with selinux policy

InternalTLSVncCAFile currently defaults to /etc/ipa/vnc.crt.
Certmonger attempts to save the CA cert to this path as cert_t, however
/etc/ipa is etc_t.
Moving to /etc/pki/CA/certs which is cert_t resolves the issue, and is
arugably a more suitable location.

Change-Id: Ib275fc43dd772851511598a4932c19fcda706479

subject: Fix creation of resolv.conf on bionic nodes
messages: [{'account_id': 13252, 'date': '2018-04-06 14:50:02.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 1.'}, {'account_id': 13252, 'date': '2018-04-09 06:54:31.000000000', 'content': 'Abandoned\n\nBetter solution in https://review.openstack.org/557842'}]
revisions:
[{'created': '2018-04-06 14:50:02.000000000', 'message': "Fix creation of resolv.conf on bionic nodes

Currently /etc/resolv.conf is a dangling symlink on bionic:

root@ubuntu-bionic-inap-mtl01-0003371066:~# ls -l /etc/resolv.conf
lrwxrwxrwx 1 root root 39 Apr  6 01:29 /etc/resolv.conf ->
../run/systemd/resolve/stub-resolv.conf

Thus the

echo 'nameserver 127.0.0.1' > /etc/resolv.conf

in rc.local fails.

Change-Id: I423f5536836e85acabf364c325ebc5d1c44cb2ca
"}]
commit_message:
Fix creation of resolv.conf on bionic nodes

Currently /etc/resolv.conf is a dangling symlink on bionic:

root@ubuntu-bionic-inap-mtl01-0003371066:~# ls -l /etc/resolv.conf
lrwxrwxrwx 1 root root 39 Apr  6 01:29 /etc/resolv.conf ->
../run/systemd/resolve/stub-resolv.conf

Thus the

echo 'nameserver 127.0.0.1' > /etc/resolv.conf

in rc.local fails.

Change-Id: I423f5536836e85acabf364c325ebc5d1c44cb2ca

commit_message:
add openstacksdk project as a cloud-client

List the openstacksdk among the official projects on the
language-bindings page for rocky and beyond.

The repo will be ignored until the rename is completed and the
governance patch is approved and merged.

Depends-On: https://review.openstack.org/555780/

commit_message:
Add redirect for python-openstacksdk project rename

Add a macro to make generating the redirect and tests for a project
rename easy.

Redirect python-openstacksdk to the new name openstacksdk.

Because the .htaccess template generates redirects for all official
projects, this patch won't pass the tests until the governance change
with the rename is approved and merged, so that patch is included as a
depends-on.

Depends-On: https://review.openstack.org/555780/
Co-Authored-By: Monty Taylor <mordred@inaugust.com>
Change-Id: I97afa686cac31b2ef8beac1df49f98625dee703d

commit_message:
tests: don't rely on configuration files outside tests directory

Following the similar Neutron change. [1]

Recently, the way sibling projects are installed were changed.
It broke networking-midonet gate as neutron-fwaas was installed
under site-packages, where the etc directory is not available.

[1] If1f5ebd981cf06558d5102524211799676068889

Closes-Bug: #1758062
Change-Id: I72aeeac8cbe07f6fc6cb4acf54fb632587d890a0
(cherry picked from commit e1231cd6eabb0992820d0c0fdc629c8a96b5f6b9)

tests: don't rely on configuration files outside tests directory

Following the similar Neutron change. [1]

Recently, the way sibling projects are installed were changed.
It broke networking-midonet gate as neutron-fwaas was installed
under site-packages, where the etc directory is not available.

[1] If1f5ebd981cf06558d5102524211799676068889

Closes-Bug: #1758062
Change-Id: I72aeeac8cbe07f6fc6cb4acf54fb632587d890a0
(cherry picked from commit e1231cd6eabb0992820d0c0fdc629c8a96b5f6b9)

commit_message:
Reverse sort previous elections output

Our current list appears to be unsorted at best, leading to an out of
order history of the previous elections.  Reverse the list displaying
recent (first) to latest (last) results.

Change-Id: I8228aeaac205c35633f3c6e5279497c6b7177125
Signed-off-by: Paul Belanger <pabelanger@redhat.com>

messages: [{'account_id': 11536, 'date': '2018-04-09 01:32:51.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 1.'}, {'account_id': 23365, 'date': '2018-04-09 02:59:19.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Code-Review+2'}, {'account_id': 22076, 'date': '2018-04-09 03:09:55.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Workflow+1 Code-Review+2'}]
revisions:
[{'created': '2018-04-09 01:32:51.000000000', 'message': 'Skip validating the subnetpool if it is none

In the kuryr driver module, it tries to validate the subnetpool
even if the subnetpool_id is None. This incurrs an extra API
call to Neutron to list the subnetpools.

Change-Id: I0f25eadb68858ec89d00432b03f715c5cb6c0c46
'}]
commit_message:
Skip validating the subnetpool if it is none

In the kuryr driver module, it tries to validate the subnetpool
even if the subnetpool_id is None. This incurrs an extra API
call to Neutron to list the subnetpools.

Change-Id: I0f25eadb68858ec89d00432b03f715c5cb6c0c46

subject: Remove a redundant call of 'save'
messages: [{'account_id': 11536, 'date': '2018-04-09 01:26:24.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 1.'}, {'account_id': 23365, 'date': '2018-04-09 03:00:53.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Code-Review+2'}, {'account_id': 22076, 'date': '2018-04-09 03:09:48.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Workflow+1 Code-Review+2'}]
revisions:
[{'created': '2018-04-09 01:26:24.000000000', 'message': "Remove a redundant call of 'save'

In the kuryr module, there is a call on saving the security groups
into the container object on processing the neutron port.
This call is unnecessary because the container object will be
saved again by caller. This patch removes this call.

Change-Id: I68ca6a7c70e1e1b576a3f2d560b480ff6d52e42e
"}]
commit_message:
Remove a redundant call of 'save'

In the kuryr module, there is a call on saving the security groups
into the container object on processing the neutron port.
This call is unnecessary because the container object will be
saved again by caller. This patch removes this call.

Change-Id: I68ca6a7c70e1e1b576a3f2d560b480ff6d52e42e

subject: Present container deletion better
messages: [{'account_id': 16352, 'date': '2018-04-09 03:11:56.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Cherry Picked from branch master.'}, {'account_id': 16352, 'date': '2018-04-09 03:38:31.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Workflow+1 Code-Review+2'}]
revisions:
[{'created': '2018-04-09 03:11:56.000000000', 'message': "Present container deletion better

Zun server has changed from synchronous deletion to asynchronous
deletion. This mean Zun accepts a request to delete a container
but the container is not deleted right away. In the UI, it is
better to present the container in 'deleting' state instead of
removing the container from displaying.

Change-Id: I05c64a1388356887aba19dc94f27dbbd0d0bcc02

commit_message:
Present container deletion better

Zun server has changed from synchronous deletion to asynchronous
deletion. This mean Zun accepts a request to delete a container
but the container is not deleted right away. In the UI, it is
better to present the container in 'deleting' state instead of
removing the container from displaying.

Change-Id: I05c64a1388356887aba19dc94f27dbbd0d0bcc02
(cherry picked from commit 6f4827bea65134f152a85980bbe0a0accc0c26ce)

commit_message:
admin cannot operate ordinary tenant's container

Admin user should be able to manipulate containers created by
normal users.
For example: start container, delete container, show container, etc.

Change-Id: Ia3a38497d5b9cdb241bc80ab506f156c98d9dded
Closes-Bug: #1756017

commit_message:
Check disk quota support on filter scheduler

The compute manager will provide information about if the node
support disk quota. The DiskFilter will schedule container
based on the disk quota support. If the container request
non-zero amount of disk, the filter scheduler will place the
container to the node that supports disk quota.

Change-Id: I8c4df909775fe120156bb058adf17381205d5a39

commit_message:
Add disk_quota_supported to compute_node

Add 'disk_quota_supported' field to the data model of compute node.
This field will be leveraged by the scheduler to do filtering based
on disk quota supported of each node.

Change-Id: I8c449c2a44bd6afbc79c4accb083d9f1bf51085a

commit_message:
Print a warning if disk quota is not unsupported

If the CONF.default_disk is configured to be non-zero but the node
doesn't support disk quota. Zun will ignore the configured
default because it is impossible to be realized. A warning message
will be printed to the log as a record.

Change-Id: Ie322984d5f3212e139470b80076c781b5996a9b1

commit_message:
Cleanup and rename test_create_ebs_image_and_check_boot

I'm trying to debug a failure in a nova change
in test_create_ebs_image_and_check_boot but
need more debug information, specifically the
volume details when it fails. While doing this,
I'm going to cleanup the comments and variable
names so this test can actually be understanble.

Also, this renames the test itself since the 'ebs'
part (AWS Elastic Block Storage) has long been a
source of confusion.

Change-Id: I4d60adc95d72be609927e36a28fd7c86b5ee86bc
Related-Bug: #1747693

[{'account_id': 2799, 'date': '2018-01-23 16:30:16.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 1.'}, {'account_id': 2799, 'date': '2018-01-23 16:30:45.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1: Workflow-1

I'm going to -W until Logan has a chance to review."}, {'account_id': 17799, 'date': '2018-01-24 01:49:20.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1: Code-Review+2

This seems fine. The reason I added this was because ceph-ansible had serialized service restarts for a while, and then they inexplicably removed them, then added them back again[1]. That occurrence has made me extremely hesitant to allow these roles to operate on more than 1 host at a time, especially mons. Obviously it doesn't make sense to serial: 1 on the OSDs, but I feel like the runtime impact vs. the safety gained is huge by operating against the mons in serial: 1 at all times. I really wish we had more information in the bug to evaluate whether its something that could simply be fixed upstream to permit serialized ceph-mon execution.

So I'm fine with this change, but I'm worried it could backfire on us some day. Hopefully that won't happen again. :)

[1] https://github.com/ceph/ceph-ansible/issues/1989"}, {'account_id': 2799, 'date': '2018-03-01 10:01:04.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1:

I will follow up with guits and leseb on that before removing my -w, I don't think that will happen because I believe it's part of their upgrade etc strategy now. I've just fixed them up in both stable 3.0 and master branches: https://github.com/ceph/ceph-ansible/commit/59a4335a5639c9be12ee8a23805aaa14882b077e"}, {'account_id': 2799, 'date': '2018-03-05 17:39:33.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1: -Workflow

commit_message:
Install mon servers in parallel.

The ceph-ansible roles handle restarting services in serial via a
script, so we shouldn't need to run this in serial.

Change-Id: Ia2f2694abe02af282e7a98fcc40410b0510cc1cd
Closes-Bug: #1741085

commit_message:
Make memcache limit_maxbytes configurable

The "limit_maxbytes" default value is 64M. It is not a proper setting
for large cluster. We should make it configurable to fit with more
deployment cases.

Change-Id: I9a85b1b3ade7498495f510897292ae1ed9d73bfa
Closes-Bug: #1758286

commit_message:
Fix revert method for batch member update

The create/delete reverts worked because the old/new member lists were
simply db object lists, but the update list is tuples of (obj, dict) and
need a little bit of massaging.

Change-Id: I423f9a679c161b11cf51337717e4e7e73d71a1b3
